column2: Ira D. Sankey has returned from Scotland for a month's visit among old friends in the United States. Last night he sang at Jerry McAuley's Cremorne Mission, in West Thirty-second-street. The little mission room was running over with auditors, and Jerry McAuley's heart was running over with gladness.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 3.--The Prohibition State Convention was organized to-day with the Rev. William McKee, of Dayton, as temporary Chairman, and C.L. Tambing Secretary. A committee was appointed to make full nominations and name the committees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3.--Everybody in and out of Congress is hoping that the two houses will adjourn on Monday, but everybody wonders why, if the two houses can waste hours, as they did to-day, in making stump-speeches, an adjournment cannot be taken on Saturday.

It was said to be the secret hope of some of these politicians that the great cables would snap in twain ...

LONDON, Aug. 3.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Gladstone proposed not to take up the Arrears of Rent bill until Tuesday, as he did not wish to do anything precipitately before arriving at what might be a momentous decision.
LONDON, Aug. 3.--The Peterhead fishing fleet has been caught in a gale. Two hundred boats are still missing.
The fifteenth annual picnic and camp-fire of of Keltes Post, No. 32, G.A.R., will be held at Funk's Park, One Hundred and Thirty-third-street and the East Boulevard, on Monday, Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3.--Lieut.-Col. Godfrey Weitzel, Corps of Engineers, has been detailed as a member of the Commission Advisory to the Board of Harbor Commissioners of the City of Philadelphia, constituted in orders from the Executive Mansion May 25, 1880, and announced in special orders May 27, 1880, vice Col. John N. Macomb, late of the Corps of Engineers, who has retired from active service.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 3.--Akron is in a state of ferment over a dam. The Hydraulic Company constructed one, which the Straw Board Company tore away, claiming that it was the means of polluting the water and damaging their business.

Thirteen of the striking freight handlers returned to their work yesterday at the Jersey City docks of the Pennsylvania Railroad at the old rate of 17 cents per hour. Canadian papers say that the Princes Louise is occupying much of her time sketching Quebec scenery. An electric light experiment in Ottawa, Canada, has, according to the correspondent of the Montreal Witness, been a sad failure, after costing the city $15,700.

BUFFALO, Aug. 3.--This was the third day of the meeting of the Buffalo Driving Park Association. The weather was bright and warm and the attendance was the largest of the season. The track was in fine condition. The free for all pacers, postponed from yesterday after two heats had been made, was finished to-day.

AOLA, Kan., Aug. 3.--The Greenback convention of the Second District of this State yesterday nominated Col. F.M. Fennicum for congress. Allen Williams was nominated as candidate for Congressman at Large.

There will be music on the Mail in Central Park this afternoon, commencing at 4 o'clock. The friends of Judge John Henry McCarthy will have an excursion and dinner to Point View Grove, Long Island, on Thursday next.

The West has for a long time been addicted to cyclones and to forest fires, but until recently it was imagined that the two things were perfectly distinct. There were, however, certain peculiarities in the last great forest fire in Michigan which attracted the attention of scientific persons and led to what is thought to be a grand discovery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4, 1882. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $113,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $493,885.95, and from Customs, $1,010,555.10.

BOSTON, Aug. 4.--The Mount Desert robbery turns out to be a more serious affair pecuniarily than was at first reported. One of the gentlemen lost $1,200 and the other $1,100, while two gold watches were taken from the ladies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4.--The House today worked for several hours without intermission in disposing of appropriation bills. The naval bill was reported back by Mr. Robeson from the conference committee in such shape as to leave only one point of difference between the House and the Senate.

It has long been rumored, and by many believed, that Mrs. Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," drew the character of Uncle Tom from an old negro who formerly lived here, and whom she met during her visits to her brother, the Rev. H. W. Beecher, while he resided in this city.
A young man in Toronto, Canada, who took a pledge not to drink at a public bar, has his liquor sent out to him and drinks it standing on the sidewalk.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 4.--Notwithstanding that a vigilant system of night patrol has been adopted since the occurrence of the daring burglaries last week, several more bold attempts at burglary have occurred this week. A second attempt to rob the residence of J.C. Fisher, a wealthy resident of the place, was frustrated last night by Mr. James L. Phelps, of Brooklyn, who was visiting the house.

PANAMA, July 25.--The revolution, headed by Eloy Alfaro, in Ecuador, has proved most successful. Alfaro landed near Emaraldas, as already reported, and commenced to organize a government and discipline his forces, which were continually increased by hundreds who flocked to his standard. The effort of Veintemilla to retain power as Dictator was his downfall.

ALBANY, Aug. 4.--Following are the official semi-annual reports of the 14 savings banks of Kings County, showing their condition on July 1. They have aggregate resources of $76,183,409.38, and liabilities of $66,461,408.53, of which sum $66,445,187.14 is due to their depositors, leaving a net surplus on the basis of market values of $9,722,000.85. The number of open accounts is 179,955.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 4.--The condition of municipal affairs here still remains unchanged, and the dual set of Funder and Headjuster officers are still on duty, exercising their prerogatives. The Funder Police force still keep the station-house, while the force appointed by the Readjuster Council have established their head-quarters at the city jail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Gustavus Goward, of Illinois, to be Secretary of the Legation and Consul-General at Madrid; Charles Seymour, of Wisconsin, Consul at Canton; Second Lieut. William H. Hand, of the Revenue Service, to be First Lieutenant.

FERNANDINA, Fla., Aug. 4.--Merrick Jackson, colored, was hanged here at 1 o'clock this afternoon. He murdered a colored boy named John Thomas, near King's Ferry, on Nov. 19, 1881. On the scaffold he offered up a prayer and thanked the Sisters of Charity for their kindness to him. He met his fate with composure, and died by strangulation.

CHATHAM, Va., Aug. 4.--Walter Hamilton Yeatts was hanged here to-day for the murder of Presly E. Adkerson in February last. The hanging was private, being witnessed only by the officers of the court, special guards, physicians, and representatives of the press. The effect upon the Arrears of Rent bill of the amendments offered by the Marquis of SALISBURY and adopted by the House of Lords is to rob the measure of all promise of successful working and to deprive it of those features which the Government deems most beneficent and useful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4.--It is learned tonight that Senor Montufar, Minister of Guatemala to the United States, has filed a notice at the State Department of his resignation of the position he has held here. A strange story is given as accounting for this resignation.

DUBLIN, Aug. 4.--A serious strike among the Irish Constabulary is threatened. Discontent among the men is wide-spread. From 5,000 to 10,000 of them threaten to resign. The men demand increased pay and quicker promotion.

The meeting of the Democratic State Committee at Saratoga, on Tuesday next, will probably attract the largest attendance of politicians ever before seen at a like event in this State, and it is said that this extraordinary rush of representatives of the "grand old Democratic Party" at this time plainly shows their desire to bring about peace and harmony among themselves.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 4.--This was the tenth extra and the twenty-first racing day. The attendance was fair, the weather bright and warm, the track fast, and betting spirited.

A runaway steer caused some excitement yesterday afternoon in the Twenty-eighth Precinct, and a man, in escaping from it, injured his leg. The animal was first seen at Forty-fifth-street and First-avenue, and it is supposed that it escaped from a slaughter-house in the neighborhood. It had a following of small boys, dogs, and reckless but poor marksmen--some of them policemen--at the start.

LONDON, Aug. 4.--The Manchester Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "There is very little alteration. The harvest prospects are watched with anxiety. Prices generally are fairly steady, without signs of improvement."

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4.--This evening Franklin P. Hawkins and Lewis Minks attempted to drive across the railroad track at Bayview Junction, a short distance east of this city, when their wagon was struck by the engine of the 7 o'clock train for the east. The wagon was demolished and both occupants seriously, if not fatally, hurt. They were removed to their homes in this city.

SARATOGA, Aug. 3.--It is surprising how many ladies here have livers. The lungs are usually the prevalent organs in the country, while in the city popular female prejudice runs in favor of tonsils, heart, head, and peptics.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4.--Mr. Gowen's long and unusual silence with regard to the mission which took him to Europe several months ago has been regarded from the first as ominous by those who are best acquainted with his usually frank, not to say effusive, disposition to tell all he knows, and perhaps a little that he is rather hopeful of than assured of.

About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the large stables in the rear of the Keystone Hotel, on North Queen-street, Lancaster, Penn., owned by Uriah Bitzer, were set on fire by an incendiary and completely destroyed, with a large quantity of hay and feed, the live stock being saved. Loss, $10,000; insurance, $6,000. An adjoining building, owned by Bitzer and occupied by Israel L. Landis, patent rights dealer, was also destroyed.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 8.--The most destructive rain that ever fell in the southern part of the county poured down in torrents last night in sections of Strasburg, Drumore, Martic, Providence, Eden, and elsewhere. The rain continued four hours, and such a flood was created as has not been known in 25 years in that section.

The season for peaches has been somewhat backward this year, and the fruit so far sent to the market, with the exception of some fancy specimens from North Carolina, has been poor.

The necessity for a rain-fall is nowhere more apparent than in the Central Park. There the leaves of the trees and the foliage are brown and withered by the sun, and the grass has in many places disappeared. The grounds are dry and dusty.

NEWPORT, Aug. 15.--Newport's dry term continues. The cry of the Grangers for rain to save their crops is fervently echoed by our Summer residents, who want the universal dust to depart and the freshness of garden and lawn to return.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 15.--The Hon. G.W. Hewitt has been renominated as the Democratic candidate for Congressman from the Sixth District of Alabama.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--The Rev. George C. Betts, an Episcopal clergyman of St. Louis, who was President of the Irish National Convention of last year in Chicago, arrived in this city this morning, to deliver the principal oration at the Irish picnic this afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15.--The Western distillers will doubtless succeed to-morrow in organizing, at Chicago, the Western Export Association, that expired by limitation on the 1st of last May. Since that date there have been several attempts made to revivify the organization.

The Cleveland League nine and the Metropolitan Club played their sixth game on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of 1,500 spectators, and it resulted in the second victory for the home team.
Our Paris correspondent, in a telegram which we published yesterday, announced the serious illness of the Comto de Chambord.

The Fourth Ward Republican primary election, which was held yesterday at Jefferson Hall Brooklyn, for the purpose of electing a delegate to the Republican General Committee and a full set of ward association officers, caused much excitement among the local politicians.

His father sat beside him during the session. A heavy shower of rain, lasting two hours, yesterday morning placed the range at Creedmoor in a magnificant condition. The foliage of the trees assumed a brighter shade of green, and the broad expanse of lawn pleased the eye while it suggested "rheumatics" to the older riflemen.

PENZANCE, Aug. 16.--It is thought the Mosel is considerably strained. Last evening the vessel was moving slightly with the roll of the sea.

NEWPORT, Aug. 16.--The leading society event of the season thus far occurred this afternoon in the fete champetre at the villa and grounds of Mr. Thomas G. Appleton, of Boston, in Catherine-street. The rain clouds of the morning gave place to sunshine in the afternoon, and at 5 o'clock, the hour of opening the fete, the spacious villa and the freshly bathed turf awaited the throng of guests that soon filled all available space.

The entire Board of Park Commissioners met yesterday for the first time since June 21. News of the fact seemed to have got abroad quickly, as a large number of local politicians and others, with large and small axes to grind, assembled to witness the proceedings. The meeting opened at 9:45 A.M., and was not over until nearly 3 o'clock.

He not only made a speech in which he denounced the whisky dealers' rebellion in strong terms, but also said that President Arthur was in a difficult position and ought to be sustained by Republicans everywhere. WASHINGTON, Aug. 16.--Supervising Inspector-General J.A. Dumont, who is preparing regulations to carry out the act recently passed to bring foreign steam vessels under the United States inspection laws, left this afternoon for Philadelphia in search of information to guide him in making the new rules.

There exists a vague impression that extreme heat, such as that from which we have suffered during the last six weeks, has a tendency to promote crime. Undoubtedly excessive heat does weaken the moral character of a man, but if there is any truth in statistics it does not predispose him to commit crime.

SARATOGA, Aug. 16.--To-day was the fiftenth extra and thirty-first racing day. The attendance was very good, the weather cloudy and warm, the track slow, and the betting spirited. The officers of the day were: Judges--Capt. Franklin, Col. J.S. Doswell, Col. G.S. Owens; timers-- P.J. Dwyer and J.H. Smith; starter--Major John Wynn; Secretary--C. Wheatley.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 16.--This morning about 2 o'clock Charles Poundey and Stephen H. Blainey engaged in an altercation on Pleasantstreet, which ended in Blainey drawing a revolver and firing at Poundey, the ball taking effect in the back of his head, inflicting a dangerous wound. Blainey has not yet been arrested.
In the Court of General Sessions yesterday a thief named John Meehan was sent to State prison for four years for stealing a watch.

Warden Green, of the Kings County Penitentiary, submitted yesterday, at a meeting of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, his report for the fiscal year ending July 31. The report shows the earnings of the penitentiary during the year to have been $73,688.90, and the expenditures $62,957 leaving a net profit of $10,731.90.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 16.--The Western Iron Association met in this city to-day, and from the action taken it is certain the backbone of the manufacturers is as stiff now as it was at the beginning of the strike. St. Louis and Cincinnati were not represented, while Wheeling, the Shenango and Mahoning Valleys, and Pittsburg, were on hand in full force.
Easton, Penn., has a Dowling in a Judge named Schuyler, who has sent a man to State prison for six years for stealing a silver watch and a pair of gloves, three years for each article.

A pitiable case of destitution was brought to light in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. A woman and her four children, the eldest 7 years old, the youngest 3, were brought into court by an officer who found them in a group by a pool of water at Franklin and Centre streets. The woman was washing the faces of the children when the officer arrested her. Her name is Kate Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 16.--Contrary to the expectation formed yesterday, Mr. Carpenter, of counsel for S.W. Dorsey and John W. Dorsey in the star route trial, consumed only half the day in concluding his summing up speech, giving Mr. Jeff Chandler the afternoon in which to begin his remarks for Brady.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16.--In one of the New-York papers there appeared this morning a special dispatch from Baltimore describing an error discovered in a bill passed during the last hours of Congress by which soldiers of the war of the rebellion who were under the charge of technical desertion were to be relieved of the charge.

The Mississippi River Commission, which has charge of the expenditure of the money appropriated during the late session of Congress for the improvement of that river, has been in session since last Monday.

In the matter of the judicial settlement of the accounts of Philip R. Underhill, Executor, , of Elizabeth R. Underhill, deceased, Surrogate Owen T. Coffin, of Westchester County, yesterday rendered his decision. This case has been before the Surrogate for about two years, and the amount involved was about $1,000,000. The deceased testatrix was a daughter of Deborah Rhinelander and wife of Isaac Underhill, of New-Rochelle.
Collector William H. Robertson said yesterday that the law regarding the regulation of immigrants approved Aug. 3 will at once be carried into effect.

Robertson, sitting member. Robertson held all the time a large plurality of the votes, but the two-thirds rule was sprung upon him and he was checked off.

There is said to be a large percentage of very young soldiers in the British forces recently sent to Egypt. Some 9,000 men are known to average little more than two or three and twenty years of age. These are under service of only three years. Fears are expressed that they may not be able to bear the severity of a semi-tropical climate at this season of the year.

ALEXANDRIA, Aug. 16.--Gen. Wolseley held a conference to-day with Admiral Seymour and all the Generals. He subsequently visited the Khedive. Major-Gen. Alison will retain local command of the British troops pending the present deliberations of the Conference.

DOVER, N.H., Aug. 16.--Frederick McCrillis and George Badger, young men living in East Rochester, went out gunning this morning, when it was very foggy. They separated. Soon after Badger fired at something and the contents of his gun entered the side of the neck and shoulders of McCrillis. One ear was completely shattered. McCrillis was carried home, and the surgeon reports that he is in a dangerous condition.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug, 16.--The young Finlander, ENgluender, whose death of yellow fever occurred last night, was undoubtedly a victim of medical curiosity. When brought into the hospital his case was pronounced a light one, and he only needed rest and quiet, but the wards are open to the medical profession and students, and the first day he was subjected to over 40 visits and examinations.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 16.--About 2 o'clock this morning Senator Hill was found to be rapidly sinking. He breathed with much difficulty. He continued to sleep, however, and at a few minutes after 6 o'clock his death occurred without a struggle. He died from exhaustion.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa. Aug. 16.--The Democratic State Convention assembled at 11 o'clock this morning. A temporary organization was effected, Judge W.C. James being elected Chairman.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16.--At a special meeting of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad to-day, the question of increasing the capital stock to the amount of $1,600,000 was voted upon and decided affirmatively. The "nickel-plated" people voted 9,000 shares and the Jewett or Erie interest 20,000 shares.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17.--This was the seventeenth regular and the thirty-second racing day. The weather was delightful and the attendance very large and brilliant. The track, after last night's rain, was dry on top but damp underneath.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 17.--Mr. N.W. Andrews, the brother-in-law of Cyrus W. Field. Jr., one of the typhoid fever-stricken guests at the Hotel Bellevue, had an unfavorable change to-day, which the physicians and Mr. Field think was cause by yesterday's severe storm and to-day's sultry dampness.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 17.--The first witness before the Tariff Commission this morning was William Kent, Assistant Appraiser in the NewYork Custom-house, in the silk department. SARATOGA, Aug. 17.--In the Bankers' Association this morning Mr. Hervey, of Mobile, gave a brief account of the crop prospects in the Southern States, which, he said, were good. The planters of Alabama, he said, are getting rid of the incubus of debt. The mineral wealth of the State is great, and only needs capital to develop it.

With the exception of Hawaii, no island of the Hawaiian group possesses the traces of as many awe-inspiring phenomena and scenes of bewildering beauty as Maui. The island is divided into two unequal parts, each having a volcanic heaven-invading mountain pile, whose lava rivers met in remote ages, uniting the two by a narrow isthmus.

The three opening days of August, 1798, witnessed Nelson's splendid victory over the French fleet in Aboukir Bay--the most glorious naval victory since the defeat of the Armada. The opening days of the present month find an English fleet once more in Aboukir Bay with hostile intent. But the coincidences of the situation are not more remarkable than its contrasts.

The eighth annual festival of the Plattdutsche Volksfest Verein--the first ever held on Manhattan Island--closed yesterday. It is estimated that from 10,000 to 12,000 people visited Sulzer's Harlem Park, where the sports took place during the day.

The conclusion of a treaty between the United States and Corea adds another to the peaceful successes of American diplomacy in the far East. Nearly 30 years ago the American Commodore Perry, overcoming obstacles which had baffled almost every European nation, and without firing a shot or leaving ill-feeling behind, succeeded in opening Japan to foreign intercourse.

SARATOGA, Aug. 18.--This was the sixteenth extra and thirty-third racing day. The attendance was good, the weather cool and cloudy, and the track in fair shape. The betting was lively. The officers of the day were: Judges--Col. R.W. Simmons, Capt. Franklin, J.N. Galway, and W.S. Montague; timers--P.J. Dwyer and J.H. Smith; starter--Major John Wynne; Secretary--Charles Wheatley.

The Garfield Club of the Thirteenth Assembly District met last evening at Twenty-third-street and Eighth-avenue. Col. John W. Marshall in the chair. BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 18.--There were 38 new cases and one death from yellow fever here to-day. The fever is increasing among the Americans. The disease seems to be on the increase in Matamoros, though the death-rate is more favorable. There were only three deaths there to-day.

LONDON, Aug. 29.--Gen. Wolseley telegraphs from Ismailia, at 1:40 o'clock this morning, as follows: "I have just received news from the front that Gen. Graham was heavily attacked last evening by a large force of Egyptians. The British cavalry from Mahsameh went to his assistance, and he has had a brilliant success, taking 11 guns. Only a few British were killed, but over 100 were wounded. I am just about to proceed to the front."

The late Jesse Hoyt, the well-known merchant, by his will, filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday, disposed of an estate variously estimated at from $10,000,000 to $15,000,000 in the most munificent manner. He first gives to James W. Jackson, his confidential clerk, $50,000. He next sets apart $1,250,000 from his estate to be held in trust by his Executors for the use and benefit of his widow, Helen Maria Hovt, during her life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--A Tribune special from Springfield gives footings by the State Department of Agriculture of the Illinois Winter wheat crop of 1882, from which it appears that the yield is, with one exception, that of 1880, the largest ever harvested in the State, and amounts to 50,951,529 bushels. The Spring wheat crop will make the aggregate yield a little more than 52,000,000 bushels.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--The condition of the Archbishop of Canterbury continues grave. Mr. Henry Irving, the actor; Mr. George Augustus Sola, the author, and Mr. Moncure D. Conway have added their names to the list of persons in favor of placing a bust of Longfellow in Westminster Abbey.

George A. McDermott, the Mayor's Marshal, completed yesterday an investigation of charges of unlawful practices made against Levy Harris, a pawnbroker, of No. 25 Catharine-street. BROWNSVILLE, Aug. 31.--Sixty new cases of yellow fever were reported to-day, and two deaths, the latter Mexicans. Dr. Melow is down with the disease. Many cases of fever exist on the ranches along the route to Corpus Christi. Three deaths are reported from Matamoras and a few new cases. The weather is very warm.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--The season is dead; the last man has left both city and suburb; from a social, literary, and artistic point of view London is a howling wilderness. Not that the streets are empty; on the contrary, a crowd from the provinces has taken possession of them, and one notices among the holiday throng many Americans homeward bound from Continental tours.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The Saratoga Clubhouse, otherwise John Morrissey's great gilded gambling palace, is an institution of the place that every man goes to on the night of his arrival. Pious citizens and fathers of large families count their visits as in the line of legitimate sight-seeing, and chill the blood of their home broods as they tell in horrified tones of the crowds that openly gamble there every night.

From New-Zealand has been shipped to England a quantity of preserved rabbits, estimated to weigh some 50 tons. The rabbits are packed in tins holding two pounds each, and 36 tins make a case--that is, 72 pounds. The supply of rabbits appears to be almost inexhaustible. The average quantity delivered per day is 5,000. On one occasion recently 9,000 were delivered in a day.

LAREDO, Texas, Aug. 31.--Track laying on the Mexican National Railway was completed to Monterey this evening. Monterey has a population of 40,000, and is one of the business centres of Mexico. An excursion on the road is promised for the 16th prox.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31.--The national lawntennis tournament was continued at the Casino to-day with a large attendance. The weather was again perfect and the grounds in excellent condition. The interest of the spectators was greatly increased as the contest in the singles was narrowed down by the two rounds played to-day.

Every father and mother, every person, parent or not, whose breast is warmed by a single spark of human feeling, will rejoice that little LIZZIE SELDEN has been found and restored to her home. There is further cause for gratification in the arrest of her abductor.

The Philadelphia nine defeated the Metropolitan Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, after a good batting game, by a score of 15 to 8. The work performed with the bat was the finest witnessed on the Polo Grounds this season, and elicited frequent applause from the spectators.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31.--The Colgate-Prince wedding at All Saints' Chapel, at 1 o'clock this afternoon, was one of the brilliant events of the season. The little chapel was filled to overflowing with invited guests, including many friends from other cities, as well as Newport cottagers.

PORT SAID, Aug. 31.--Arabi Pasha has asked for an eight days' armistice. Gen. Wolseley refused, but offered an armistice for one day. Nothing, however, will be done for several days, unless Arabi again forces an issue. A reconnoissance in the direction of Fort Ghemileh will be made to-day.

He tendered a fifty-dollar bill in payment and requested that the balance be paid him by check, payable to H.T. Norton or bearer.

MONTEREY,Mexico, Sept. 1.--The first passenger train on the Mexican National Railroad entered this city last-evening. The road is now completed from Corpus Christi, Texas, to this point, a distance of 330 miles. The opening of this line makes Monterey the great gateway to Mexico from the United States.

Upon the tablet are engraved simply these words: "Francois Rabelais est mort dans cette maison on 1558."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2, 1882. The first of the new 3 per cent. bonds will probably be issued on Monday. Bonds of all the denominations except the fifty-dollar bond are now ready.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 2.--D.N. Sherwood, postal clerk on the route from Greensboro to Goldsboro, was detected this morning, in Goldsboro, robbing the money-drawer of the Post Office. He was arrested and gave bail, and left on the train for Greensboro.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--The United States Steamer Passaic was yesterday put in commission at the Washington Navy-yard, and the Wyandotte has taken her place as receiving ship at that yard. As soon as the Passaic is ready for sea duty she will go to Norfolk.

The Dowager Countess of Rosebery, who is dead in London, was in the eighty-sixth year of her age. She was married to the fourth Earl of Rosebery, the grandfather of the present Earl, in 1819, and was his second wife. By her he had two daughters, both of whom are now dead. The Earl himself died in l868.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 3.--The fever continues to increase in this city. For the 24 hours ending at 10 o'clock this morning there were 70 new cases and 4 deaths reported. Since then Mr. F. Henry Bollack, a prominent merchant, died. The fever at Matamoros is at about the same stage. Seven deaths have occured in the last 24 hours. The weather is cold and damp, with some rain at intervals.

Wisconsin has a "shoestring" Congressional district almost as remarkable as the one in Mississippi. It begins just north of the city limits of Milwaukee and extends to Green Bay. The Mississippi district is composed mostly of negroes and Republicans, while that in Wisconsin is inhabited largely by foreigners and Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4, 1882. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $1,056,949.91, and from Customs $1,072,072.19. The receipts of national bank notes for redemption to-day amounted to $197,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4--Dr. M.M. Hedges, of Newburg, N.Y., who, with Mr. Scott, won $450,000 from Francis P. Weed at draw poker and faro, arrived here yesterday on a visit to Scott, who is still at the Briggs House, ill with consumption.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--This has been the most sensational day so far in the investigation of the peculations of Major Ellis P. Phipps, the exSuperintendent of the Alms-house. Phipps was arrested last Thursday night on a charge of embezzling city money, the specific sum named being $5,000, although it was well understood that this was merely a formal amount, and that more crookedness would be put in evidence at the trial.
HONOLULU, Aug. 22.--Mr. Daggett, the new American Minister, has been received by the King. He has been feted by society, and is likely to become popular on the island.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--Lemuel Mountain went home drunk last night, boat his wife, and drove her and their three children from the house. After admitting them subsequently and when they had retired to bed he saturated a coat with coaloil and set fire to it. His wife carried the burning mass out into the street before serious damage was done to the building. Mountain was arrested and held for arson this morning.

Mlle Rh a made her first appearance this soason at the Park Theatre, in Brooklyn, last evening. The audience was large, the welcome gental, and the applause liberal. The play was "Adrienne Lecouvreur," and Mlle Rh a filled the titular role. DUBLIN, Sept. 4.--Eighty persons, injured in street rows here since the trouble occurred among the Police force, are being treated in the various hospitals. Nearly a score of the patients have bayonet wounds. A woman has died of injuries received in the charge made by the military on Saturday. One of the soldiers has been arrested.

The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby, after his sermon at Manhattan Beach on Sunday, was asked by a TIMES reporter to give his views upon the modern New-York observance of Sunday in visiting the neighboring watering-places.

Edison's central station, at No. 257 Pearl street, was yesterday one of the busiest places down town, and Mr. Edison was by far the busiest man in the station. The giant dynamos were started up at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and, according to Mr. Edison, they will go on forever unless stopped by an earthquake.

NEWPORT, Sept. 4.--The meets of the Queens County hunt on the island of Aquidneck, for the season of 1882, had a lively ending this afternoon. The meet was at Southwick Grove, and there was a very large assembly of spectators. The rain of the morning had laid the dust, and the roads and fields were in excellent condtion.

The first of the regular weekly meetings of the Baptist Pastors for the Fall season was held yesterday morning at the Baptist Publication House, in Murray-street, with the Rev. Dr. G.W. Samson as Moderator. The meeting was occupied chiefly by the relation of vacation experiences.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 4.--The Light-house Point mystery was solved this morning by Frederick W. Reimann, of No. 382 East Fourth-street, New-York, who positively identified the clothing of the young man found dead in the water at the mouth of New-Haven Harbor last Thursday as that of George Cornell, his 15-year-old companion on the unfortunate cat-boat trip from Ho boken to Windsor Looks. The Guinevere, one of the swiftest boats of the Columbia Yacht Club, was stolen from the club moorings at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, North River, during the night of Aug. 8. The owner of the yacht, a gentleman residing in West Eighty-second-street, at once began a search for her.

The little village of Kensico, Westchester county, was greatly excited yesterday over the discovery of one of the most brutal murders over committed in that region, the victim being Albert Montfort, one of the oldest and best known residents of the place.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 5.-- The returns from the State election are coming in slowly. Up to 10 o'clock P.M. less than 60 towns have been heard from, and thus far there is a sensible falling off from the vote of 1880.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 5.--The labor troubles at Youngstown are approaching a crisis. Brown, Bonnell Co. invited a conference with their finishing men today.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 5.--The Hon. Russell Errett, of the Twenty-second, and the Hon. Thomas M. Bayne, of the Twenty-third Congressional District, were renominated by the Republican Convention to-day.

Another large crowd gathered on the grounds of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday to witness an interesting serios of races, which were so well contested as to arouse a vast amount of enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The probable foundation of the story about the collision at Charlevoix, Mich., is the fact that the steam barge Araxes sunk in Waiska Bay on Thursday last during a heavy gale. The crew were saved and the hull may be recovered.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 5.--Seventyseven new cases of yellow fever were reported today and four deaths. Relief has been furnished to 344 families. The patients in the hospital number eight males and two females.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--The Western Cricketers continued their second innings in the match against the Young America Club at noon to-day. Tha weather was fine, but the attendance very poor.
JAMESTOWN, Dakota, Sept. 5.--Lynch, alias McCarthy, who seven years ago murdered Angus McNeal, of Plymouth, Ind., has been delivered over to the Sheriff.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 5.--The Republican State Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning. The platform adopted refers to the history of the party and indorses President Arthur.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Gen. Crook has assumed command of the Department of Arizona, relieving Col. Wilcox, who will at once proceed East with his command, the Twellth Infantry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Fully one-half of the persons who this morning filied the Criminal Court room were ladies, among them being Mrs. Dorsey, who, with a party of friends, sat directly in the rear of the defense table.
BINGHAMTON, Sept. 4.--A variety of local interests tends to make the political situation in Brooms Counts a complicated one. The Administration has a handful of supporters in Binghamton.

Inspector Byrnes yesterday furnished some further particulars in regard to the arrest on Saturday of Burritt G. Seymour, the broker, who was taken to Boston to answer a charge of negotiating stolen bonds. He is now in jail in that city in default of $30,000 bail.

The British and American rifle teams practiced on the ranges at Creedmoor yesterday. The American team shot only in the second stage, at 800, 900, and 1,000 yards, while the British team began at 200 yards and shot at all the distances which will be covered in the international match.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 9.--A most destructive rain and hail storm passed over the south eastern portion of this county last night. YOKOHAMA, Aug. 22.--Mr. George E. Rice, hitherto Vice-Consul-General of the United States at Yokohama, has beeen nominated Deputy Consul-General. The change is owing to difficulties caused by the previous system, under which Mr. Rice could act and receive pay only in the absence of the Consul-General. As Deputy he may act even while his superior is in Yokohama.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 12.--The Kentucky association continued its Fall meeting to-day. The weather was perfect and the attendance very fair. The track was fast and very dusty. The betting was moderately active.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept. 12.--The steam er Saragossa, from Baltimore, for Norfolk, arrived here this morning. She reports having been in collision last night in Chesapeake Bay, off Wol Trap, with an unknown schooner.

About 8 o'clock yesterday morning two boatmen, Daniel and James Ruth, found the body of John Rapelye Morris, Treasurer of Long Island City, floating in the East River, off Sanford's Point, Astoria, near what are known as the Black Rocks.

Following the example of a bicycle rider, a rider of the tricycle has just made the journey in Great Britain from John o' Groat's, Scotland, to Land's End, in Cornwall. His time was 13 days, 23 hours, and 55 minutes, the distance being 995 miles. His machine weighed 95 pounds, and he carried an additional weight in baggage of 10 pounds.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Sept. 13.--The Halifax steamer Lizzie, which has just arrived from Labrador, brings discouraging reports of the fishery on that coast. The catch is the smallest for many years.

Capt. Harding, of the brig Annie R. Storer, which arrived from Cape Haytien on Tuesday evening, reports the narrow escape of his vessel, which ran into and sank the fishing schooner James Fitch, Jr., on Monday morning, and while in a crippled condition was caught in the heavy storm of that day, which came near driving her on the New-Jersey coast.

Rhodes, and W.H. Gallup. The delegates are uninstructed, but favor Cornell or Wadsworth. A Folger resolution was tabled.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--Warrants were issued to-day for the arrest of Frank Johnson and Edward Donergan, the United States Supervisors of the First Division of the Fourth Ward, charging them with illegally registering votes. It is claimed that the false registration is part of a scheme for wholesale fraud at the approaching election. Johnson was arrested this afternoon and held in $1,500 bail for a further hearing. Donergan has left the city.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13.--The Catholic Church, as an organized society, prominently appears as an important factor in the political fight of the Twentyfirst Congressional District.

BANGOR, Sept. 13.--The usual allowance for adverse returns from the remote places seems unnecessary with the Republicans this year. Over 90 per cent. of the total vote is now reported, and the Republican plurality is nearly 10,000.

McQuiddy, recently nominated by the Greenback convention for Governor, was to-day arrested by a United States Marshal on a charge of having conspired to obstruct United States Marshal Poole in the performance of his duties during the Mussel Slough troubles of two years ago. LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 13.--Official returns from 61 counties show the vote on Governor to be: Barry, (Dem.,) 75,940; Slack, (Rep.,) 39,947; Garland, (Grbk.,) 8,271. Berry's majority over Slack about 35,000, over both nearly 28,000.

WATERTOWN, Sept. 13.--The Hon. Henry Spicer, Hamilton Smith, E.J. Leeber, and John Allis were elected delegates to the Republican State Convention from the Second District of Jefferson County to-day. After a hard fight they were instructed for Wadsworth. Gov. Cornell will probably be the second choice of three of them. E.B. Bulkley, of Antwerp, was nominated for Assembly on the second ballot. The Congressional delegation is for Charles R. Skinner.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 13.--President Arthur arrived on a Pullman train from the East at 4:15 this morning, and immediately repaired to the Rockingham House and retired. RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 13.--Baldwin Jenkins, wholesale shoe-dealers, suspended to-day. Their failure is attributed to outside speculations on the part of the junior member of the firm.

KASSASIN, Sept. 13.--Tel-el-Kebir was carried by the British this morning with a rush. The first shot was fired about 4:45 A. M., and in 20 minutes the position was taken. Arabi Pasha's army was scattered, and, with its leader, fled toward Zagazig, followed by the British troops, leaving 2,000 dead on the field and about 3,000 prisoners in the hands of the British.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 13.--The river is flooding the north-western part of the city, and many families have been forced to leave their houses. There were 31 new cases of yellow fever and three deaths reported to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The Criminal Court met this morning, Judge Wylie presiding, for the purpose of hearing arguments on the motions entered upon Monday last for arrest of judgment in regard to Miner and Rerdell, and to increase the bonds of the defendants as to whom the jury failed to agree.

SARATOGA, Sept. 13.--A strange gathering was the which met here to-day and, in the name of the Anti-monopoly Party, adopted a platform of principles, formed an organization, and gave voice to sentiments opposed to the absorbing and grasping tendencies of corporate powers.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 13.--The no-masted steam-sbip Meteor was successfully launched tonight just before 11 o'clock in the presence of a large number of spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 13.--Lieut. John W. Danenhower, of the Jeannette crew, has just returned to this city from Capon Springs, West Va. Owing to the continued bad condition of his eyes, he will probably be unable to attend the New-York City to-morrow evening.

OWEGO, Sept. 13.--The delegates to the Republican State Convention from Tioga County are as follows: T.C. Platt, R.A. Elmer, Frank M. Baker, and N.J. Thompson. This delegation is under the control of Mr. T. C. Platt.
BATON ROUGE, Sept. 13.--Merchants are jubilant over the prospects for the cotton crop. The weather is favorable for picking and the quality or the cotton is improving.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--The markets were a good deal steadier to-day, with very much less doing. The storm was about over, although the feeling was still unsettled enough to make the prices waver more than they do in a time of steady trading. The corn market was stronger, although the receipts were comparatively large.
Major-Gen. Winfield S. Hancock was in Jersey City yesterday afternoon as the guest of Van Houten Post of the Grand Army of the Republic.

LONDON, Sept. 13.--The race for the St. Leger Stakes, for 3-year olds, at the Doncaster meeting to-day, was won by Lord Falmouth's brown filly Dutch Oven. Mr. T. Cannon's brown filly Geheimniss, the favorite, came in second, and the Duke of Westminster's chestnut filly Shotover third.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 13.--For several days past Gov. Colquitt has been thinking of appointing Mr. B.H. Hill, Jr., to fill the unexpired term of his father, the late Hon. Ben H. Hill, in the Senate. The political situation in the great State of New-York, which for 10 years has been of paramount interest to the Democrats, is shifting its importance round to the Republicans. CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--There was to-day a renewal of the weakness of Tuesday in leading markets. BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 14.--The Rio Grande is still rising. This city is completely isolated, being without mail communication. Thirty-two new cases of yellow fever have been reported in the last 24 hours, but there were no deaths from the disease. All the sick in the city are doing well.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 28.--The Greenbackers, who are now making a canvass of this State in behalf of their State ticket, which was recently nominated, held a mass-meeting at Lancaster Court-house yesterday, which resulted in a bloody riot and in the loss of a number of lives.

It is impossible to reach any other conclusion but that fraud entered into the nomination made for Governor by the Republican Party at Saratoga.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The leading produce markets were active to-day, and gain was very irregular, white provisions were relatively steady. All were stronger after an early phase of weakness, which was greatest in corn. On the 11th inst. an old man claiming to hail from Pittsburg was committed to an insane asylum in New-York. He gave the name of Charles Bartberger, and labored under the hallucination that two men were pursuing him for the purpose of obtaining possession of a jewelry store he claimed to own in this city. He land attempted suicide during one of his frenzied spells.

There will be no opportunity this year to make changes in the composition of the State Senate, but a new Assembly is to be elected. Nominations have already begun in a few of the country districts. After the disgraceful record of the last session the people ought to appreciate the importance of selecting honest men as candidates for the Assembly.

Men are universally agreed that war is a terrible thing, and that if it cannot be entirely abolished, its horrors ought to be mitigated. Admirable as this sentiment is, it has as yet borne no fruit. Nations will go to war, and they will fight with the latest and most murderous weapons.

St. Cecile Lodge, No, 568, F. and A.M., meets on next Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 3, when the third degree will be conferred. The Association of the Alumni of Columbia College will hold its annual meeting at Delmonico's on Monday evening.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 28.--A convention of temperance organizations of this State, in the interest of a constitutional prohibitory movement, was held here today. There was a large attendance of delegates. Dr. Dorchester made an ad dress outlining the work before the convention and alluding to the progress of the prohibitory movement.

Senators John W. Browning and A.M. Holmes, of the Senate Committee on Villages, continued the investigation yesterday of the leases made by the Commissioners of the town of Gravesend of the common lands on Coney Island. The investigation was held in room No. 32 of the Gilsey House, and the witnesses were questioned by exAssemblyman A.D. Williams, the counsel of the committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The conductors and drivers employed by the North Division Street Railway Company struck this morning at 10 o'clock, and all the cars in that part of the city stopped running. The trouble was not one of wages, but of hours. A short time ago the company employed a new Superintendent, who, as the men claim, increased their hours of labor unreasonably.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Joseph K. McCammon, Assistant Attorney-General for the Interior Department, recently visited the Flat Head Indian Reservation in North-western Montana, and negotiated an agreement with that tribe to allow the Northern Pacific Railroad Company to build its road through the reservation, a distance of 58 miles.

CAIRO, Sept. 28.--An ammunition train has exploded near the Cairo railway depot. The explosions still continue at intervals of less than half a minute. Arabs and Europeans are fleeing from the scene. Thirty persons are reported to have been killed. The railway depot is now in flames. The train caught fire, it is believed, by spontaneous combustion, owing to the exceptional heat.
The Treasury Department to-day purchased 415,000 ounces of fine silver for delivery at the Philadelphia, New-Orleans, and San Francisco Mints.

The fourth annual regatta of the Union Boat Club was rowed yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River. LONDON, Sept. 28.--A Vienna newspaper publishes a story in effect that the Emperor and Empress of Russia were secretly crowned during their visit to Moscow. If the Emperor survives until the public coronation the secret ceremony will be considered void. In the event of his death it will be made public, so as to avoid any difficulty in proclaiming the Czarewitch Alexander as the lawful successor of the crowned monarch.

Some of the courts in the Pacific States of the Republic are kept busy with proceedings designed, apparently, to test the elasticity and expansibility of the act to regulate the immigration of Chinese laborers. The law, as THE TIMES has often had occasion to declare, is one which the people of the Pacific States have long demanded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Gen. Sherman, who is now acting as Secretary of War, denies the truth of the statement that plans are under consideration for the extensive reassignment of Army officers. "It has always been our policy," said the General, "to make such changes as may be necessary to equalize the amount of service rendered by the officers of the Army, and nothing more than this is now being done."

At the meeting of the Emigration Commissioners yesterday the subject of disposing of the Castle Garden franchises was again brought up. CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The Chicagos defeated the Buffalo Club by 11 to 5. This victory over the Buffalo Club gives the Chicagos the League championship for 1882. The Chicago club has won 54 games, with one more game to play.

NORWICH, N.Y., Sept. 27.--The celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the mustering into the service of the One Hundred and Fourteenth New-York Volunteers occurred here yesterday, and was a most interesting occasion. Tourtelotte, comprising the royal party now visiting this city, left the Palace Hotel last evening, in company with Chief Crowley and Capt. Lees for a visit to the Chinese quarter.

Hamilton and a greatgrandson of Alexander Hamilton, for the revocation of the probate of the will of his grandmother, Maria E. Hamilton, the wife of the late John C. Hamilton. Much public interest centred around the meeting of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, which was called for last evening in the Music Hall, at Flatbush and Fulton avenues, Brooklyn. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28.--The weather to-day was warm and the attendance at the races the largest of the meeting. The racing, with the exception of the pulling of Harry F. in the second race, was highly satisfactory. The track was fast and the betting was heavy. The officers of the day were: Judges--Gens. J.F. Robinson and Abe Buford; Distance Judge--B. Schell; Timers--E. Lawrence and R. Johnson; Starter--M.L. Clark, Jr.; Secretary--D.W. Johnson.

The ninety-ninth convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York was in session in St. Augustine's Chapel, in East Houston-street, yesterday. The venerable Bishop Potter presided. The early part of the day was occupied with reports, which showed in most respects a favorable state of affairs.
DOVER, N.H., Sept. 28.--The Democrats of the First Congressional District, in convention here, to-day nominated George B. Chandler, of Manchester.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--The gravity of the political situation in New-York is fully realized in this city, where the course of the Republican Party is closely watched by so many whose fortunes depend upon its continued success.

The Democrats have been making loud claims, but the Republicans are doing the hard work.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--The resignation of Col. George Stoneman, United States Army, (retired,) has been accepted by the President, to take effect Sept. 15, 1882.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Kings County Republican General Committee, held at Everett Hall, Fulton-street, Brooklyn, on Thursday night, the question of asking Mr. Folger and the other nominees of the Saratoga Convention to withdraw was considered and excited a good deal of acrimonious discussion.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 29.--It rained heavily here this morning, and the track in consequence was fetlock deep in mud. Toward noon the storm subsided and the weather this afternoon was clear and warm. The attendance was very fair; more ladies were present to-day than on any other day during the meeting. The betting was lively, particularly on the stallion race.

Prof. Ernest Haeckel, in his third "Journey Letter" to the Deutsche Lundschau, after describing his arrival in Ceylon and its capital, Colombo, goes on to give an account of his stay with Mr. Stipperger, the Austrian Lloyd's agent, in his beautiful villa of Whist Bungalow, and to pronounce a criticism on the English mode of life in Ceylon.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Sept. 29.--This place has been interested this week in an affair in the Somerset County Court, which is the outcome of a practical joke perpetrated by a genius whose ability is squandered upon the dull details of the undertaking business. The matter originated in an endeavor of the Bound Brook Law and Order League to enforce the State laws against illegal liquor-selling.

"If my counsel does not appear I shall plead my own case," said Miss Emmeline Laurent, when told in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon that her attorney could not attend to continue the proceedings against James H. Elliott, the lawyer whom she accused of entering her apartments and abstracting papers. Miss Laurent was waiting with a lady friend for the case to be called.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Further evidences of a big squeeze in September wheat similar to that which caused all the trouble in the July deal were abundant on 'Change to-day. Our receipts were quite large, aggregating 725 car-loads, besides some by canal. New-York was dull. But Liverpool and London were quoted better in tone, with more money asked, and this gave a little more confidence to outside parties.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Tott J. Dunkle, the last of the Kewanee bank robbers, was arrested in Battlemount, Dakota, yesterday. Dunkle is 25 years old, and lived in Des Moines, Iowa, where his father, for many years, was a merchant and occupied a high social position. Young Dunkle was highly esteemed and never before known to be engaged in any questionable business.

A brief morning session was held, but, no witnesses being present, a recess was taken till 2 o'clock, at which time the interests of the manufacturers of chemicals and fertilizers containing sulphuric or muriatic acids, were represented by R.W.S. Rasin, of Baltimore.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, Superintendent of the American Museum of Natural History, will begin a series of lectures on zoology before the teachers of the public schools on Saturday, Oct. 10. The lectures will be given on the successive Saturdays, at 10:30 A.M., and will be delivered in the lecture-room on the upper floor of the Museum building.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 29.--Gov. Cameron a few days ago appointed a new Board of Visitors for the Medical College of Virginia, to this city, thereby summarily displacing the old board. This action has created much excitement to medical circles, and is being severely criticised by the press and public.

The election of city and town officers in Connecticut will occur next Monday. The President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, in Washington, caused the arrest of two men on Thursday for carrying live chickens home from market by the legs.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29.--Newton W. Nutting, of Oswego, was unanimously nominated on the first ballot by the Republican Congressional Convention of the Twenty-fourth District, at Oneida, this afternoon.

The Metropolitan team went to Newark, N. J., yesterday, and played a match game there with the Domestic nine. The latter played a good fielding game, but could not withstand the heavy batting of the New-York men, who won by a score of 12 to 4.

Edward Hovey, who on April 26 last shot and killed his sister-in-law, Mrs. Fannig Vermilyea, in her apartments, at No. 273 West Thirty-eighthstreet, was convicted, in the General Sessions Court, on Monday, of murder in the first degree. When brought to court for sentence yesterday he was handcuffed to a forger named Charles Willis.

The Senate Committee on Insurance resumed yesterday the inquiry into the affairs of the National Trust Company, which passed into the hands of William J. Best, as Receiver, in December, 1877. At the opening of the session F.N. Bangs, who appears as counsel for Mr. Best, asked for a postponement of the investigation owing to the absence of his client, who, he stated, was too ill to appear.

A part of the Senate Insurance Committee of this State less been engaged for the last few days in investigating the National Trust Company Receivership, which serves to remind the public at least that this committee was charged so long ago as last March with the task of inquiring into Receivership abuses.

CAIRO, Sept. 29.--The explosions at the railway station yesterday continued at brief intervals for over three hours. By the energetic efforts of the military, although they were hampered by the lack of pumping-gear, the fire was prevented from spreading and finally brought under control.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--It is over the services that took place this forenoon that a cloud hangs, which, to many minds, betokens a storm for the Episcopalians of this city. Bishop McLaren was invited some time ago by Father Ritchie, the Rector of the Church of the Ascension, to be present this forenoon at the laying of the corner-stone of the new edifice, and signified his intention to be present.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 29.--The Picayune gives a version of the settlement of the affairs of the First National Bank of New-Orleans which varies somewhat from that first reported from Washington, showing that the settlement has been prevented and avoided for nearly a generation through the stubbornness and overzeal of Treasury officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--The Assistant District Attorney took additional depositions today relating to the star route bribery cases, and there is some hope that either the Attorney-General or some one connected with the prosecution in the recent trial will come to this city next week.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29.--The United States Grand Jury has found two new bills of indictment against Col. Charles H. Houghton, Collector of Customs for the Port of Perth Amboy, for transmitting false and forged vouchers to the Secretary of the Treasury with intent to defraud the Government of the United States in violation of section No. 5,418 of the Revised Statues.

Yesterday was the third day of the lawntennis tournament at Montrose, Mountain Station, N.J., and a number of very interesting matches were played. The weather was very fine, being all that the most enthusiastic tennis player could wish, but the turf was in even worse condition than on the two preceding days.

PORT JEFFERSON, Long Island, Sept. 29.--A recent almost fatal case of poisoning of an aged lady who lives in the little settlement known as Miller's Place, about six miles from this town, and the mysterious circumstances connected with it, have occasioned considerable discussion of a quiet nature among the residents there.
Hague's Minstrels will give their two last performances at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre today.

BOATON, Oct. 3.--The long struggle for the Republican nomination in the new Sixth Congressional District ended at about 6 o'clock this morning after a second session, continuing through the night and from 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon. Elisha H. Converse, Mayor of Malden, was nominated on the one hundred and thirtieth ballot.

The October exhibition of the New-York Horicultural Society was given yesterday afternoon in Republican Hall, No. 55 West Thirty-thirdstreet. Although the display was not very large, the specimens exhibited were very choice.

BUFFALO, Oct. 5.--The Erie County Republican Convention held here to-day was entirely in the hands of the managers of the Stalwart machine. The Independent Republicans made no effort to elect delegates and took but little interest in the proceedings.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--John, Ellen, and Mary Morris were before the Criminal Court this morning to receive sentence. Mary, the daughter, 14 years old, had pleaded guilty to 13 indictments for burglary and larceny.

KEWANEE, Ill., Oct. 5.--A detective arrived yesterday with the bank robber Dunkle, and this morning, after a walk of a couple of miles east of here, returned with a sack of gold containing $5,000. This accounts for all the money, and all the robbers are in custody.

A mass-meeting to ratify the Republican State ticket was held in Chickering Hall last evening by the Lincoln Club. The hall was between one-half and two-thirds full, among the audience being several ladies.

Stockdale, editor of the Wool Grower and Farmer, who was one of a committee appointed by the woolgrowers of Washington County to bring the wool question to the attention of the commission.

Registration of voters for the coming State and City and County election will begin to-day in all the election districts of this City at 8 A.M., and the books will be closed at 9 P.M. Register to-day.

CAIRO, Oct. 9.--Sultan Pasha, President of the Chamber of Notables, thinks that Turkish intervention in Egypt would mean anarchy, and maintains that the cost of the joint control is extravagant, and that 400,000 might be saved annually by the substitution of efficient native for foreign officers. He admits that the mass of the population is unfit for a representative Government.

The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher withdrew yesterday from the New-York and Brooklyn Association of Congregational Churches. The Autumn meeting of the association was held in the Park Congregational Church, in Seventh-street, near Sixth-avenue, Brooklyn, and Mr. Beecher was expected simply to open a discussion on the subject of "Spiritual Barbarism." His action was entirely unexpected, and excited general surprise among the members.

The golden wedding of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Ray Palmer was celebrated last evening at their home, No. 205 Mount Pleasant-avenue, Newark, N.J. The anniversary of their marriage was on Oct. 3, but owing to the absence of relatives and friends the celebration was postponed to last night.

The annual meeting of the Western Union Telegraph Company was held in the Western Union Building yesterday, and there was an unusually full representation of stockholders. The Hon. E. D. Morgan presided.

The announcement that Henry Ward Beecher would speak on the peculiar political situation in this State, and that he would also make some comments on his own now departure in separating himself from the Congregational Pastors, had the effect of crowding Plymouth Church yesterday morning.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 15.--William George, a merchant at Reed's Landing, 18 miles from this city, was murdered last night by unknown persons. The crime was committed for the purpose of robbery, but the design of the murderers was frustrated. George leaves a widow and several children. Surgeons and friends have gone to the scene of the crime from this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16, 1882. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $213,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $966,340.23, and from Customs $733,306.97.

Democratic primaries were held last evening in the 25 wards of Brooklyn and the five country towns of Kings County to elect delegates to the various local nomination conventions. PORT ROYAL, S.C., Oct. 16.--The schooner Addie Fuller, Hart, from Boston, which arrived yesterday, reports having encountered heavy gales on Oct. 13 and 14, off Frying-pan Shoals. The vessel sustained considerable damage to her bulwarks and sails, and lost $150 worth of stores.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The following general order was issued to-day from the Head-quarters of the Army: "The retirement from active service, by operation of law, of Major-Gen. Irvin McDowell, on Oct. 15, 1882, under the provisions of the act of Congress approved June 30, 1882, is announced to the Army. Gen. McDowell will proceed to his home in New-York City."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The examination of Lieut. Danenhower was resumed before the Jeannette board of inquiry at 12 o'clock to-day. This play, which was seen last night at the Fourteenth-Street theatre, was written by Mr. Elliott Barnes, a person who is unknown to us and, probably, to famo. It has been acted, apparently, in various parts of this unhappy country. Its fortunes are directed by Mr. C.R. Gardiner, who appears also to be the proprietor of it. Mr. Maurice Grau, always energetic in his profession, gave the first performance in this country of Offenbach's posthumous opera "Les Contes d'Hoffman" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last night, and a very excellent performance it was. The libretto amounts to little and is not specially creditable to M. Barbier, its author; but the music coming from the pen of Offenbach is remarkable in more than one particular.

ROME, Oct.18.--The funeral ceremony over the late George P. Marsh, united States Minister to Italy, in the Protestant Cemetery, was simple and almost private, the only official persons present being Mr. Richmond, the American Consul-General, and ex-Secretary of Legation Wurtz. A mass of flowers concealed the American flag, which covered the coffin.

The Forest and Stream anglers' tournament was concluded yesterday morning with a contest for the champions in single-handed fly casting, which was open to all, and in which the distance cact was alone to count. A stiff breeze blew across the lake, which materially assisted the casters, and the records made were wonderful, all but one of them excelling any record made in any previous tournament.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21.--Only about two weeks remain in which to prosecute the campaign in Connecticut. The Rev. GEORGE T. RIDER is prostrated by an attack of nausea, with headache, and much constitutional disturbance. He brought this trouble on himself by attempting to read critically an armful of newspapers. He tells the world all about his case in an article entitled "The Pretensions of Journalism," in the November number of the North American Review.

PARIS, Oct. 5.--I have recently been disappointed in the Germans; I knew they were methodical, that their movements were aso precise that nothing like celerity was to be expected of them--in short, that they are slow; but frankly I did not expect, while in Munich last week, that on the eleventh day after its opening, their electrical exhibition there would still be in a state of incompleteness.

A collection of woods without a parallel in the world is now being prepared for exhibition by the Directors of the American Museum of Natural History. YOKOHAMA, Oct. 8.--The King of Corea has issued a proclamation in which he accuses himself of employing incompetent Ministers and of neglecting the welfare of his kingdom and people. He promises full amendment in the future. There is much doubt as to the whereabouts of Tui-in-Kun the father of the Corean King and instigator of all the disturbances in Corea. He was inveigled on board a Chinese ship of war and transported to China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.--The opinion of Attorney-General Brewster upon the papers presented to the President last June, in support of an application for the appointment of a commission to consider the mental condition of the assassin Guiteau, and asking for a reprieve pending such investigation, was given to the press to-day.

CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 28.--The bi-centennial celebration at Chester to-day was a grand success. The morning dawned with a threatening sky, but notwithstanding this our citizens were engaged in decorating their premises, and soon nearly every building was res lendent with flags, bunting, and various appropriate decorations, giving the city a genuine holiday appearance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.--The President has mitigated the sentence of Second Lieut. James R. Chapman, Twenty-second Infantry, to loss of half pay for six months. Lieut. Chapman was convicted by court-martial of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman, and sentenced to dismissal from the service.

The electric light has been successfully employed in various parts of the Paris Opera-house, expensively and conspicuously in the foyer, where the elaborate decorations have undergone grave injury at the hands of gas. Ten chandeliers have been used for the gas, each chandelier containing 48 burners. It was found that two of these, when fitted with 48 Swan lamps each, gave out light atmost equal to the eight remaining gas-lit chandeliers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day than the recent average, and irregularly steadier. Provisions were stronger, while grain averaged lower under fair receipts and an upward tendency in freight rates by water, but strengthened late in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--The annual report of Edward Clark, architect of the Capitol, says that several additional rooms formerly occupied for storage, and even the ends of corridors, have been fitted up as committee rooms, and that the crypt is now being utilized for the storage of many books belonging to the library.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--The defense continued to-day to put in their testimony in the case of Augustus C. Soteldo, indicted for the murder of his brother, A. M. Soteldo. The principal witness was the defendant, who testified that his brother had supported, clothed, and fed him, and had procured him a situation and that they were very fond of each other.

A Citizens' meeting was held last night in Beethoven Hall. The main floor was crowded and the galleries were filled. The meeting was under the direction of the German Independent Organization of the Tenth Assembly District, but hundreds of interested citizens outside of that association, and many from outside of the Tenth District were in attendance. Great enthusiasm prevailed.

Our men were beaten because their rifles were inferior to the English rifles and because they were poorer marksmen. They had the advantage of familiarity with the range, which the Englishmen lacked, but this could not compensate for bad weapons or bad shooting.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2.--Attorney-General Brewster has telegraphed United States Marshal Kerns that in view of the discovery of extensive irregularities in registration of voters thorough investigation of the matter where fraud is suspected should be made, and directing him to cause the arrest not only of Supervisors and Assessors, but the election officers.

Another sale of Malmaison property has just been recorded in Paris. LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 2.--The encounter between State troops in charge of the Ashland murderers, Craft and Neal, and a mob attempting to secure the prisoners for the purpose of lynching them, has created great excitement.

LONDON, Nov. 2.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Trevelyan, Chief Secretary for Ireland, replying to Mr. O'Kelly, said that the issues of the New-York Irish Nation of Aug. 26, Sept. 9, Sept. 16, Sept. 30, Oct. 7, Oct. 14, and Oct. 21 had been stopped because they contained matter which the Post Office authorities could not permit to circulate.

The long contest has ended in the election of Joseph N. Dolph to the United States Senate. It is a result which will be accepted as a fortunate deliverance from a controversy of which the whole State had become weary, and which for several weeks had attracted national attention.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 2.--The publication in a New-York paper of an article signed E.D. Williams, charging that Gov. Foster and the Hon. George K. Nash had made a demand upon the Postmistress at Westerville for a contribution of $25 to the campaign fund created quite a sensation in Republican circles here.

YOKOHAMA, Oct. 17.--The Mikado is confined to his residence, suffering severely from the peculiar Japanese disease called "kakake." The cattle plague is alarmingly prevalent in the Southwestern provinces. There have been heavy floods in the central provinces, with great lose of life and property. Small villages were entirely swept away. Thousands of persons are reported to be drowned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3.--The leading produce markets were generally active to-day and very much unsettled, but averaged lower. There was an early flurry in corn, due to the fact that it is badly wanted in Europe, but the longs unloaded, and other grain was easier in sympathy, while provisions were beared by the packers as usual.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--From the annual report of Third Assistant Postmaster-General Hazen the following information is obtained: The ordinary receipts of the department during the fiscal year ended June 30 amounted to $41,515,642.80, and the net money-order receipts to $360,767.35, making a total revenue of $41,876,410.15.

BOSTON, Nov. 3.--The report that Vanderbilt has secured control of the Boston, Hoosac Tunnel and Western Road seems to be generally credited by railroad people here, though it is not confirmed. This is the road projected by the late Gen. Burt, and over which there has been so much litigation.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 18.--The State Fair closed to-day. The attendance has been good. The event of the week was a trotting race, free for all, for a purse of $1,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 18.--The Attorney-General has rendered an opinion that parsonages, even though they be on the same lot with churches, are liable to be taxed, if the parsonages are owned by the church Trustees or corporations. It is held that the section of law referring to the exemption of clergymen does not apply to parsonages owned by the church Trustees or corporations.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 18.--There was another lively session at the Oil Exchange this morning, and a large amount of trading was done. BOSTON, Nov. 18.--Thomas Loeman, 18 years of age, a cash-boy in Jordan, Marsh Co.'s establishment, and his sister and brother have, by the death of their uncle, Michael Loeman, a broker in Melbourne, Australia, fallen heir to his entire fortune, amounting to $2,000,000. The children, who have no parents, will leave for St. John, New-Brunswick, where they will be educated at the hands of their Trustees.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18.--The iron strike in the fifth district of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers still continues. This district embraces the works at Green Castle and Terre Haute, in this State. The demand is for $6 per ton for puddling iron, the Pittsburg scale calling for $5.50. The prices paid in this State are estimated at $5.53 a day for puddlers and from $8 to $10 for heaters.

CLEMENCEAU, the Radical Deputy for Montmartre, gave a very pithy illustration of the behavior of the present unmanageable French Chamber of Deputies, the other day, when he said that in the 124 days of the first session it devoured (that is, drove from office) 54 Ministers or Under Secretaries of State, an average of forty-hundredths of a Minister a day.

Another extensive robbery of Denver's registered mail matter for New-York and New-England points, sent by the banking-houses in this city on Oct. 31, has been reported to the Post Office authorities, and from present indications a valuable mail of the 7th inst, is also missing.
The formal resignation of the Rev. Dr. L. W. Bacon as Pastor of the Park Congregational Church was offered at a meeting of the church last night, and accepted by a vote of 32 to 13.

Not often nowadays does a collection of short stories tempt the reader on and on until he has come to the end of the book. Without possessing the highest form of originality, the tales by Mr. Stevenson are sufficiently off the beaten track, sufficiently eccentric, sufficiently unexpected, to give much enjoyment.

The iron business of this country has been running largely for the last few years to the production of steel rails. There has been a "boom" in railroad building, and the steel rail makers have had the benefit of a protective duty of $28 a ton on foreign rails.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 26.--Harry Troxell was arrested here to-day for having last night broken open the rear door of the house of his mother and ransacked the premises. No one was at home, Mrs. Troxell having gone to New-York yesterday to wait on a sick daughter. What was taken cannot be told until her return.

Willard Asylum for the Insane, at Ovid, has among its inamates a Danish lady of good education, and who, previous to the loss of her reason, occupied a respectable position in society. Her delusion is that she is immensely wealthy--the Queen of the universe. On all other subjects she is rational, and converses with ease and fluency.
The steam-ship Donau, from Bremen, landed 692 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday, and the De Ruyter, from Antwerp, 124.

It was stated yesterday that Jay Gould and William H. Vanderbilt were going to use their influence to arrange a conference at which the Northwestern railroad war might be settled. A report that Mr. Gould had obtained pledges from representatives of the different roads to attend such a meeting was called to the attention of Mr. H.H. Porter, President of the Omaha Road. Mr. Porter said that he had made no promise of that sort.

Torrence, Secretary of the Pennsylvania Bibie Society; his nephew, 8 years old, and four men in his employ, while driving home last evening in a spring-wagon, were precipitated down an embankment by the shying of their horse, and all were badly injured.
