All overdue notes, with interest, will be paid on presentation, and all notes not due will be paid at maturity.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 29.--The Rev. James Beecher, a half-brother of Henry Ward Beecher, who eight years ago resigned his position as Pastor of the Poughkeepsie Congregational church, where he was extremely popular and in receipt of a large salary, and took up his residence in the backwoods of Ulster County, was placed in the State Homeopathic Asylum for the Insane, at this place, a few days ago.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29.--It is announced that the rail works of the St. Louis Ore and Steel Company will close, at least in part, about the middle of December unless a reduction of 25 per cent. in the cost of pig-iron and labor is effected before that time.

There is no longer any doubt that we are to have the Passion Play. Miss Lizzie Vanderbilt, a daughter of Mrs. S.A. Hoogland, was married last evening to Mr. George W. Vanderhoef. The ceremony took place it the Hotel Bristol, Fifth-avenue and Forty-secend-streed, and was performed by the Rev. Dr. Coe, of the Forty-eighth-Street Collegiate Church.

Thomas Hoey, an engineer in the employ of Alois A. Bermnn, the proprietor of a large factory building in East Twenty-second-street, near Second-avenue, met with a terrible death yesterday. Hoey had charge of the engine which supplied steam power to the building.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13.--The announcement made some time ago through THE TIMES that the Hon. H.B. Payne, of Cleveland, andJudge George W. Hoadley had a quiet understanding in reference to important political deals for future realization finds early indorsement so far as Mr. Payne is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--The effort to procure a jury in the star route case was resumed this morning. At the time of adjournment yesterday there was one juror (John H. Crane,) sworn, and there were ten others in the box who had passed the gantlet of challenges on the part of the defense, but who were still open to challenges on the part of the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--To the friends of civil service reform who have been waiting in vain for years for Congress to do something in the way of real reform the prospect of the early passage of the Pendleton bill in the Senate is probably as gratifying as any they may hope to see during the present session.

A motion to compel William Campbell to pay temporary alimony and a counsel fee to his wife, Annie Louise Campbell, whom he issuing to obtain an absolute divorce, was made before Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Campbell have long been at enmity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13, 1882. Secretary Folger has sustained the appeal of Watjen, Tael Co., of New-York, against the assessment of a duty on Hawaiian Sugar, and has ordered the Collector to reliquidate the entry free of duty.

James C. Rice Post, No. 29, opened their fair last evening in the assembly-rooms in the Grand Opera-house under favorable auspices. Before 3 o'clock the rooms overflowed, and a great many applicants for admission were turned away.

The presence in Europe of the envoys of her Most Gracious and Christian Majesty of Madagascar has set the newspapers of France and England snarling at each other, and their quarrel is, in some respects, like a falling out among thieves.

Bellini's "Sonnambula" was represented for the first time this season at the Academy of Music last evening. A meeting was held in Commissioner Fink's office yesterday afternoon of representatives of the Union and Central Pacific Railroads, the trunk lines running to this City, and the intermediate reads running from Chicago to Council Bluffs, which are banded together in one association known as the Iowa Trunk Road Association.

The Charity Ball of 1883 will take place in the Academy of Music on Thursday, Jan. 25. The annual reunion of the Wesleyan University Alumni of New-York will take place at Martiuelli's to-morrow evening.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13.--W.J. Pope Co., lumber merchants, have failed, with liabilities amounting to $94,000. The Exchange Bank is their largest creditor, the amount due them being $50,000, which is fully secured, however, on timber limits.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13.--Frank McNamee, Henry, alias "Dutch," Pillett, and Levi and Robert Chew, the resurrectionists, were indicted to-day by the Grand Jury, six true bills being found against them, and their trial is fixed positively for Friday morning.

BOSTON, Dec. 13.--In the Municipal Court, before Judge Parmenter, this forenoon, Michael O'Neill was arraigned on a complaint charging him with the murder of his wife, Hannah, at their home, in Dedham-street, last Sunday night. Officers have been at work on the case ever since the murder was discovered, last Monday forenoon.

Inspector Byrnes ascertained yesterday that a well-organized plan was on foot to rob one of the banks in this City. He was unable to ascertain which banking institution was to be honored by a visit from burglars, so he took measures whereby the Police Captains stationed an officer at the entrance to every bank in their respective precincts.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--The Times says from the point of view of administrative efficiency the impending changes in the Cabinet give general satisfaction. The Pall Mall Gazette says the announcements of changes in the Ministry are premature. The Times says Lord Derby has accepted the Secretaryship for India.

The railroad strife in the North-west was ended yesterday, and the old rates will be restored on the warring lines to-day. The questions at issue, however, were not settled, and the terms of peace were the simplest that could have been devised.

Maitland, Phelps Co., the correspondents of the Colonial Bank, in Kingston, Jamaica, say they do not think that the fire in that city on Monday last has proved as disastrous as was at first supposed.
LONDON, Dec. 13.--The Press Association says the Bishop of Winchester has declined the Archbishopric of Canterbury owing to his advanced age.

ALBANY, Dec. 11.--Three weeks from today the Democratic Party, for the second time in nearly 30 years, will come into full possession of the legislative power of the State Government--having the Governor and a good working majority in both branches of the Legislature.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--A fire broke out early this morning in the east quadrangle of Hampton Court, the royal palace at Hampton, 15 miles from this city. The local fire brigade succeeded in confining the flames to a private suite of apartments in the cloisters in which they originated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14, 1882. The House Committee on Public Lands today agreed to report favorably upon Mr. Washburne's bill to repeal the laws allowing pre-emption of the public lands and amending the Homestead law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--Raymond B. Newcomb, the naturalist and taxidermist of th Jeannette expedition, was examined by the Board of Inquiry to-day. He said that he had no charges to make against any officer of the ship or against the management of the expedition, although he admitted that the visit to Bennett Island caused unnecessary delay.

The beautiful and enterprising town of Opelika, Ala., is in mourning. Her favorite sons, or several of them, at least, have been laid low in fratricidal strife, and the angry note of the shot-gun has disturbed the peace of many families.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 14.--The Australasian mine in Creswick, Victoria, has been flooded. Twenty-two persons were drowned.

TOLEDO, Dec. 15.--The Hall block at St. Clair and Jefferson streets, the finest business block in the city, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The first floor of the building was occupied by numerous jobbing houses and the upper floors by law and insurance offices, the offices of the Wabash and Ohio Central Railroad Companies, art galleries,

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--A well-attended meeting of citizens of the Fifth Congressional District was held in this city to-day, and an association was formed, to be known as the Civil Service Reform Association of the Fifth Congressional District.
The Chairman of the Republican National Committee issued a call some days ago for a meeting of that body, to be held in Washington on the 17th of January.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--In the case of Dr. J.K. Alleon, convicted in the United States District Court of circulating improper matter through the mails, Judge Treat, in that court, to-day, alluding to the case, gave the Society for the Suppression of Crime a severe rebuke.

A faint odor of smoke was perceptible on the parlor and ground floors of the New-York Hotel at 10 o'clock last night. Mr. H.C. Cranston and Detective Larkin thought that its source was the news-stand of William Guernsey, under a stairway near the telegraph office, and this was thoroughly explored without result.
At the annual business meeting of Plymouth Church last evening Gen. C.T. Christensen, the Clerk of the church, read his report for the year ending yesterday.
The lives of a number of women and childred were imperiled yesterday afternoon by a fire which broke out on the ground floor of the fivestory double tenement-house, No. 172 Suffolk street.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--The East St. Louis City Council are reported to have decided to cut down the poles of the Western Union Telegraph Company in that city and to have purchased a lot of axes for that purpose.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 15.--A terrible tragedy occurred in Richmond County, in his State, last night. It seems that John Rogers went to see Miss Violetta Deans, with whom he was in love, and found with her Duncan McDonald, who was also in love with the young lady.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 15.--News has just been received of an affair which occurred Monday night at Graceville, a small village in Big Stone County, on the Browns Valley branch of the Manitoba Road, in which John Callaghan, a farmer, was shot and instantly killed, and his young son, aged 12, was fatally wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Col. Robert Murray, Surgeon, to be Colonel and Assistant Surgeon-General; Lieut.-Col. John F. Hammond, Surgeon, to be Colonel and Surgeon; Major Basil Norris, Surgeon, to be LieutenantColonel and Surgeon; Capts. Frank Meacham and Daniel G. Caldwell, Assistant Surgeons, to be Majors and Surgeons.
The ingenuous opera-goer who went to the Academy of Music last night expecting to hear "Aid a" with Mme. Fursch-Madi in the title role, found himself listening to Gounod's "Faust."

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--The Faculty of the Chicago University to-day suspended two students for impudence and insubordination in connection with the recent troubles there. Bad feeling still prevails, and more suspensions may follow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--A dispatch from Way's Landing, N.J., says the Supreme Court of New-Jersey is engaged to-day in the consideration of the suit in ejectment against the Camden and Atlantic Land Company and Edwin Lippincott, owner at land bought from that company.
Robert A. Smith, of St. Paul, has been added to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee from Minnesota.
LONDON, Dec. 15.--The Daily News says that before Parliament reassembles Sir Charles Dilke, Under Foreign Secretary, will probably enter the Cabinet.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. Charles Andrews, Chief-Justice, presiding, the following decisions were handed down: Davidsburgh vs. The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company; Mason vs. Libbey; Ryan vs. Cochran; ...

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--A movement is on foot in this city among wholesale fruit-dealers to form an organization similar to the one recently formed in New-York, and a meeting was held this afternoon to devise means to correct some of the evils of which they complain. The matter of selling fruit at auction was much commented upon.
KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 15.--The Medical College difficulty has been settled. No more women will be admitted to the college, but those now attending will be allowed to finish their course.

BATH, Me., Dec. 15.--Nothing has been heard from the new steam-bark Mendoza, Capt. Tucker, now 12 days from Bath, Me., for New-York. It is generally believed that she has been blown out to sea, and will have to work back under sail. Her builders confidently expect that she will report within a few days.

BERLIN, Dec. 15.--The North German Gazette says in view of the disinclination of the French to purchase articles of German manufacture Germany will not maintain the present moderate duties on French goods, and will particularly subject sparkling winos and articles de Paris to higher duties.

WINSTON, N.C., Dec. 15.--Intelligence has been received here that the people of Stokes County, in this State, are very much excited over the discovery of the actual sale by one man of his wife to another.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The following companies were incorporated to-day: The Multiplex Telegraph Company of New-York; capital, $1,000,000. The New-York, Richfield Springs and Cooperstown Railway Company; capital, $6,000,000.

The Symphony Society's public rehearsal yesterday afternoon was attended by an immense audience. Bruch's new symphony received a faithful performance at the hands of the orchestra, and was much enjoyed by the audience, ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 15.--The steam-boat St. Francis Belle, belonging to the Ouachita River Consolidated Line, sank in Bayou Bartholomew to-day. She had a full cargo of cotton. No lives were lost. The boat was valued at $8,000; insured in this city for $4,000. The cargo is doubtless insured, and will be saved in a damaged condition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--At 10:30 o'clock this morning the jury in the Teresa Sturlata case came into court and rendered a verdict that Teresa Sturlata was guilty of manslaughter and that her punishment be one year in the penitentiary. Mr. Trude, counsel for the prisoner, has entered a motion for a new trial.

Jay Gould contributed a mass of interesting testimony yesterday in the investigation which the Senate committee is making of corners and futures and their effect upon the public welfare and the trade and commerce of the country.
A corner is made when the control of a certain article of merchandise or a certain line of stocks is held by one party of men, or by one man.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 15.--The steam-boat Kate Kinney took fire in the bayou at Ferry Landing, La., at 2:30 P.M., to-day. The boat and cargo are a total loss.

MADRID, Dec. 15.--At the sitting of the Congress yesterday Senor Rivas, one of the leading supporters of Marshal Serrano, made the unexpected declaration that all the members of the Dynastic Left would accept the Constitution of 1876, and if called to power would reform it in a liberal sense on the lines of the Constitution of 1869, but without constituent periods.

There was seen yesterday at Messrs. Knabe Co.'s factory a magnificent concert grand, just finished by them for the Presidential mansion. President Arthur, who is a thorough connoisseur of music, in selecting a piano for the White House decided in favor of the Knabe Piano as his preference, and ordered accordingly the instrument referred to.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 15.--In the Troup-Register libel suit to-day much time was spent in arguing objections. Mr. Alling, of counsel for the defense, asked James Gallagher, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, if Troup was not a public man, to which plaintiff objected.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Some time since the Secretary of the Board of Trade sent a notice to the telegraph companies doing business on the board that, after Jan. 1, 1883, no operator would be allowed on the board who transmitted market quotations to "bucket-shops."

The friends of the late Robert L. Stuart nearly filled the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday during the funeral service, which was conducted with extreme simplicity, in accordance with the wishes of the dead man.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 15.--The Right Rev. Bishop Tuigg, of this Catholic Diocese, is lying seriously ill at the Episcopal residence in this city. The sudden prostration of the Bishop has caused general alarm throughout the diocese.
HAVANA, Dec. 15.--The steamer Saratoga, which sailed hence yesterday for New-York, has on board $187,000 in specie.

COFFEYVILLE, Kan., Dec. 15.--News has been received here of great suffering among the Cherokee Indians, in the Indian Territory, on account of the ravages of small-pox. In one family of five members all have died. The Territorial Government has appropriated $2,000 to secure attendants for the sick.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--The Land Commissioners to-day granted 40 acres of land under water, on the Hudson River, in the south part of Albany, to Eugene Van Rensselaer and others, with certain restrictions, for $100 per acre.

There was much mystery at Police Headquarters last night over the arrest of a tall, stout, well-built gentleman, who said to be a railroad officer and a defaulter to the extent of $300,000. In the early evening two lawyers, C.H. Tweed and Treadwell Cleveland, of No. 52 Wall-street, called at Police Head-quarters and held a long conference with Inspector Byrnes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Capt. H.H. Crews, Fourth Artillery, who tendered his resignation a few days ago, has reconsidered his action and withdrawn his resignation.

TRENTON, Dec. 15.--The eighth annual meeting of the New-Jersey Sanitary Association came to a close in the State Capitol to-day.

A fire broke out in the four-story brick building at No. 244 Pearl-street at 1:30 o'clock this morning. The building is occupied by J.F. Herbert as a brush and broom factory, and by Meyer Mendelsohn as a tobacco factory. The loss will probably not be more than $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The War Department to-day received information that First Sergt. Neeland, Company B, with Sergt. Bobst, of Company F, and two Indian scouts, struck a camp of half-breeds and Crees, near Campbell's Houses, on Milk River, in Montana Territory, on Saturday night, the 2d inst. The party fled with their horses, leaving in Neeland's hands 58 carts and harness, 20 hides, 16,000 pounds of meat, and other property.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 15.--Trichinae were discovered to-day in a white man named Henry Beaver. His body is filled with the animalculae, but they are well encysted and no fatal termination is feared. They are ascribed to eating freely of sausage.
Long ago THE TIMES raised a warning voice in regard to the india rubber waterproofs that women were then beginning to wear.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--When the Jeannette Board met this morning the Judge-Advocate announced that the court had decided to admit Lieut. Wainwright to represent Lieut. Danenhower in asking the questions contained in the letter submitted yesterday.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday took up the estimates of the Park Department for next year. Alderman Levy, on behalf of a committee appointed by the Common Council, asked the board to so increase the appropriations for the Park Department that the salaries of the park policemen might be raised.
The Prince of Arisgawa, uncle of the Emperor of Japan, arrived in this City yesterday, on the Scythia, of the Cunard Line, and at present occupies a suite at the Windsor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The Committee on Ways and Means to-day continued its work upon the report of the Tariff Commission. Schedule B, comprising earthenware and glassware, was completed, through all the items under the head of glass were passed for future inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--In the Dickson case in the Police Court to-day the cross-examination of Brewster Cameron was resumed. He said the conversation in which the $25,000 demand was first mentioned occurred down stairs at Driver's.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 15.--A Winnipeg special to the Pioneer-Press says that last night shortly before 7 o'clock the Canadian Pacific Railroad Hotel, in Main-street, a frame building near the railway station, was discovered to be on fire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15.--There have been very heavy floods in Oregon and Washington Territory for the last three days, and much damage has been done to railroads, bridges, , by the flood. The Pendleton River rose so rapidly that many of the inhabitants were forced to take refuge in trees, where they remained all night. Mills, houses, and other property were carried away. No loss of life has been reported.

DETROIT, Dec. 15.--The official canvass of the late State election is now proceeding at Lansing. The vote for Governor is declared as follows: Begole, Democrat and Greenback candidate, 154,268; Jerome, (Rep.,) 149,697; Sagendorph, (Proh.,) 5,854. The vote for the remainder of the State officers stands--Republicans, 157,000; Fusionists, 149,000.

Manufacturers of rubber boots and shoes, belting, packing, and hose, and rubber clothing, met yesterday at No. 115 Broadway, Mr. A.O. Bourne, of the National Rubber Company, of Rhode Island, in the chair.

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--Charles J. Eastman, Rufus K. Noyes, and W.D. Corken, corporators and officers of the Bellevue Medical College, recently arrested on the charge of issuing bogus diplomas, were examined before Commissioner Hallett today on charges of using the mails for fraudulent purposes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--There is a growing impression that a tariff revision bill, agreeing in most respects with the bill of the Tariff Commission, will be passed by Congress at this session.

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--An agent of the Duke of Sutherland is now in this country, and at present is in charge of the land agent of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company. He will inspect the Atchison Company's lands in Kansas, those of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company in Arizona, and some lands that are offered for sale in Chihuahua, of the line of the Mexican Central Railroad.
The steam-ship Celtic, from Liverpool, arrived last evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15.--The Marquis of Lorne and the Princess Louise and suite will go by a special train to Monterey this afternoon. The party will remain there until the early part of next week, when they will return here. On the 24th inst. the Princess and the ladies of her suite will go to Santa Barbara, but the Marquis will return to Canada.

The attendance at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon was decidedly flattering to Mr. Archer, considering the musical attractions at the Academy of Music with the Symphony Society and Stienway Hall with the New-York Chorus Society.

Senators Jacobs, Jones, and Lynde, composing the subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee, continued the investigation of the Emigrant Commission yesterday by examining W.H. McPherson, an interpreter at Castle Garden from 1874 until last year.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec., 15.--The steamer Carrie, owned by the Petersburg Steam-boat Company, sank this afternoon in the James River, opposite Blair's Wharf, while coming into Petersburg with a large cargo of freight consigned to merchants in this place. The passengers and crew narrowly escaped with their lives.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--In the Farmers' Convention this morning Mr. Green B. Raum made a speech favoring protection. Ulrick Bleckenderfer, of Pennsylvania, read a paper on "Under Drainage."

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Attorney-General Russell heard arguments this afternoon on the application of Joseph P. Greaves, John G. Moore, and others, for permission to bring an action in the name of the people of the State to annul the charter of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--A temperance reformer well known here as "Bud Eagleston" was run over and killed to-night by a train on the Baltimore and Potomac Railway.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15.--Receiver Smith, of the broken First National Bank, to-day secured a judgment for $51,387 against Charles C. Sears, and a judgment for $10,542 against Sears and R. Porter Lee. Lee was President of the bank and is now serving a term in the penitentiary for wrecking it.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 15.--Dr. Wiggins has received a letter from the Secretary of State, of Great Britain, stating that he has laid before the Lord Commissioners of the Admiralty his letter announcing his prediction of a great storm on the 9th and 11th of March. Dr. Wiggins has received many letters from all parts of the United States making inquiries regarding the storm, its direction, nature,

Orders were issued yesterday by Superintendent Walling to keep up the Police guard over the banks in this City until after Dec. 17. The guard will also be resumed on the evening of the 23d inst., and will be continued until the day after Christmas, and the same plan will be followed on New Year's Day.

MANSFIELD, La., Dec. 15.--Peter Thomas, colored, was hanged here to-day, in the presence of 2,000 people, for the murder of Richard Bright, also colored. The drop fell at 2:30, and 11 minutes later Thomas was pronounced dead.

GALWAY, Dec. 15.--Patrick Joyce, Myles Joyce, and Patrick Casey, the three men convicted of participation in the murder of the Joyce family, at Maamtrasna, on the night of the 17th of August last, were hanged in the jail here at 8 o'clock this morning.

Choate and James O. Broadhead for defendants in error, and concluded by B.H. Bristow for plaintiff in in error.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--The Mississippi Valley Cane Growers Association held its final meeting to-day, when the question of securing a market for sorghum was considered.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 15.--R.D. Whitehead, of the Humane Society, who went to Nebraska to search for Maggie Hennicke, telegraphed to the father of the missing girl to-day that nothing could be learned in Hastings, and that Brown, who claims to have found the three abductors, had gone to Iowa. Mr. Whitehead left Hastings for home to-day, and will stop at Shenandoah, Iowa, to look up Brown. Mr. Hennicke has gone to meet him.

PARIS, Dec. 16.--The Cabinet has decided to postpone bringing forward a credit bill for the expedition to Tonquin at present. The report of the abandonment of the expedition is without foundation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--The House to-day went into Committee of the Whole on the Post Office Appropriation bill, the pending amendments being that offored by Mr. Robinson, of Massachusetts, appropriating $600,000 for special mail facilities, and that offered by Mr. Hiscock, of New-York, reducing the sum to $200,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--The work of the House Committee on Appropriations is in a very satisfactory condition. Only two weeks of the session have passed, but four of the regular appropriation bills have already been disposed of. These are the Military Academy, Indian, Diplomatic, and Agricultural bills.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Dec. 18.--The steamer Colina, from Glasgow to Baltimore, put in here yesterday afternoon for repairs. On Thursday at 2 P.M. she experienced a heavy gale in latitude 48 32', longitude 43 51'.

The first Patriarch ball of this season came off last night at Delmonico's. The rooms were decorated as usual with tapestry, lambrequins, damask curtains, and illuminated with tinted lights, so that the spectator might easily have imagined that he was at one of the balls of last season.

The large assembly-room in the Academy of Music Building, Brooklyn, was filled by a merry party of gentlemen last night, the occasion being a complimentary dinner given by the Brooklyn Young Republican Club to Mr. Horace E.Deming, the retiring President.
The antiquated practice of serving out stated portions of grog to seamen on ocean vessels has almost entirely gone out of fashion on the large passenger steam-ships which traverse the seas.

The steam-ship Wisconsin, of the Guion Line, which was due here last week, arrived at Quarantine yesterday morning. The delay was caused by her having come into collision with an American bark, which the wisconsin afterward attempted to tow into port.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18.--The House Committee on Ways and Means this morning continued its consideration of the metals schedule. Returning to the section considered on Saturday the words "iron or" were restored in the Trails Clause.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18.--On Sunday last the commission of George B. Winslow, Postmaster at Gouverneur, St. Lawrence County, N.Y., expired, and he is now holding over until reappointed, or until a new Postmaster shall have been chosen in his place.

HONG KONG, Nov. 22.--There was a great fire at Canton on Nov. 7 and 8. Eight hundred houses were destroyed and many lives lost, including firemen, who were burned to death.

UTICA, Dec, 18.-- George Hardiman, of this city, met Dwight B.Warner, of Rome, in the railway station here this afternoon, and, chasing him to the rear of Baggs's Hotel, fired four shots at him, hitting him twice in the right leg. The injuries are not serious. Hardiman was arrested.

John Most, the German Socialist, who was arrested in England for publicly approving of the assassination of Czar Alexander II, in the columns of the Freiheit, a Socialist organ printed in London, arrived in this City yesterday morning by the steamer Wisconsin.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 18.--Trains Nos. 4 and 5, on the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad, came into collision near Foster's Crossing this morning. Train No. 5 had both day and night mail cars and was three hours late.
The National Petroleum Exchange was opened yesterday. The sales yesterday aggregated 150,000 barrels.

The Penal Code makes an attempt to commit suicide a misdemeanor punishable by two years' imprisonment and a fine of $1,000. The first case ever brought to trial under this new law came before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 19.--Postmaster-General Fawcett is now fairly convalescent. The storm in North-east Scotland which began yesterday continues. Three vessels have gone ashore.

The State Department publishes a copy of the new Russian tariff, which went into effect on July l, 1882. It is stated that this tariff greatly reduces the free list and largely increases duties generally.

After the evening of Thursday there will be no more Salmagundi for another year--so say the authorities of that sprightly little club. It is true that the catalogues give the close as on Friday, the 22d, but owing to some error the day should have been Thursday; the fiat has therefore gone forth to close the exhibition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--The court-martial for the trial of Surgeon Alfred M. Owen, of the Navy, which adjourned last Tuesday, on account of the death of the sister of Rear-Admiral Bryson, President of the court, met again at noon to-day at the Civil Engineer's office, at the navy-yard.

The Camden Transfer Company was obliged to stop running some of its coaches on Saturday afternoon last, and to-day all but a few will be withdrawn from the line, owing to its horses being afflicted with epizooty.

The social revolution has taken on a new phase in Italy. As yet this phase has been visible only in Milan, and Herr MOST, when he made his speech on Monday night, prophesying the speedy destruction of religion and policemen, did not seem to be aware of what was passing in the Lombard capital.
Public Works Commissioner Hubert O. Thompson has sent to Mayor Grace the report of the doings of his department for the third quarter of 1882.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--The leading produce markets were very nervous and unsettled to-day, but generally at a higher range. There was sharp buying early in the day, but it did not last all through the session, and the later tone was decidedly mixed, with not much doing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19.--It was officially announced today that the half-yearly interest on the general mortgage 6 per cent. bonds of the Reading Railroad Company, due Jan. 1, 1883, would be paid when due.

Miss Hilah Eugenie Humbert, a daughter of Mr. Pierre Humbert, was married to Mr. John Houe Foster yesterday in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, Rector of the church.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 19.--In their consideration of the Tariff Commission's report this morning, the days and Means Committee finished the iron and steel schedule, and made only two changes namely, by fixing the rate on wire rope and iron strand the same as an iron-steel wire of the same gauge, (3 cents per pound,) instead of the same rate as that upon the wire of which the rope is made,
The sale of seats for the concert at the Academy of Music next Sunday night has already begun. It will be the last appearance in NewYork of Mr. Mapleson's artists till next March.

Members of the incoming Board of Aldermen are now busily engaged in trying to decide whom they shall elect to preside over them next year. The office of President of the Common Council carries with it membership in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, one of the most important branches of the City Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--In the star route trial this morning Mr. Bliss resumed his opening address, apologizing for the time already consumed by him and promising to conclude within an hour. He then reviewed some additional routes and said he had stated nothing which would not be proved.

The much-talked-of Army Reorganization bill has at last been promulgated. A glance at the enactments it contains proves it to be a simplified system for facilitating mobilization, by keeping the various units in the districts whence they are recruited.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19.--Eight true bills Of indictment were found by the Grand Jury to-day against Dr. William S. Forbes, Demonstrator of Anatomy at Jefferson Medical College, for complicity with resurrectionists in the despoliation of graves in Lebanon Cemetery.

PARIS, Dec. 19.--During the debate on the budget in the Senate to-day, M. Leon Say praised the Cabinet for negotiating in the matter of the incompleted railways, with the view of assigning their completion as a portion of the public works to be executed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--The new legislation recommended in the Army Appropriation bill, as reported to the House by the Appropriations Committee, is as follows: Under the head of "pay of the Army" it provides for the payment (in addition to pay in the line) of 25 aides-decamp instead of 37, as recommended by the estimates.
The new to deum composed by Mrs. Hancock, the wife of Gen. Hancock, will be sung in the chapel on Governor's Island Christmas morning.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 19.--Another disastrous decline caused a wild panic in the Oil Exchange today. The market opened at 96, 1 above yesterday's closing price, then crept up to 98, and afterward began to drop off at a rate which caused consternation.

The tea trade received another surprise yesterday on the announcement of the failure of J. M. White Co., Wholesale dealers in teas at No. 81 Front-street. The partners, Messrs. J.M. White and Thomas Phelan, made an assignment without preference to Morris Woodruff.

The last meeting of the Republican Central Committee for 1882 was held in Republican Hall, in West Thirty-third-street, last night. John J. O'Brien presided, and Police Justice Solon B. Smith was at the Secretary's desk.

Henry L. Kipling, a lawyer, of No.103 Broadway, Brooklyn, Eastern District, and Walter F. Shibley, a clerk, formerly employed by William Sutphen, a lawyer, of No. 20 Nassau-street, were brought before Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, yesterday.

Joseph Cook, of Boston, who announced that he had never been ordained, nor been identified with any evangelical organization, and who modestly announced himself as "the censor of the present current of religions thought," spoke at the Church of the Paternity, at Fifth-avenue and Fortyfifth-street, last evening.

Arguments were heard by Judge Arnoux, in Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday upon three classes of the cases in which injunctions are pending restraining the Police from enforcing the provisions of the Penal Code.
The House of Representatives yesterday reversed its action of the previous day and resolved to take a recess from Dec. 22 to Jan. 2.

Henry James, Sr., the philosopher and theologian, died at his home, in Boston, on Monday afternoon, after a long illness, in the seventy-second year of his age. His last hours were made easy by the presence at his bedside of his two sons.

The Senate committee which has been engaged in this City lately in investigating the effect of " corners" and " futures" upon commerce and the general welfare has succeeded at least in obtaining some very entertaining testimony from men who are popularly supposed to be giants in speculation.

This excellent association of artists gave the second concert of fifth season at Chickering Hall last night. The audience was as numerous at over,and contained an unnusual proportion of musicians and the most experienced amateurs.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20.--It is generally agreed that the next Governor of Ohio stands a better chance of succeeding Senator Pendleton in his present position than any other man in the State.
LONDON, Dec. 20.--The Right Rev. Edward White Benson, Bishop of Truro, has been appointed to, and has accepted, the office of Archbishop of Canterbury.

On the 30th of November, at 10 A.M., a dreadful woman, one Kate Nagy, was banged in Stein-an-Anger, the frontier town between Styria and Hungary. There was a rare gathering in the city of Detroit, Mich., on Friday evening last, the occasion being a banquet tendered by nearly 200 of his fellow citizens to the Hon. Charles C. Trowbridge, to celebrate his eighty-third birthday.

Fire last night swept through the art gallery of Miss Sallie J. Gibbons, on the ground floor of No. 1,160 Broadway, and in less than a quarter of an hour destroyed or damaged the entire collection, which was valued at from $45,000 to $55,000.

The prize offered some months ago for the best design for the enlargement of the Sorbonne in Paris has been awarded to M. Henry Nenot. His plans provide for a ceremonial hall, capable of seating 2,000 persons. Some 22,000,000f. will be expended on the enlargement, more than half the sum being required for the ground. The State contributes one-half of the 22,000,000f. and the city the other.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 4.--F.N. White, of Tobyhanna, manufacturer of baby carriages, has made an assignment. The cause of the failure was lack of capital. His head-quarters were in NewYork.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--The leading produce markets were much more active to-day, and generally stronger. There was a much better demand all round, which seemed to hinge largely on the situation in wheat, and that again hung on the tone of foreign advices, with regard to crop prospects.

It has been remarked that we are only on the threshold of discoveries in electricity. It is not, perhaps, an original remark, since it has been made by several millions of people at bi-weekly intervals during the last three years, but it is evidently entirely true.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--It is estimated that at least 10,000 looms and probably 200,000 spindles are now idle in the cotton and woolen mills of this city and vicinity in consequence of the continued depression in trade.

At a meeting of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Sooiety last Thursday books valued at $9,000 and $182 36 in money were granted to the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Sweden.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 5.--During December the domestic exports at the New Orleans Customhouse amounted to $16,686,852 a gain of $7,285,432 over the same period of last year. This is the largest month's business ever done at this port.

LIMA, Jan. 5.--The letter of Gen. Logan, United States Minister to Chili, to Gen. Montero, was republished in the Diario Oficial of the 2d inst. It is applauded by the Chilians, but causes great indignation among the Peruvians, who say that Gen. Logan, being Minister to Chili and not to Peru. had no right to address an official communication to Peru, and that his letter has really postponed peace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5, 1883. The Controller of the Currency has called for a report snowing the condition of the national banks at the close of business on Saturday, Dec. 30, 1882.

PARIS, Jan. 5.--It is estimated that 15,000 persons yesterday visited the Palais Bourbon, where the body of Gambetta is lying. At a meeting of the Cabinet Council yesterday it was resolved to issue invitations to commanders of army corps and Judges to attend Gambetta's funeral.
LONDON, Jan. 5.--The Times says the note sent to British representatives abroad by Lord Granville, Foreign Secretary, in regard to Egypt is purely explanatory and in no sense apologetic.

There was an almost uninterrupted fall of snow from the beginning to the close of yesterday. Early in the day the flakes fell thickly and covered the ground to the depth of about two inches, but during the afternoon, although the air was full of whirling snow clouds, the amount that actually fell was comparatively small.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5.--The United States steamer Alaska has been ordered to proceed to Honolulu to be there at the time of King Kalakaua's coronation.

The public rehearsal for the third concert of the forty-first season of the Philharmonic Society was given yesterday afternoon at the Academy of Music. To-night the concert will take place, and judging by the attendance of yesterday, the usual throng of genuine admirers of music will be present.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--The Receiver of the German Uptown Savings Bank, which failed Dec. 4, 1875, has transferred to the Superintendent of the Bank Department at Albany the unclaimed dividends due to the depositors of that bank who had not claimed the same when declared.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The District of Columbia Appropriation bill, passed by the House to-day, was prepared and reported by Representative Ketcham, of New-York, who has an exceptional knowledge of District affairs, owing to his service as a Commissioner.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 5.--A short hearing in the Brush murder case was held in the Town Hall at Stratford this afternoon, only three witnesses being called. It was expected that Della Gilbert, a sister of the deceased, would testify, but sickness prevented her appearing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--In the star route trial this morning a good deal of testimony was put in touching the non-delivery of mails at a little Post Office in Colorado called Agate.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 5.--Notices of a 10 per cent. reduction in wages, to go into effect on the 15th inst., have been posted at the Fall River and the Mount Hope Iron Works in Somerset.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The Ways and Means Committee worked all day upon the free list of the Tariff Commission's report. Quinia and cinchonidia, sulphate of and salts of, was struck out and a duty of 10 per cent. ad valorem recommended.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Although the thermometer registered only a few degrees above zero last night a large number of sporting men gathered at a resort on the Troy road to witness a main between socks from Rochester and Mechanicsville.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 5.--Herr Most's efforts here have not been successful, most of the former Socialists being now property-owners. He spoke to-night before about 500 persons. His speech was of the usual nature, advocating the replacing of capital by Communism. No enthusiasm was shown. Herr Most will leave to-morrow for Louisville and other Southern cities.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 5.--At a meeting of depositors of the late City Bank held to-night, John Fahy, Dr. C.E. Rider, S.J. Johnson, D.G. Weaver, and Gilbert Brady were appointed a committee to confer with the late Directors and President and ascertain what terms of settlement can be obtained. Over one-half of the deposits was represented. It is thought that 50 cents in cash will be offered and 25 cents additional in notes running three years.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--It is reported here tonight that John Kelly has given the two Tammany Senators, Grady and Treanor, instructions to co-operate with those Democratic Senators who favor a reorganization of the Senate.

A number of business men, principally cigardealers and proprietors of candy shops, met last evening at No. 422 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, to protest against the Penal Code. Mr. George W. Blauvelt presided.
BOSTON, Jan. 5.--In the case of Jane White, (colored,) against George Spofford, (white,) for $5,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, judgement was given for defendant to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5.--The New-Jersey Legislature will convene here next Tuesday. The action of the managers of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company in discontinuing the trains on the Sixth-avenue line between midnight and 5:30 A.M. has proved to be one of the most unpopular of the many ill-advised acts in the management of the elevated railroad system in this City.

A provincial paper prints a story that Mr. William H. Vanderbilt, the President of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, has ordered his master machanies to devise large and fast locomotives capable of hauling 15 heavy drawing-room cars at the rate of 60 miles an hour.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 5.--Gov. Cullom's Message was presented to the State Legislature today. It estimates the number of persons in charitable institutions in the State at 150,000. Of 5,000 insane persons only 2,000 are provided for in State institutions.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 5.--The Rev. James A. Walsh, Pastor of the Catholic Church of Our Lady "Star of the Sea," has presented to Bishop O'Farrell, of Trenton, as a personal gift, a plot of ground, between Elberon and Green's Pond, and fronting Ocean-avenue, valued at $15,000.

John Kelly called about 1,300 men to order in Tammany Hall last evening, to organize the first meeting of the Tammany General Committee of 1883. The "honored leader" was greeted with loud applause as he named John Welde for temporary Chairman and Joel O. Stevens and Thomas F. Gilroy for temporary Secretaries.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 5.--The Municipal Bank of Sapojok has failed. The town has only 3,000 inhabitants, but the liabilities of the bank are probably several millions of roubles. The assets, exclusive of the furniture, are only 29 roubles. The municipality of Sapojok will prosecute one of the Directors. The affair is regarded as a further proof of the unsoundness of the system of municipal banks.

LONDON, Jan. 5.--Mr. Henry Stevens's collection of documents, c., relative to Benjamin Franklin, which was purchased by the Government of the United States, was handed on Wednesday to the Hon. James Russell Lowell, the American Minister.

BERLIN, Jan. 5.--Prince Bismarck has submitted to the Emperor William a draft of a bill providing relief for the sufferers by the floods. The bill will be presented in the Diet, and it is expected that it will be passed immediately.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--The weather is cold and threatening more snow. Reports from all parts of Northern Illinois and Iowa indicate that from 6 to 8 inches of snow fell last night. Trains are considerably delayed, but none are abandoned yet. In the far North the thermometer is very low, but the weather is moderating.

NEW--HAVEN, Jan. 5.--Part of a freight train was derailed at Milford to-night, while the train was backing from a switch on to the main track, through the failure of the switch to work, and the road was blockaded for three hours. No person was seriously injured.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 5.--The examination in the case of Mrs. Mary Paye, charged with poisoning her husband, David W. Paye, was concluded to-day before Justice Harris, at Fishkill Landing. The Justice in rendering the decision said he had carefully examined the testimony and found it insufficient to hold the prisoner. Thereupon Mrs. Paye was discharged.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5.--The Grain Exchange will to-morrow publish a carefully complied statement showing the amount of wheat now in the State, including that on ships in San Francisco Bay not yet cleared, to be 419,000 tons, and of barley $9,000 tons. The amount of wheat exceeds the previous estimates of wheat men by from 10 to 30 per cent.

READING, Penn., Jan. 5.--The plans of the new pipe line, to extend from Trevorton to Reading, along the county line between Lebanon, Sehuylkill, and Berks Counties, are made public to-day. The Transit Oil Pipe Line Company, of Cleveland, are the projectors. Agents are now purchasing the right of way and settling damages.

BOSTON, Jan. 5.--The Grand Chapter of the Zeta Psi Fraternity of North America continued their session to-day. Business of importance was transacted, and propositions to re-establish several defunct chapters were considered and acted upon.

The investigation by the Senate Committee on Villages auto the sale of public lands is the town of Gravesend, on Coney Island, was resumed at the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday. Senator Browning conducted the examination of witnesses. Mr. J.A. Bowman stated that he began buying land at Coney Island for Mr. Corbin in 1873.

COHOES, Jan. 5.--The fiercest and most disastrous fire that has visited Cohoes in a long time broke out this morning. The fire originated in the wheel pit of the rolling mill of Morrison, Colwell Page. As is generally known, work was suspended there last Friday for repairs, and was to have been resumed this morning.

MILTON, Ontario, Jan. 5.--Michael O'Rourke, who murdered the old man Maher and his daughter in Nelson Township, Halton County, in January last, was hanged at 8 o'clock this morning. He was firm to the last, but made no statement on the scaffold, Father O'Reilly saying a few words in his behalf.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 5.--Roland Blied, warehousemen, have failed for $27,000; assets, $9,000.

LONDON, Jan. 8.--Sir Charles Dilke was to-day re-elected to Parliament from Chelsea without opposition.

A large proportion of the entrance examinations for the English universities are fixed for next month, and in thousands of middle class households the controversy whether unviersity education helps young men on in life must again be raging.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8.--The stockholders of the Reading Railroad Company are in an exceedingly pleased frame of mind to-night over the prospect of an early termination of the Receivership and the unexpectedly good showing made in the reports of the President and Receivers of the company at the meeting to-day.

PARIS, Jan. 8.--The coffin containing the body of M. Gambetta has been placed in the vault at Pere la Chaise belonging to the Municipality of Paris. A bag filled with earth, from the soil of Lorraine, which was sent from Metz, is now being placed upon it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Third Assistant Postmaster-General Hazen received special returns from 89 of the 138 letter carrier Post Offices. These 89 offices, comprising the principal Post Offices and collecting about 38 per cent of the total postal revenue, show an increase in business of 10.4 per cent.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 8.--Lawrence Barrett is playing an engagement here this week. This afternoon he was called upon at his hotel by Mr. R.J.E. Miles and a number of other gentlemen of the Dramatic Festival. Mr. Miles is the Director of the festival.

Mayor Edson's office was filled with politicians yesterday, and the City Hall was filled with countless rumors regarding the nominations for one Police Commissioner, two Police Justices, and two Park Commissioners, which the Mayor is to send to the Board of Aldermen at noon to-day.

GALVESTON, Jan. 8.--A special to the News from Henderson says: "The negro, Andrew Jackson, who recently attempted an outrage on a young lady, was taken from the jail last night by a large mob and hanged to a tree in front of the Hotel Don Juan."

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen organized yesterday for the year 1883 by the election of Alderman James Weir, Jr., as President. Mr. Weir is a Democrat, and was the caucus nominee of his party, which is in a majority in the board.
The annual meeting of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game was held last evening at Angear and Croghan's, No.69 Madison-avenue, Mr. Benjamin L. Ludington, Vice-President, in the chair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The Ways and Means Committee's revision of the commission's tariff bill was sent to the printer this evening, and the bill will probably be reported on Wednesday or Thursday next. CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--The refusal of the standing committee of the Springfield (Ill.) Diocese to consent to the installation of the Rev. Dr. Hugh Miller Thompson, an Assistant Bishop of Mississippi, was commented on with much interest in Episcopalian circles to-day.
DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 8.--Fire broke out this evening at the foot of the elevator in the telegraph block, evidently in some rags kept there for use around the elevator.
An elaborate dinner was given at the Union League Club to a party of about 20 gentlemen by Edward A. Quintard, President of the Citizens' Savings Bank, last evening.

BOSTON, Jan. 9.--To-day 49 out of the 61 Boston banks held their annual meetings. All the reports presented showed an excellent condition of things. As a whole, the showing, was better than for 1881 in every-respect. The changes made at the meetings to-day as compared with past years were few in number, and are confined almost entirely to the Directories. The old officers, with hardly an exception, being unanimously re-elected, for the ensuing year.

OTTAWA, Jan. 9.--Veterinary surgeons of Manitoba have forwarded to the Minister of Agriculture a recommendation that the Government appoint an inspector of animals for the frontier ports of that Province in order to prevent the importation of diseased animals, owing to the prevalence of glanders and bink-eye in the United States.
COLUMBUS, Jan. 9.--The Ohio State Woolgrowers' Association met in convention here today, an unusually large number of those engaged in the wool, interest being present.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Jan. 9.--The funeral of Sister Mary Bernadotte Maher, a well-known Sister of Charity and teacher in the Roman Catholic Female seminary here, took place this forenoon. Her life was piously devoted to the sick at all times, without reference to sect or creed, and she fell a victim to her own devotion to the sufferings of others.

The steam-ship City of Richmond from Liverpool, landed 121 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 9.--The dead body of H.A. Wilson, the night yard-master of the Cincinnati Southern and Western and Atlantic Railroads at Boyce Station, five miles from this city, was found on the tracks this morning. He had been struck on the head with a heavy billet and his skull crushed.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Jan. 9.--Judge Dreher made a decree to-day in the equity suit between Asa Packer's estate and the late firm of Noble Hammett Co. in favor of the Packer estate. The suit was commenced by Asa Packer in 1857, and grew out of the building of the Lehigh Valley Railroad. It involved a very large amount of money.

A lecture descriptive of the object, the scope, and the spirit of the Nineteenth Century Club, recently formed, was delivered last evening by Mr. Courtlandt Palmer at his residence, No. 117 East Twenty-first-street. An audience of about three-score ladies and gentlemen enjoyed the hospitality of Mr. and Mrs. Palmer, and listened to the lecture with interest.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 9.--There is no doubt that the Rev. F.F. Emerson, of Amherst, Mass., will accept the call to the United Congregational Church in this city. This pulpit was vacated by the Rev. Henry Vandyke, Jr., who accepted a call to the Brick Church, New-York. It is one of the leading Congregational Churches in this State.

ATHENS, Jan. 9.--Mr. Eugene Schuyler, United States Minister to Greece, presented his credentials to the King to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 9.--The New-England growers of seed-leaf tobacco held an adjourned meeting here to-day to consider their interests as affected by the introduction of the Sumatra leaf.

GALVESTON, Jan. 9.--A special dispatch from Waco to the News says: "Last Thursday a young man named E.C. Oberly attempted suicide because the parents of a young lady he loved objected to him. AUGUSTA, Jan. 9.--In the House to-day Representative Eaton, (Fusion,) of Camden, presented a resolution providing for a stringent prohibitory amendment to the State Constitution and for the enactment of such laws as shall be necessary to carry out sach amendment. Both branches of the Legislature agreed to proceed to elect a United States Senator next Tuesday noon.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 9.--An act was introduced in the Delaware Legislature to-day to repeal the Uniform Ballot law passed by the Democrats two years ago. The law is similar in some respects to the black ballot law of Connecticut. It was passed as a political measure, by which it was expected some advantage would be secured. The Democrats are heartily sick of it, and it will be gladly repealed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--A report was in circulation to-day at the Capitol that the President had decided to withdraw the nomination of John F. Olmstead to be District Commissioner. It was afterward stated at the White House that the President had expressed no such intention, and that the report was without foundation in fact.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 9.--The Supreme Court overruled the motion of James E. Campbell for a writ of mandamus to count the vote in the Seventh Congressional District for H.L. Morey and Henry L. Morey for different persons, so that Morey (Republican) holds the certificate.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 9.--Last November a son of Josoph Bates, colored who was then in the employ of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company, received his monthly pay, amounting to $23 40. He received the money in a sealed envelope, which was the customary way of paying employes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9.--Major Charles T. Doxey is elected to Congress to succeed Mr. Orth from the Ninth District at the special election held to-day. The earlier advices are to the effect that he has carried every county in the district except Tipton.

Mr. Frederick Wolffe, the financiai agent of the English, German, and American syndicate which is organizing a new system of railroads in the South, said last night that 62 miles remained to be built to complete the Brunswick and Albany Railroad to the Chattachoochee River. He was negotiating for a road to Montgomery, Ala., making a through line from Brunswick, Ga., to the former place.

A full account of the exhibition given by Mr. Jem Mace, the famous pugilist, and Mr. Herbert A. Slade, the New-Zealand giant, in San Francisco on Monday evening has been telegraphed to Mr. Richard K. Fox, of this City.

RIHMOND, Jan. 9.--A heavy north-east snow-storm set in here at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and at this hour, 8 P.M., there is no indication of its ceasing. Telegrams from along the line of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway show the storm to be general as far west as Ashland, Ky. From the present outlook it will probably be the heaviest snow-storm seen in Virginia for years.

TROY, Jan. 9.--John E. Glendenning, a linendealer, made a general assignment to-day to Joseph Hicks. He made preferences to Margaret H. Duke, of Brooklyn, $225, and to Lockwood, Glendenning McLeod, of New-York, $700. His liabilities are about $10,000 and his assets about $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9, 1883. Clarks Mills, the sculptor, is dangerously ill with an affection of the heart. The Senate, in executive session, to-day ratified the Corean treaty. The terms of the treaty will not be made public until promulgated by the President.

BOSTON, Jan. 9.--An event which was a complete surprise to his friends on the street was the sudden departure for England, Tuesday last, of Henry Clementson, a wool broker, leaving unpaid debts, it is alleged, to the amount of several thousand dollars.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 9.--John A. Edwards (mulatto) and Katie Marsh, the Rochester elopers, were caught this morning at Willsborough, Essex County, N.Y., and taken to Middlebury, Vt., tonight. They did not want to come back to Vermont, but thought there was no alternative. The girl announces that she intends to marry Edwards. The authorities have not yet decided what course to take.

TORONTO, Dec. 9.--Samuel Miles, a 7-yearold boy, was found frozen fast on the ice in the middle of the bay. He left home to skate on Saturday afternoon, and, it is thought, was driven out by a strong wind, and being uuable to return, lay down and was frozen to death.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9.--There was a decidedly lively time at the meeting of the Committee of One Hundred to-day over the question of the right and propriety of a member of the committee to permit his name to go before the people as a candidate for a public office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--The House to-day resumed consideration of the Shipping bill. Mr. BISBEE, of Florida, thought there were fatal objections to the section which exempts vessels engaged in foreign trade from State and municipal taxation.

The annual meeting of the American Geographical Society was held last evening in Chickering Hall. Chief-Justice Charles P. Daly presided. The report of George Cabot Ward, the Treasurer of the Society, showed that the receipts during the past year were $10,696 32, of which a small balance remained on hand after the payment of expenses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--In the star route trial this morning, Juror Greer, replying to an inquiry, said he had seen the sick juror (Gill) yesterday afternoon, and had been told that he would be prasent today. Mr. Bliss said that for the purpose of being regular he would request a return of the subpoena for John Walsh.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9.--A meeting of the Directors of the Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad Company will be held in New-York on Friday next, President Harris not being able to attend a meeting here.

PARIS, Jan. 9.--Gen. Horix de Valdau, Chief of Staff to Gen. Vinoy during the siege of Paris, and a signatory to the capitulation of that city in the Franco-German war, died at L'Isle-Adam on Saturday of apoplexy on hearing of the death of Gen. Chanzy.

Hawkins to-day received a dispatch from United States Marshal Milner, of San Antonio, Texas, stating that State Treasurer Polk had been rearrested and would be held until the reward was paid. The Westchester County Board of Supervisors met at White Plains yesterday. They authorized the making of a contract with the White Plains Gas Company for the lighting of the county buildings at the rate of $2 75 per 1,000 feet.

BUFFALO, Jan. 9.--At the annual meeting of the Erie County Medical Society to-day Dr. T.M. Johnson, the President, delivered an address in which he urged the necessity for the creation of a State Board of Pharmacy. The Counties of NewYork and Kings now have laws regulating pharmacy, but in the other counties almost any one may sell drugs and poisons.

HAARISBURG, Jan. 9.--In the Senate tonight Senator Everhart presented a bill probibiting the issuance of passes by railroad corporations except to officers and employes. It provides a penalty of $100 for a violation of the act. It does not apply to passes issued before the adoption of the new Constitution, or to passes granted for a valuable consideration under contracts made between corporations and individuals.

TORONTO, Jan. 9.--The Rev. W.S. Rainsford, who has accepted a call from St. George's Church, New-York, and leaves to-morrow, gave a farewell service last night. He was presented with a purse of $1,000. The parting between the Pastor and the congregation was a very sad one. Mrs. Rainsford was so much affected that she fainted.

The following steam-ships are several days overdue: The Daniel Steinman, from Antwerp, Dec. 21: the Pollux, from Amsterdam, Dec. 20, and the Notting Hill, from Liverpool, Dec. 21. The agents of these vessels do not feel uneasy about them, as heavy weather has prevailed on the Atlantic of late. The City of Richmond, of the Inman Line, which arrived yesterday, encountered severe gales and freezing weather, during which the crew suffered greatly.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 9.--Mayor Logan, of Salem, writes that reports of small-pox there are greatly exaggerated, saving there are but two cases of that disease, and three of varioloid, in the town limits, and only five or six cases on the outskirts of the town. He says the disease has not reached the epidemic state. Considerable excitement prevails there.
BOSTON, Jan. 9.--The funeral services of the late Matthew Francis Whittier took place at Maverick House, East Boston, to day, and brought together a large attendance of relatives and friends ...

COULTERSVILLE, Ill., Jan. 9.--Yesterday afternoon a terrible explosion occurred in the coal mine of Jones Nesbit, near here. Of 12 persons in the mine at the time only two escaped--a man named Mason and a boy. Mason was at the mouth of the shaft and was badly hurt. The explosion seems to have been occasioned by the ignition of fire-damp by blasting coal.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9.--In the hearing in the Melville habeas corpus proceedings to-day nearly the entire session was taken up in the examination of evidence produced by Engineer Melville to show that his wife was unfit to have the custody of her children.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Jan. 9.--Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon a frightful boiler explosion occurred at No. 1 blast furnace of the Bethlehem Iron Company, resulting in the death of four men and a woman, and in the serious injury of several others.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 9.--The case of the New-York and Charleston Steam-boat Company against Alexander Harbison, late QuartermasterGeneral of the State, to recover for a failure of contract in the transportation of Connecticut troops to Charleston last year is on trial before Judge Shipman, of the United States court.

WILKESBARRE, Jan. 9.--"Al" Wilson, who has been arrested in New-York for swindling Buffalo banks, is alleged by the authorities here to be the same individual who victimized a number of merchants in this city and Scranton by passing forged checks upon them and obtaining considerable money.

The Dartmouth Alumni Association in NewYork, which has been steadily growing in strength and fraternal spirit during the last five years, will have its nineteenth annual dinner at Pinard's this evening.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 9.--The eastern division of the Pennsylvania State Committee of the Prohibition Party met here this afternoon. The delegates present were from the Counties of Philadelphia, Bradford, Lackawanna, Luzerne, Montour, Susquehanna, and Columbia. They decided to appoint an organizer in each county, and to form clubs in every city borough, and to winship in the State for the purpose of promoting the interests of the party.

RICHMOND, Jan.--The snow-storm which began yesterday did not abate in violence until this morning. The snow has continued to fall lightly nearly all day and is now from 16 to 18 inches deep. It is undoubtedly the heaviest snow-storm since January, 1857.

The triangular plot of ground at the junction of Prytania and Camp streets is being prepared for the reception of Margaret's Monument. The fence that formerly inclosed the area has been removed and a quantity of material for raising the grade delivered there.

ALBANY, Jan. 11.--The annual meeting of the Regents of the University was held at 7:30 tonight in the Senate Chamber. Chancellor Pierson made the annual address. The officers of the board were continued for the ensuing year.

The public rehearsal of the Symphony Society is announced for this afternoon at the Academy of Music, under the direction of Dr. Damrosch. The regular concert will follow to-morrow night.

The inhabitants of Australia and the neighboring islands have been very unfortunate in the experiments made by them in acclimatization.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 11.--The pig-iron manufacturers of the West met in this city to-day. The association has taken a wider scope than was first planned for it, and instead of being confined to the West alone will have members from as far east as New-York, as far south as Alabama, and in the West and South-west will draw in all the prominent furnace men.
A Cincinnati paper heads the account of the election of Mr. Doxy to succeed the late Mr. Orth in Congress, "Orth-o'doxy."

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Jan. 11.--The Cape Ann Advertiser figures that the 275 barrels of mackerel taken in the Bay of St. Lawrence last year by the schooner Yankee Lass, of Boston, cost the United States, by remission of duties and interest on the Halifax award, not less than $1,400 per barrel. The Yankee Lass was the only United States vessel that fished in Provincial waters.
No man, after reading the published accounts of the burning of the Newhall House, in Milwaukee, can say that it was one of those disasters which human foresight could not have prevented.

PORT DURNFORD, Jan. 11.--Cetywayo has arrived here. Very few chiefs met him. COCHIN, India, Jan. 11.--A portion of the crew of the British ship British Empire, which was recently burned at sea on the voyage from Shields to Bombay, have landed here.

PROVIDENCE, R.J., Jan. 11.--The will of the late Miss Abby Smith, of this city, gives all her estate, some $4,000 or $5,000, to the American Baptist Missionary Union, of Massachusetts; the American Home Mission Society, of New-York, and the Rhode Island Baptist State Convention.
BOSTON, Jan. 11.--The Journal will print in the morning details of the effects of the prolonged drought in Maine, New-Hampshire, and Vermont.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11.--James W. Carson Co., prominent clothing dealers in Superior-street, made an assignment to-day to William Walton. The firm consists of James W. Carson, C.W. Chase, and S.D. McMillan, special partner to the amount of $15,000. The assets and liabilities cannot be told for several days. The firm was supposed to be quite solid, and the failure has created great surprise.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 11.--The Civil Service Reform Club organized here this afternoon. Edmund Tweedy was chosen President. It was thought that the next annual meeting of the national association would be held here next Summer.

WILMINGTON, Del. Jan. 11.--On complaint of the Western Union Telegraph Company's manager here, the Telephone Exchange has cut the telephone wire running to the Mutual Union Telegraph Company's office in this city, on the ground that the Mutual Union Company has violated its contract by using the telephone for the receipt of telegraph messages to be transmitted by its lines. WASHINGTON, Jan. 11, 1883. Clark Mills, the sculptor, became uncon scious at 9 o'clock tonight, and is expected to die before morning.

A lady, whose name was not disclosed by the Police, was arrested last evening in a dry goods store on Broadway, by an officer of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, on the charge of shoplifting. The Police think the prisoner is the victim of an unfortunate mistake.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11.--The Hon. Frank Brundage, of Lockport, County Judge of Niagara County, has resigned his office, and will come to Buffalo to practice law. Cleveland will appoint Judge Brundage's successor.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 11.--William Brush, who is suspected of the murder of his wife, at Stratford, about two weeks ago, was found in New-York last night and brought to this city this afternoon by Detective Weeks, of Pinkerton's force, and lodged in the Police station.

WASHINGTON, Jan 11.--The draft of the proposed treaty of reciprocity with Mexico is in the hands of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and Gen. Grant and Senor Romero appeared before that committee to-day and explained its provisions.
TRENTON, Jan. 11.--A shocking suicide occurred on the Belvidere division of the Pennsylvania Railroad in this city to-day.

The administration of the German empire is conducted on more economical principles than our own. In England 5,000 a year is the salary of seven leading Cabinet Ministers. At Berlin, the Chancellor of the empire and Prime Minister receives only 2,800, with a house and an additional 1,000 a year to keep it in order. The Secretary of State's salary is 2,500, with a free house.

Mr. Charles R. Thorne, Jr., the actor, is still confined to his bed. He passed a very restless night Wednesday,and during the day yesterday he did not seem to find much relief. In the evening, however, he suffered less pain and felt much easier. His appetite is very poor, and his physician has not yet thought it fit to encourage him to eat much. He is very weak.

The Providence Ease ball Association this evening re-elected Henry B. Winship President, with last year's board of officers. The Treasurer reported the receipts as $41,217, and the expenditures $36,592.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 12.--John B. Hoffman, a tailor, living at No. 40 Elder-street, fatally shot his son Robert, aged 22, at his home, this morning. Hoffman was drunk and had a quarrel with his son last night. This morning he arose early, and hid behind a door until his son started out to work, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12.--The Academy of Music to-night was crowded to suffocation to listen to Donizetti's "Linda di Chamounix," with Mme. Patti and Mme. Sofia Scalchi in the leading roles. The enthusiasm was great throughout the performance. The receipts for this single performance reached the very large sum of $10,250.

BOSTON, Jan. 12.--The meeting of the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, held here today, was for the purpose of inquiring into the condition of the road so as to obtain facts and figures for their forthcoming annual report.

An international bicycle-race was arranged yesterday in the Police Gazette office. The race is to take place in the American Institute Rink on Jan. 26 and 27. The contest will last 26 hours, and the winner is to receive half of the gate receipts and be known as the champion of the world.
PARIS, Jan. 12.--The body of Gambetta was removed at 6:45 o'clock this morning from Pere la Chaise Cemetery. There were very few persons present and no demonstration was made.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 12.--The steamboats Laura Lee and City of Greenville came into collision early on Friday morning. The former boat is in the Red River trade, and was on her down trip from Grand Ecore.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12.--The Supreme Court yesterday have a judgment dismissing with costs the appeal in the celebrated case of Grant against Beamley, which arose from the Orange and Green troubles in Montreal, July 12, 1878, and has since been before different courts. The appeal was dismissed on the ground of insufficiency of notice, and under the circumstances the Chief-Justice declined to express an opinion as to the loyalty of the Orange Association.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12.--A report of Prof. Dawson upon coal deposits in the Bow and Belly River districts of the North-west Territory contains an approximate estimate of the quantity of coal, which can be easily mined, and shows that the extent and richness of the coal fields guarantee an abundant supply of fuel in those districts for many years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12.--A purring-match for $250 a side was fought during the small hours this morning in Camden between Robert Tavish and David McWilliams. Heroic Englishmen of a certain class consider purring a sport.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12.--Philip Matthews, a German boy of 18, was hanged at Belleville to-day in the presence of a small gathering. He ascended the scaffold dressed in broadcloth and slippers.

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 12.--Mrs. Hettie Cunningham, a widow, to-day threw her threeyear-old boy from the suspension bridge at Fairmont into the Monongabela River, a distance of 52 feet, and then jumped in herself. Both were rescued after floating over the dam below the bridge, and were with difficulty resuscitated. No cause is assigned for the act.

The new steam-ship Aurania, of the Cunard Line, which was launched at the yard of J. G. Thompson, on the Clyde, on Dec. 26 last, will be added to the fleet which plies between Liverpool and this port.

Several years ago the John F. Briggs Company sold to A.T. Stewart Co. seal-skins of the value of $1,970. The money was not paid, and the sellers sued A.T. Stewart Co. for it. The latter put in a counter-claim for $5,000 damages, on the ground that the plaintiffs had misrepresented the character of other goods sold by them to the defendants.

BOSTON, Jan.12.--The brig Goldfinder, Capt. Stuart, from San Domingo, of and for Boston, was towed into Delaware Breakwater yesterday, having had four men frozen to death, the Captain frost-bitten, and only one man fit for duty. The vessel, covered with ice, was picked up at sea, 11 miles from Henlopen.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Jan. 12.--The Wabash Railroad Company will commence to-morrow to run through passenger trains from Toledo and Chicago by way of the Peoria and Shenandoah and Humestone Branch, just completed to this city.

"Young Mrs. Winthrop" was produced at the Madison-Square Theatre last evening for the one hundredth time. The play was greeted by an audience which filled every seat in the house, while a number of spectators stood during the two hours of the performance.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 12.--Several of the merchants of this city have petitioned the Collector of the Port of New-Haven for the establishment of a bonded warehouse of the third class, and Secretary Folger has, upon the recommendation of the Collector, granted permission for such warehouse. This arrangement will be of great advantage to New-Haven wholesale merchants, relieving them of the necessity of having foreign importations admitted through the New-York Custom-house.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 15.--One hundred and fifty men are at work searching for bodies to-day. The work proceeds more rapidly, yet the total result of the forenoon's search was only two bodies, which were so badly burned as to render recognition impossible. Thus far 20 little heaps--pronounced by the physicians to be human flesh and bones--have been taken from the ruins. As far as can be ascertained, 39 persons are still missing.

Williams, a prominent capitalist of this city, for $32,350, and the private property of the ex-President. R.P. Lee, who is now serving a term in the penttenttary, for $7,500 to T.S. SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 16.--The vote for United States Senator in the Senate to-day stood; Cullom, 30; Palmer, 20. In the House: Cullom, 75; Palmer, 75. This not being a majority in the House, there must be a joint ballot to-morrow, when Cullom will probably be elected.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 16.--The third annual meeting of the Cider and Cider-vinegar Makers' Association is now being held in this city. The association is working to secure the repeal of an act of Congress of March, 1879, which authorizes the use of the alcoholic vapor process in manufacturing vinegar. They claim that this act allows the illicit distillation of whisky.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The State Board of Health held a special meeting at the Capitol to-day. The Sanitary Committee gave a detailed statement of the work accomplished during the year in carrying out the laws to prevent the adulteration of food and drugs and to regulate the sale of dangerous kerosene oils. Nine kerosene accidents, four of which resulted fatally, were investigated.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The Board of Control of the Agricultural Experimental Station held a meeting to-day in the executive rooms at the Capitol, and re-elected Robert J. Swan President and Treasurer, and Gen. Curtis Secretary. The board will continue its session to-morrow.
