The amount of drifting ice in the Harbor was greatly increased yesterday by new fields which were supposed to have come from the Jersey flats. One very large field which appeared to be unbroken floated into the north River in the morning and reached half way across the stream.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 16.--Eli Saulsbury was re-elected for a third term to the United States Senate this morning, receiving 8 votes in the Senate and 18 in the House. The Republican State Senator Betts voted for Nathaniel B. Smithers. Three members of the House were not in their seats. John Mitch Houston, Jesse L. Long, and Samuel D. Truitt were respectively elected State Treasurer, State Auditor, and State Librarian.

The Count de Valcour de Vermont, a representative of the old French aristocracy, who has recently arrived from Paris, lectured last evening in the Church du Saint Esprit, in west Twenty-second-street, on "Contemporary Historians."

HARTFORD, Jan. 16.--Gov. Waller has renominated the Judges whose terms expire this year. Thes are Judges Dwight Loomis, of the Supreme Court, and Edward J. Sanford and Moses Culver, of the Superier Court. Their terms are for eight years from June next.

BERLIN, Jan. 16.--At the fifth representation of "Hamlet," which took place to-night at the Residenz Theatre, Mr. Booth was repeatedly called before the curtain. The Crown Prince Frederick William wes present, accompanied by Herr Werder, the well-known exponent of Shakespeare.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--About 7:30 o'clock lastevening the nail factory at Cummings, South Chicago, was burned to the ground, together with a warehouse and blueing-house. The fire was clearly of incendiary origin, as the watchman discovered oil-waste and kindling-wood at both the south-east and north-west corners of the factory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Mr. CARPENTER, of Iowa, submitted the conference report on the Agricultural Appropriation bill, and it was agreed to. AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 16.--In the Senate today the vote for United States Senator resulted as follows: William P. Frye, 27; Harris M. Plaisted, 3. In the House, William P. Frye had 108 and Harris M. WHEELING, W. Va., Jan. 16.--The Democratic Legislative caucus, held to nominate a candidate for United States Senator this evening, was harmonious. All the Democratic members in the city except one participated. John E. Kenna, Congressman from the Third District, was nominated on the third ballot. The election will take place next Tuesday.

BOSTON, Jan. 16.--A hearing in the case of Theodore Thomas against J.G. Lennon and others on the application to restrain the defendants from producing in this city a musical work by Gounod, entitled "The Redemption," was begun in the United States Circuit Court this morning.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 16.--The ceremonies incident to the inauguration of Robert E. Pattison as Governor has drawn a large number of people to the city, but, although great crowds are on the streets, the attendance is far smaller than that of any previous inauguration.
RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 16.--At noon today the Legislature balloted for United States Senator. The vote in the Senate was: M.W. Ransom, 33; William Johnson, 12.

A large audience was present last evening at the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Diet Dispensary in the hall of the Long Island Historical Society. Addresses were made by ex-Mayor Hunter, the Rev. S.H. Camp, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, and Judge Gilbert.

LIMA, Jan. 16. via GALVESTON.--Casma is now regularly blockaded by the Chilian turret-ship Huascar, and the Chilians will occupy the port in order to avoid complaints from the British merchants, who, while there was no war vessel there, had to pay double duties on shore and also to a Chilian launch. Seven hundred Montoneros are said to be at Sisiclaya, in the Lurin Valley.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 17.--Francis M. Pierce, of Buffalo, N.Y., an engineer on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, committed suicide here to-day by shooting himself through the head. He leaves a family in Buffalo. Despondency was the cause of the act.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 17.--A special from Silver Creek to the Herald reports that the colored miners, at a meeting to-night, refused to join the movement to resist the reduction of 5 cents a ton in the price of mining. The white miners are reported to be greatly excited over this action, as they fear that they alone cannot successfully resist the reduction.

A report of Sanitary Inspector Tracy in relation to the complaints made by the occupants of buildings in William and Pine streets of noxious odors, attributed to the pipes of the American Steam-heating Company, was submitted to the Board of Health yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--The annual report of the State Board of Charities was sent to the Legislature to-day. The value of all property held by the various charitable institutions of the State on Sept. 30, 1882, was $42,654,054; the receipts during the year were $9,768,395, and the expenditures $9,320,135.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17.--Miss Zeralda Garrison has been sent East by her uncle, who, on the advice of the family physicians, has decided to place her in an asylum for the treatment of nervous diseases.

A spirited and excellent performance of "She Stoops to Conquer" was given at Wallack's Theatre last night. The theatre was not crowded, though it contained a rather large audience. The weather was certainly discouraging, and this kept many people who would have been glad to see Mr. Wallack again as Charles Marlowe at home.

A large meeting of silk operatives was held in Paterson on Tuesday night, at which numerous grievances against their employers were discussed. It was claimed by several speakers that the tariff was no benefit whatever to the employe; that the ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 17.--A blizzard is reported as coming this way from Manitoba

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 17.--The joint resolution providing for the submission to the people of a constitutional amendment forbidding the payment of the railroad aid, the levee, and the Holford bonds was adopted in the Senate by a vote of 30 to 1. It will also pass the House.

MADISON, Ind., Jan. 17.--A large and enthusiastic citizens' meeting held here to-night organized a Commercial Exchange. The membership includes most of the prominent merchants and business men. John B. Ross was chosen permanent President. John Clements heads the Executive Committee.
GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 17.--A special dispatch to the News from Crockett says Taylor J. Hail was accidentally fatally shot to-day.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Jan. 17.--Another case of accidental shooting occurred here last evening. A few miles up the North-western Railroad, at Logan, a boy named Frank Porter was playing with a pistol, supposed not to be loaded, when it was discharged. The ball struck the wife of W.C. Codwell, a banker, in the abdomen, infliating a dangerous wound.

There was an unexpected flavor of wormwood in the cup of joy which the Democrats of Pennsylvania pressed to their parched lips at Harrisburg on Tuesday. They inaugurated a Governor whom they had chosen, and with the help of the Independents had elected.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 17.--Over $30,000 having been subscribed for an equestrian statue of the late Gen. A.E. Burnside, a meeting of the subscribers has been called to take steps to secure the execution of the work.

The rubber manufacturers held an adjourned meeting yesterday at the office of the home Insurance Company, No. 115 Broadway. Twenty-nine of the largest companies in all branches of the trade were represented by 35 gentlemen.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--Select and Common Councils met this afternoon to elect a City Controller in place of Robert E. Pattison, who was inaugurated Governor yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The Republican National Committee refused this afternoon, by a vote of 23 to 15, to adopt any new basis for the representation of the party in National Conventions.

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--At the annual meeting of the New-England Shoe and Leather Association held here to-day, Gen. Augustus P. Martin was reelected President and Charles S. Ingalls Secretary. The financial affairs of the association are in a flourishing condition.

LIMA, Jan. 17--Via Galveston.--There was a grand review of the Chilian troops here to-day, in honor of the anniversary of the occupation of Lima. Medals were afterward presented to the soldiers. The festivities were marred by the death of GenLynch's son.

The Old Guard reception, which takes place in the Academy of Music to-night, promises to be the most brilliant event of its kind in the history of the organization, and one of the most noteworthy receptions of the season. Unusual preparations have been made in the Academy for the comfort and pleasure of the guests.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17.--Gossips were to-day furnished with a piece of very unusual news, the announcement that the fortunes of a gentleman of 84 years and a lady 50 years his junior had been united for life.

In the action brought by Gen. Daniel E. Sickles against the Manhattan Gas-light Company to restrain the latter from removing the meter from his residence, Judges Dwight, Brady, and Davis, in Supreme Court, General Term, rendered an opinion yesterday affirming the decision of ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--The Illinois association of the Sons of Vermont held its sixth annual banquet at the Palmer House to-night. Four hundred persons, including many distinguished citizens of Chicago and the State, sat at the board.
The report of the operations of the Vaccinating Corps for 1882 shows that during the year 99,061 persons were vaccinated.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Jan. 17.--A dispatch from Weeksville, Montana, says "Billy the Kid," the notorious robber, was apprehended by vigilantes last night, and in attempting to escape was fired at as he ran. He reached the river safely, but at the second volley he sank from sight.
James Gregory sued the City to recover a balance of salary as Excise Inspector between Dec. 15, 1880, and Sept. 1, 1881. The case was tried before Judge Donohue in the Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims held its first business session to-day, the six months' interval since its organization which the law requires as notice to claimants having expired on the 14th inst. All three of the Judges--Wells, French, and Harlan-- were present, as was also Mr. J.A.J. Creswell, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17.--The Grand Lodge F. and A.M. assembled to-day in its ninetyfifth annual communication in Masonic Temple, in this city. About 300 members were present, including all the officers of the Grand Lodge except J.K. Wheeler, Grand Secretary, whose place was filled by L.A. Dickerson, Assistant Secretary.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Jan. 17.--The publisher of the Standard was cited to appear before the Supreme Court for inserting a letter libeling Judge Gray, charging that he conferred with the counsel of a party to a suit before giving judment in the party's favor.

At the hearing in the contest over the will of the late Sarah Burr yesterday, before Surrogate Rollins, John H. Riker, Miss Burr's legal adviser, being recalled, testified that he always found Miss Burr neatly dressed in a black silk dress and a lace cap.

William S. Blunt, dealer in pumps, at No. 100 Beekman-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edward G. Whittaker. He is said to have been very unfortunate through having been deprived of his eyesight for about 16 months, and in the meantime had to leave his business mainly with his employes. His liabilities are reported at about $10,000, of which $4,500 are borrowed capital.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 17.--A dispatch from Oxford, Miss., to the Times-Democrat says; "The Federal court has been busy all the week with the prosecutions growing out of the recent election in the Second Congressional District.

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--At a meeting of the Executive Council held to-day Gov. Butler made the following nominations: William E. Parmenter, of Boston, to be Chief-Justice of the Municipal Court of Boston; M.J. McCafferty, of Worcester, Associate Justice of the Municipal Court of Boston; ...

The Assembly Committee on Privileges and Elections, sitting at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, resumed yesterday the hearing in the contested election case of Robert E. Connolly against David Lindsay for the seat in the Assembly from the Eighth District of Kings County.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 17.--The voting in joint convention to-day was disastrous to Mr. Windom's hopes. He lost 5 from yesterday on the first ballot and 4 more on the second. The House received the Senate shortly after noon, and proceeded, in joint session, to ballot for United States Senator.

A gentleman who has arrived from Japan gives the following information of interest to Americans: The railroad built from Sapparo to the sea-coast in Yesso, by Col. J.A. Crawford, has proved so economical, and at the same time so satisfactory, that it is reported to be the intention ...

Five tables were filled with the members of the first panel of the Sheriff's Jury and their guests at Delmonico's last night. Covers were laid for 170, and the jurors exhausted not only the fines and fees of the body, but their individual pockets in the magnificence of their spread.
HARRISBURG, Jan. 17.--The Pennsylvania Editorial Association met here to-day and elected the following officers: President--W.M. Hensel, of Lancaster; Vice-Presidents--M.P. Handy, of ...

A portion of the crew of the German bark Amelia and the entire crew of the Norwegian bark Daeapo, both of which vessels were wrecked in the West Indies, reached this City yesterday. The Amelia was bound from Rio Janeiro for Cayes Avalo, which is on the southern coast of Cuba, near Cienfuegos.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17.--D.B. Chisholm, Secretary of the Albion and a number of other mining companies, has absconded. The Directors to-day received a letter from him stating that he was a defaulter to the amount of $7,800, and explaining how he had covered his crime.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--Mme. Albani and her husband, Mr. Ernest Gye, arrived here to-day from Albany and took up quarters at the Grand Pacific Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 17.--The Times says: "The scheme formulated by the Egyptian Government, approved by Lord Dufferin, and transmitted to the Foreign Office, proposes that the Khedive of Egypt shall have a Council of 12 responsible Ministers, and that a Legislative ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--In the House to-day, Charles T. Doxey was sworn in as the successor of the late Godlove S. Orth, of Indiana, and J.T. Cain was admitted as Delegate from Utah. Mr. RICE, of Massachusetts, called up the special order, being the joint resolution providing for a new mixed ...

Official returns still show that wolves exist in large numbers in France. Last year the number that were killed by persons who received the State awards amounted to 1,225. The amount annually voted for these awards and for other expenses attendant on the State campaign against the beasts is 150,000f.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The sub-contractor, Jaramillo, continued his testimony in the star route trial to-day. He said he paid $500 to be released from his sub-contract with John Dorsey; had never received any remitted fines.

At a meeting of the Board of Regents of the State of New-York held in Albany on Friday last, several amendments to the charter of the University of the City of New-York were proposed and unanimously adopted. Much discussion has arisen as to the object of the amendments and in what manner they would affect the university.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 17.--In the House to-day bills were introduced to allow women to vote on school matters; to compel hotel-keepers to provide ropes in rooms for escape from fires, and that ballots shall be on white card-board, provided by the State, and that nothing shall be printed on either side except the names of candidates.
Mlle. Martinez has been engaged to sing at the next Sunday evening concert at the new Casino.

ALBANY, Jan. l7.--The necessity of protecting the forests of the Adirondack region from further devastation, which has been fully appreciated and persistently urged by the press and by all intelligent bodies of men in the State except the Legislature, has at last been recognized by the Senate.
The Hon. Montgomery Blair is reported to be ill at his home in Montgomery County, Md.

DETROIT, Jan. 17.--There is no change in the Senatorial situation. Only one vote was taken to-day in joint convention, with the result of showing that the position of the contending forces is absolutely unchanged. Ferry received 59 votes, while 22 opposing Republicans scattered their votes on not less than 14 different candidates; and Stout (Democrat) received 50.

Mr. C.E. Kregelo, the undertaker, has a telephone at his house which is much used for business purposes. Mrs. Kregelo has a parrot which, being an unusually smart bird and good talker, has picked up the telephono language.
BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The mill property belonging to the bankrupt estate of R.O. Storrs, of Dedham, was sold at auction this morning at the low price of $47,800, or a little more than one-third of ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Roger S. Green, of Washington Territory, to be Chief-Justice of Washington Territory; Joseph Wasson, of California, to be United States Consul at San Bias, Mexico.

NEWPORT, Jan. 17.--Boston, Philadelphia, New-York, Providence, Baltimore, and other leading cities were represented here at a ball given tonight by the members of the Newport Club. It was a brilliant affair. The storm, however, kept many persons from attending.
TRENTON, Jan. 17.--In the Assembly to-day, Speaker O'Connor announced the following standing and joint committees:

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 17.--A convention composed of about 30 prominent gentlemen from various sections of the State met here to-day for the purpose of considering the cultivation of jute in Mississippi.
KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 17.--Ex-United States Senator Spencer left here last night for Halifax, en route to England. During his stay here he has been ceaselessly watched by two detectives.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 17.--Orso Fisher, a 16-year-old boy, was killed here last night while coasting. He struck against a stone post.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 17.--On the joint ballot to-day Cullom was elected Senator, receiving 107 votes and Palmer 95. The only one not voting was Adams, of Cook County.

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The condition of A. Bronson Alcott is reported as quite favorable at present, although he is confined to a reclining-bed nearly all the time. His right arm and leg are powerless, but his appetite is good.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--The employes on the New Capitol intuitively discover the day and the hour when bills appropriating money for continuance of work on the mammoth structure are to be brought up in either house.

ROCKPORT, Me., Jan. 17.--The following telegram was sent to-day to Senator Hale in reply to his remarks in Congress that opposition to Postmaster Rich at Camden was confined to the family of the ex-Postmaster:

TRENTON, Jan. 17.--It has been amusing to notice the shifting changes in the Senatorial situation here since the dispatch of last night was put on the wires. The unled and unorganized army of anti-McPhersonites have anxiously hunted for a leader and bowed themselves in the dust to every political Richmond that has ventured to come among them.

In the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court yesterday Judge Benedict listened to argument on the motion for leave to withdraw the plea of guilty entered by George D. Bayaud and Gustave F. Perrenoud, the New-street liquor-dealers, accused of removing and reissuing canceled internal revenue stamps.

Fire Commissioner Van Cott and Superintendent Smith, of the Fire Telegraph, called on Mayor Edson yesterday with reference to the proposed erection of a fire-proof building in which to keep a duplicate set of telegraph apparatus for use in case of a fire destroying the present building in Mercer-street.
LONDON, Jan. 17.--Mr. Gladstone, his wife and daughter, and the Rev. Stephen Gladstone, his son, started for Cannes to-day.
BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The following cable dispatch from the Imperial German Foreign Office at Berlin has been received by S.B. Schlesinger, German Consul here:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--Second Lieut. James B. Goe, Thirteenth Infantry, now on leave of absence at Bellefontaine, Ohio, has been ordered to proceed to Columbus Barracks, Ohio, and report by letter to the Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service at New-York City for assignment to duty at that post.

COLUMBIA, Jan. 17.--A very important suit, involving the validity of certain bonds issued by the State, has been commenced in Charleston County. The total funded debt of the State now amounts to $6,123,720, and the total unfunded valid debt to $448,104.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17.--A writ of quo warranto was issued to-day directed to Henry G. Lewis, Mayor of this city, on behalf of Frank S. Andrew, who was declared elected by 38 majority at the recent city election.

The members of the famous Blossom Club, in their elegant rooms at the south-west corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, were last evening very much occupied with the affairs of the club. Mr. Edward Kearney, the newly elected President, took command.

The trial of John Kenny, the bill-poster, for the murder of John Lennon, a car-driver, in October last, was continued in the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday. Samuel J. McDermott, who keeps a saloon at Tillary and Duffield streets, testified that he saw Lennon near his (the witness's) ...

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The match game of polo on skates between the Alpha Polo Team, of Lowell, Mass., and the Newports, of Newport, R.I., for the championship of the United States and five gold medals took place here to-night at the Olympian Club Skating Rink, in the Mechanic Fair Building. The Newports were victorious by a score of 2 goals to 1.
A meet of lot-owners of the Eleventh-Street Roman Catholic Cemetery and others whose relatives lie buried there was held last evening at Room No. 24, Cooper Institute.

At the sixth annual meeting of the Mercantile Benefit Association, last evening, in Masonic Hall, Twenty-third-street and Sixth-avenue, President Joseph W. Congdon said that the safeguards thrown about the admission of members had rendered it almost impossible for the association to suffer imposition from rascals, had obviated ...

Mr. William E. Esselmont, of Fordham, is a gentleman who has for years devoted his time and attention to sporting; he lives at the corner of Morris-street and the Ridge road and is engaged in the occupation of breeding horses.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--About noon yesterday heavy snow began falling and continued until this morning. Nearly two feet of snow fell on the level. The cable cars were obliged to stop last night, but are now running again.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--A portrait of Thomas West, third Lord Do la Warr, was formally presented to the city at noon to-day through Capt. Clipperton, the British Consul. It is the gift of Mary C. West, Countess of Derby. The original portrait is in possession of her family. Speeches were made by Consul Clipperton, Vice-Consul Crump, Count Galli, Joel Cook, and others. The picture will be placed in Independence Hall.

The American Society of Civil Engineers began its annual session yesterday morning at No. 127 East Twenty-third-street. The following officers were elected for the coming year: President --Charles Paine; Vice-Presidents--William H. Paine and Henry Flad; Secretary and Librarian-- ...

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 17.--A cold rain and sleet, which prevailed during the greater part of the day, compelled most of the vice-regal party to keep in-doors, materially interfering with their sight-seeing in Richmond.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Jan. 17.--On the Troy and Boston Railroad last night, a freight train in charge of Conductor Coneally and Engineer Morty fell through the bridge at Petersburg Junction, N.Y., smashing eight cars and piling them on top of each other in the Hoosick River.
The following sales of stocks and bonds were made by Adrian H. Muller Son in the Exchange Sales-room yesterday:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The members of the Republican National Committee met this morning in the parlor of the Arlington Hotel, the following being present:

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--At the annnal meeting of the State Agricultural Society to-day the following officers were elected: President--George F. Mills, of Montgomery; Vice-Presidents--C.R. Agnew, New-York; Isaac H. Cocks, Queens; ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--In the trial of the suit of John D. Weber against Col. Abner Taylor for damages for alleged criminal intimacy with Mrs. Weber, several witnesses testified to that lady's good reputation for virtue and chaste conduct. Col. Taylor, the defendant, testified that Mrs. Weber had frequently visited his office on business, but that the door was never locked, and that he was never criminally intimate with her, either in his office or elsewhere.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 17.--The jury in the Common Pleas Court to-day awarded the Rev. Pliny B. Morgan $12,000 damages in a suit against the Collage Hill Railroad. Dr. Morgan was thrown from a passenger car, which was run into by a loaded freight car running wild down a steep grade. His left arm was broken and his ankle so badly injured as to permanently disable him.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--The Senate Committee on Railroads this afternoon decided, by a vote of 6 to 1, to report favorably the three candidates nominated by the Governor for Railroad Commissioners. The report will be made to-morrow.
The Grand Jury yesterday dismissed the complaint against Edward A. Lavigne, a bookbinder, of No. 174 Third-street, who, while sitting at supper on the night of Dec. 26 with his wife ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17, 1883. Gold certificates of all denominations, to the amount of $6,000,000 have been sent to the Assistant Treasurer at San Francisco.

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--A meeting of the committee appointed by the Massachusetts Supervisors of Election, who officiated at the late election, to take action in regard to the reduction of their compensation, was held this afternoon, at which they voted to send a letter to Attorney-General Brewster protesting against the reduction, and asking his reasons why the full compensation allowed by law was not made.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 17.--In the Republican caucus to-night. Mr. Plumb was unani mously nominated for re-election to the United States Senate. This indicates his election on the first ballot.
DENVER, Jan. 17.--There has been no change in the Senatorial contest. The joint conference took but one ballot, which did not change the strengths of the candidates for the long term.
The Revue des Deux Mondes has concluded the publication of a work of considerable interest to all students of the history of human thought and of the working of the human mind.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17.--Papers are in preparation in this city for the institution of ejectment proceedings for the recovery of over 50,000 acres of land in North-eastern New-York, and upon which is situated the town of Whitehall.

No one has ever yet been able to account for the way in which people disappear suddenly, completely, and forever. A man of respectable character, a woman in comfortable circumstances, or a child happy in the possession of a full stomach and a top, ...

Circulars were sent out yesterday to holders of stock of the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company, containing blanks making William K. Vanderbilt, Augustus Schell, and Gen. J. H. Devereaux proxies at the annual election at Cleveland, Ohio, Jan. 30.

GALWAY, Jan. 17.--Thomas Higgins and Michael Flynn were hanged this morning for complicity in the murder of the Huddys. The public executioner, Marwood, officiated. They both walked firmly to the scaffold, and died without a struggle.

A gentleman who treasured up old banknotes recently died in this City, and his Executors overhauled his trunks. They found therein a large number of time-worn bank-notes issued by State banks many years ago.
GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Jan. 17.--The Ancona Print-works, of this place, are about to resume operations after several months of idleness. They employ about 300 persons.

The elections to the United States Senate which have thus far been held have secured for that body some of its best members for another six years, particularly on the Democratic side of the house. Mr. BECK has received a renewal of his commission from Kentucky, and the State could not have done better.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 17.--The Supreme Court this afternoon confirmed the compromise in the matter of the contested will of the late Joseph J. Cooke.

PARIS, Jan. 17.--The papers generally approve the arrest of Prince Napoleon, but nearly all of them condemn the vote of urgency in the Chamber of Deputies on M. Floquet's motion prohibiting the presence in France or Algeria of any member of former French dynasties.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--The leading produce markets were very much at variance to-day. Provisions were steady, with only a moderate volume of business doing, while grain was active at a sharp advance in prices, being apparently the subject of a speculative boom.

OMAHA, Jan. 17.--The first joint Legislative ballot for the election of a successor to United States Senator Saunders shows the same scattering of votes as did the first ballot in the separate branches yesterday.

A notable decision was rendered by the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday in the suit brought by the Attorney-General, in the name of the people of the State, against the New-York Central and Erie Railroad Companies. The case is the one which grew out of the freight-handlers' strike of last year.

At the meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday the board was informed that Controller Campbell had advertised the sale of the franchise of the Thirty-fourth-street ferry, and had fixed the upset rent at $2,000 per annum.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17.--Several months ago mention was made of a prospecting party having started for the upper waters of the Yukon River, Alaska, under the lead of Edward Schuffelin a veteran miner.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Jan. 17.--The condition of the steamer Pottsville, stranded on the south side of Squan Beach during the late storm, was less favorable last night, and the heavy sea accompanying to-day's storm has thrown her a little further up on the beach.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 17.--The principal attraction at this favorite sea-side resort--its high and green-swarded bluff--will soon be a thing of the past.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--The American Field will publish a reply from Capt. A.H. Bogardus, accepting Dr. W.F. Carver's challenge for a pigeon-match, and offering to shoot at 100 pigeons each at Louisville, Ky., between Feb. 1 and 10, and to decide the wing-shot championship of the world.
A meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday, and the standing committees for 1883 were announced by President Stephen A. Walker.
Another hearing was had before Judge Ingraham, in Superior Court, Special Term, yesterday, in the action brought by William S. Williams against the Western Union Telegraph Company.

Active preparations are making for the dramatic entertainment in aid of the Bartholdi pedestal fund, which will be given at the Academy of Music on the evening of Feb. 3, under the patronage of many of the most prominent ladies in New-York society.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--Ling Ah Dwe and Ling Ah You are on trial in the Criminal Court for the murder on Aug. 28 last of Sing Quon. It appeared in the testimony that Quon attacked Dwe with a Chinese pipe, whereupon Dwe ran out of the room, procured a knife from You, and returned and stabbed Quon to death.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 17.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Augusta and Knoxville Railroad to-day, the Directors were authorized to lease or sell the road on the most favorable terms.
ALBANY, Jan. 17.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, presiding, the following business was transacted:

COLUMBUS, Jan. 17.--The Ohio Democrats are not a little excited over the comments of the press on the action of the Democratic members of the House in having entered upon the Journal their protest against the resolution thanking Congress for the passage of the Civil Service bill.

Passengers are carried on the "emigrant" trains on the Sixth-avenue elevated railway, which leave either end of the road at 1:15 A.M. and 4:30 A.M. The former train runs to take the employes home and the latter to distribute them along the line.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 17.--Sidney S. Rider, a book-seller, made an assignment to-day. His liabilities are probably between $25,000 and $30,000.

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--A Democratic caucus of the members of the Common Council to-night voted 24 to 4 in favor of a viva voce selection of the heads of the city departments, instead of by secret ballots, as is done at present.

Several members of the Republican National Committee professed yesterday to be strongly impressed with the idea that the present is a bad time for making mistakes, and then proceeded to vote for a plan of representation in the next National Convention which is very likely to prove a mistake.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--The Assembly Judiciary Committee will report favorably Mr. House's bill prohibiting the soliciting of cases by keepers and others connected with prisons of the State where prisoners are held for trial.
BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The fifteenth annual meeting of the Woman's Board of Missions was held here to-day. been $124,843.
MONTREAL, Jan. 17.--The exports from this port for December were $509,000, an increase of $164,000 over the same month in 1881.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--The second day of the international curling tournament was occupied with a contest for the Gordon medal. Four rinks were played by the Chicago, Milwaukee, Portage City, and Buffalo Clubs. Portage City and Chicago led and will contest to-morrow for the medal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--In the Senate to-day the Post Office Appropriation bill was taken up. Mr. DAVIS, of West Virginia, called Mr. Plumb's attention to the item of $183,000 "for necessary and special facilities on trunk lines of railway," and asked an explanation.

A German version of "Hamlet," with Herr Ludwig Barnay in the title role and Frau MoserSperner as Ophelia, was produced at the Thalia Theatre last evening in the presence of a large and somewhat over-enthusiastic audience.

Mrs. Catherine Garrick, of No. 671 Lexington-avenue, who has shown such decided opposition to the erection of a telegraph pole in front of her house by the American Rapid Telegraph Company, appeared in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, accompanied by her counsel, Richard ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--It is expected that there will be a caucus of the Republican members of the House before the end of the week for the purpose of securing united action, if possible, in support of the Ways and Means Committee's tariff bill.

For months the stockholders of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, extending from Memphis, Tenn., to Stevenson, Ala., a distance of 272 miles, have been endeavoring to secure possession of their road, which is leased for 20 years from July 1, 1877, to the East Tennessee, Virginia, and Georgia Railroad.
BOSTON, Jan. 17.--Two ballots for United States Senator were taken in to-day's joint convention of the two branches of the Legislature without result, and an adjournment was had until to-morow.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--The testimony in the habeas corpus proceedings in the Delaware County Court for the possession of the Melville children was concluded this morning by the examination of a number of witnesses on behalf of Mrs. Melville.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to day: No. 1,091--The County of Alexander, plaintiff in error, vs. John F. Kimball; submitted by W.B. Gilbert for plaintiff in error and T.C. Mather for defendant in error.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17.--Nothing was done this morning about bringing Scheller into court for examination. The District Attorney will fully examine the case to-day. Messrs. Ebbitts and McKinny have been retained by Scheller.
Henry E. Hopkins was indicted by the Grand Jury for obtaining 65 boxes of pork tenderloin, valued at $390, from Armour Co., Chicago, on fraudulent orders to which the name of Aaron ...

The new Police Board of Long Island City met yesterday. Chief Woods presented a statement showing the condition of the department. The statement set forth that the department was in a very unsatisfactory condition.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18.--Since Mrs. Langtry and her devoted attendant, Mr. Gebhardt, came here the newspapers have kept the public fully posted upon their doings and their goings and comings.

ALBANY, Jan. 18.--Early this morning a portion of the north wall of the burned Tweddle Hall, fell crashing through the adjoining house in North Pearl-street, and rendering the interior almost a complete wreck.

DUBLIN, Jan. 18.--Mr. Davitt appeared before the Queen's Bench Division to-day. The court-room was densely crowded. Many members of the Ladies' League and Mr. and Mrs. Healy were present. The Judges declined Mr. Davitt's request to be allowed to question Sub-Inspector Seymour, who laid the information against him.

PARIS, Jan. 5.--Concerning the circumstances of M. Gambetta's death the autopsy of Tuesday goes to confirm the statement that he died of the results of a wound inflicted in a moment of exasperation by Leonie Leon.

The Associated Pioneers of the Territorial Days of Califorina, with their guests, to the number of 60, sat down to their eighth annual dinner, at Martinelli's, last evening, in commemoration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the discovery of gold in California.

A deep and mysterious plot to bear Lackawanna was discovered in the office of W.E. Connor Co. yesterday. Bad grammar, strange spelling, and a desperate piece of forgery were combined to accomplish the purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The differences between the House and the Senate in relation to the postal appropriation for fast mails on railway lines must be settled in a conference committee.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 18.--Carrington Baskerville, commission merchants and large dealers in tobacco, of this city, have failed. Their liabilities are placed at $125,000. The assets are not stated, but it is said the firm will pay 75 cents on the dollar.
UTICA, Jan. 18.--The Yonkers Club to-day defeated the Utica Curling Club at this place by a score of 59 to 54.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 18.--Under the laws of Louisiana river and bar pilotage is compulsory. Complying with the statute, therefore, the pilots some years ago, formed a close corporation, purchased boats, established agencies, , and divided profits pro rata.

TROY, Jan. 18.--Coroner Green last evening concluded the examination into the cause of the accident which occurred on the Troy and Boston Railroad, at Melrose, on Dec. 19 last, causing the death of Frank C. Brundage and John Riordan.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The bark Hattie N. Bangs, Capt. Atkins, before reported as having been picked up at sea abandoned and taken into Charleston, S.C., is owned by Capt. Elijah Bangs and others in Provincetown and in Boston.
When in command at Atlanta, Gen. Meade was quite popular, and visited the highest circles of Southern society, and was a particularly welcome guest at the house of Dr. Lawsche's parents.

Thus far the "Uncle Tom's Cabin" of Brazilian slavery has not been written, but when it is there will be no incidents lacking to fill it with horrors of which Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe never dreamed.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 14.--Cheatham Taylor and George Goldman, grocers and commission merchants, of this city, have made an assignment. The liabilities of both are about $15,000. During the last 12 months there has been a steady decline in the trade of Raleigh.

Surrogate Rollins yesterday granted the application of Mrs. Mary J. Hoyt and Miss Helen M. Hoyt, the widow and daughter, respectively, of the late Jesse Hoyt, for an allowance of $25,000 each. In the case of Mrs. Hoyt the sum of $3,000, which she has already received from the Executors of the will, is to be deducted, leaving here $22,000.

An audience which was somewhat larger than the audience which greeted Miss Mary Anderson on Monday night witnessed her performance of Berthe in "The Daughter of Roland" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening.

The discovery of a comet reported Saturday by Capt. Catharine, of the steam-ship City of Savannah, from New-York, was made by Mr. W. L. Burton, second officer of the ship, at 2 o'clock on Friday morning, 12th inst.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The President has decided not to interfere in the case of Charles Shaw, (colored,) convicted of the murder of his sister, and his sentence of death will be executed at the District Jail to-morrow afternoon. The Attorney-General made an adverse report upon the application for a reprieve or a commutation of sentence.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Jan. 18.--Last June the people of this State voted, as is well known, upon a constitutional amendment prohibiting the manufacture and sale of all kinds of spirituous and malt liquors except for medicinal, mechanical, and sacramental purposes, and the Government declared the amendment adopted.

Mr. Woollett's Longfellow recitals have been, we are glad to know, intelligently appreciated. Good-sized and sympathetic audiences have listened to these recitals in the Turf Club Theatre, and Mr. Woollett has been encouraged to go on with his excellent work.

DETROIT, Jan. 18.--The result of to-day's balloting for Senator seems to vindicate the suggestion made yesterday, that Ferry struck 12 on his first ballot. Three ballots were taken to-day, making a total of five thus far.
There was a great and gayly-dressed crowd in the Madison-Square Garden last night. Flags were suspended from the rafters and pictures of people in fancy dress were hung from beams and pillars.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--An advertisement which will appear in to-morrow's Tribune, announces the withdrawal of Messrs. Henry Field and Henry J. Willing from the firm of Marshall Field Co.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18.--Ten thousand dollars have been subscribed here for the sufferers from the floods in Germany. One or two balls and benefit performances at the theatres yet to be given to increase the fund.

ALBANY, Jan. 18.--The Assembly Railroads Committee well next Tuesday afternoon hear arguments on the Crane-McManus Five-cent-fare bill, and upon the McManus bill requiring all-night trains to be run on the elevated railroads.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The general courtmartial appointed to meet at Willett's Point, NewYork Harbor, by special orders of Dec. 22, 1882, has been dissolved. The extension of leave of absence granted to Capt. William Clifford, Seventh Infantry, has been further extended one month.
At the Signal Service Bureau yesterday it was reported that another cold wave was moving Eastward, and that very low temperature prevailed in the West.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The reception given by Mrs. Frelinghuysen and her daughters this evening to guests invited by card was one of the most brilliant social events of the season in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The Secretary of the Navy this morning received a telegram from Ensign Hunt, dated Kirinsk, Jan. 5, announcing the death of the Alaskan Indian Aneguin, which occurred at 2 o'clock A.M. of that day, from smallpox. Ensign Hunt was awaiting the mail from Irkutsk.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The Senatorship contest in this State ended to-day with the re-election of Senator Hoar on the first ballot of the day. This result was brought about by the action of the Crapo men. In response to the very urgent appeals telegraphed him by the ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The International Commission appointed to negotiate a commercial treaty between the United States and Mexico has held meetings at the State Department every day this week, and has made satisfactory progress in its work. From a well-informed source it is learned that a free list has been agreed upon, ...

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The one hundred and first anniversary of the birth of Daniel Webster was celebrated by the Webster Historical Society by a dinner at the Revere House this evening. A large number of persons was present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18, 1883. At a meeting of the Light-house Board to day, Vice-Admiral S.C. Rowan was elected Chairman, vice Rear-Admiral R.H. Wyman, deceased. Secretary Folger, who is ex office President of the board, presided at the meeting.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 18.--The trial of James H. Corey for extortion was continued this morning. Minnie Levy, the sister of Mr. Levy, who attended Mrs. Levy in her sickness, was put on the stand and examined for a few moments as to the actions of Corey in removing the furniture and disturbing Mrs. Levy while sick.

BUFFALO, Jan. 18.--Thomas Waldron, known as Brother Frank, a member of the order of Christian Brothers, and President of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic College, in this city, was arrested to-day and locked up, on a charge of rape, committed on Hattie Carr, a little girl 7 years old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 18.--In the Court of Common Pleas, at Westerly, this morning, the case of Zachariah Chafee, Trustee, against William Sprague for the possession of Canonchet, the Sprague villa at Narragansett Pier, came up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The Senate to-day resumed consideration of the Post Office Appropriation bill, the pending question being on the amendment appropriating $185,000 "for necessary and special facilities on trunk lines."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The first two hours of to-day's session of the Criminal Court were consumed in the identification of official papers concerning the star routes from Redding to Alturas, Cal., and from Eugene City to Bridge Creek, Oregon.

The delegates to the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which began in this City on Wednesday, were busily occupied yesterday. In the forenoon they inspected the dry docks at Erie Basin and the East River bridge.

Officers of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad were elected yesterday as follows: President--Gen. Edward F. Winslow; VicePresident--Theodore Houston; Treasurer--Conrad N. Jordan; Secretary and Assistant Treasurer--John L. Nisbet.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18.--The annual meeting of the New-Jersey Historical Society, held in the State House, drew a number of distinguished citizens from all parts of the State to this city today. President Samuel W. Hamill occupied the chair.

The details of a desperate encounter with a bear come to us from Hamilton County. John Walton, a farmer living on the outskirts of the great northern wilderness, had been engaged in drawing bark from the woods to a neighboring tannery.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18.--The Republican members of the Legislature have named Monday evening for their caucus in the United States Senatorial contest, while the Democrats have not yet designated a day for their caucus, though it is generally believed that it will come off on Tuesday night.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18.--The snow blockade has effectually demoralized railway traffic both in and outside of this city. The Western express, due here last night at 9 o'clock, only arrived at 7 this morning. All other trains were from four to seven hours late.
BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The morning session today of the Woman's Board of Missions was occupied with addresses by delegates from different portions of the United States and Canada.

PARIS, Jan. 18.--It is asserted that search warrants will be issued for domiciliary visits to the houses of several of the intimate friends of Prince Jerome Napoleon. President Grevy regards M. Floquet's proposal prohibiting the presence in France or Algeria of any member of former French dynasties as tyrannical.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--The leading produce markets were irregular to-day. Provisions averaged lower, with only a moderate volume of trading, while breadstuffs were higher, with some excitement, which, however, was not shared by corn. The later feeling was not far from being strong.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18.--The defeat of James McManes for re-election as a member of the Gas Trust practically finishes the work for which the Committee of One Hundred was organized, and is the Waterloo of the ring which has ruled and robbed the city for years. One by one the ringsters have been dislodged and their power broken.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18.--At the meeting of the Fire Commissioners this afternoon a communication was received from the Underwriters' Association asking for information regarding the condition of the department.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 18.--A suspension of business for three days, commencing this morning, took place in all the collieries in this district. It is thought that the collieries will suspend for three days each week until next March.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 18.--At the Republican legislative caucus held here yesterday afternoon to nominate a United States Senator, Preston B. Plumb received 106 votes on the first ballot, being the unanimous vote of the caucus. The balloting for Senator commences next Tuesday. There are 165 votes in a joint session.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18.--A stampede was caused in the Grand Opera-house here to-night during the performance of the "Lights o'London." In the third act the calcium light machine on the stage exploded with fearful force, causing great excitement in the audience of about 600.

WINNIPEG, Jan. 18.--Small-pox has broken out in the lumber camps near Rat Portage. Several deaths are reported, and about 12 cases are known in the Valley of St. Herbert, nine miles from here, and the surrounding country.

LARNED, Kan., Jan. 18.--The worst storm within the memory of the oldest inhabitant struck this section of the country at about 3 o'clock today, and is still raging.

With the conclusion of the Senatorial term of DAVID DAVIS, of Illinois, ends one of the most curious experiments in American politics. Exactly what Mr. DAVIS thinks of his venture into the field of political neutrality no man but himself, probably, knows.
County Clerk Keenan yesterday removed Edward J. Atkinson from the post of assistant docket clerk, the duties of which he had discharged efficiently for three years.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 18.--The Marquis of Lorne and the Princess Louise and party left here at 10:20 o'clock to-night on the regular mail train, on the Atlantic Coast Line, for Charleston. The two coaches in which the vice-regal party traveled all the way from California were left here, and the party now occupy a special sleeper.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 18.--The striking icemen on the Hudson created considerable disturbance yesterday, and to-day the strike at one time threatened to become general. Gangs of men patrolled the river this morning between Saugerties and Catskill, compelling all laborers to stop work.
ALBANY, Jan. 18.--Most of the session of the Senate to-day was spent with closed doors, the subject under discussion being the confirmation of the Railroad Commissioners nominated by the Governor.
Many of our readers are familiar with the case of the State of Georgia against Doc Wilson. The defendant in this case was charged with the offense of murder.

The third of the series of popular matinees was given yesterday afternoon, and was highly successful alike in the matter of attendance and in the artistic excellence of the performance. The enterprise of the managers is to commended.

DENVER, Jan. 18.--The balloting in joint conference in the caucus of the Republicans has not changed the result in the Senatorial contest. All the candidates are holding their strength, the only change perceptible being that Tabor and Bowan are exchanging with each other, but their combined strength will not nominate.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 18.--Another sensation has occurred here in connection with the disappearance of Mrs. Robinstein. Tuesday night her two sons, Carl and Otto, left their home in a cab, and have not been seen or heard of since. They are about 17 and 19 years of age, respectively. Their disappearance cannot be accounted for.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 18.--A snow-storm from the north has prevailed here all day, and the snow is now six to eight inches deep on the level and is drifting. There has been no delay yet in travel, but it may be expected if the storm continues.
OTTAWA, Jan. 18.--Prof. Wiggins claims the storm of yesterday to have been a verification of his October prediction. The second storm is fixed for Feb. 9.
BOSTON, Jan. 18.--Life-saving Station No. 4, Maine, reports boarding, previous to Jan. 15, the British brig Stanley, from Halifax, for New-York, off Bunker's Ledge, in distress.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 18.--Mrs. Catharine A. Pettengill, widow of the late Hon. A.A. Pettengill, died at her residence, in this city, yesterday. She leaves an estate valued at about $200,000.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18.--The annual banquet of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association took place to-night at the Carrollton Hotel. Over 200 persons were seated at the tables.
MADRID, Jan. 18.--There were renewed shocks of earthquake in Murcia to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18.--A letter submitted to Gov. Stephens yesterday details a horrible crime perpetrated near Homer, in Banks County, Saturday night. Joe Patterson, son of John Patterson, of that town, is a young man of about 25 years of age, and is described as rough and uncouth in manners.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 18.--Three Senatorial votes were taken in the Legislature to-day. Windom lost in all 6 votes and Cole gained 4. At 12 o'clock the Senate was announced at the doors of the House, and three minutes later the third joint ballot was in progress.

SEATTLE, Wyoming Jan. 18.--The steamer Josephine, which left this city yesterday for Skagit River, having on board a full freight and 20 passengers, blew up yesterday afternoon in Port Susan Bay, 50 miles north of this port.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--A caucus of Republican Representatives will be held in the hall of the House to-morrow afternoon, immediately after adjournment. It is understood that the caucus has been called at the instance of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, and that the subject of discussion is to be the Tariff bill.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The projectors of the proposed New-York and Boston Inland Railroad, whose application for a charter in this State was granted yesterday, say that their plans for building the road as speedily as possible are completed. If work should be begun at once the line could not be constructed in less than two and a half years.

ALBANY, Jan. 19.--Mr. Van Allen, Republican, of New-York, attempted to pledge the Assembly to-day to a plan of procedure that would tend very materially to shortening the legislative session. He offered a resolution calling for a session every day in the week, Sundays excepted. Practically only three days of every seven are now utilized in attending to public affairs.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 19.--Harry V. Chapman, a 9 year-old boy living in Lake-street, a few weeks ago donned a pair of black stockings. In some manner he chafed one of his heels, and the coloring from the stocking got into the wound.

FORTRESS MONROE, Jan. 19.--Arrangements are being made here for testing a new style of torpedo, the invention of some New-York parties, which, if found satisfactory, will materially increase the risk of an enemy's vessel approaching any of the harbors along the sea coast.

PARIS, Jan. 19.--The French trade returns for 1882 show an increase of imports amounting to 108,000,000f., and of exports amounting to 34,000,000f. This is considered unfavorable. Ninety-eight millions of the increase in imports are under the head of manufactures, and the increase in exports is divided between manufactures and raw materials.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20.--It is stated on good authority that the Prince of Wales and suite will visit Canada the first week in March next, remaining in this country until after the meeting of the Science Association. It is also said the party will probably visit the prominent cities of the United States.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 20.--Apprehensions are felt that the Savannah River will overflow its banks. At 6 o'clock it showed 28 feet 6 inches, and is rising at the rate of 2 inches an hour.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 20.--The worst blizzard of the Winter struck St. Paul yesterday and raged all day, the fierce blasts raising the snow in sheets and drifting it badly. The storm was general throughout the North west and much more severe at other North-western points than at St. Paul.

George Norman, 3 passengers and crew of 26, came ashore at 1:30 A.M., three miles north of Green's Run, Md. All hands saved by crew of Lifesaving Station No. 5."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--At the close of the morning hour in the Senate to-day the Post Office bill was taken up. The pending question was on the amendment changing the date when the reduction of letter postage from 3 to 2 cents shall take effect from Jan. 1, 1884, to July 1, 1883.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--A special dispatch from Matamoros, Mexico, says: "News has been received here of a desperate battle near Tehuantepec between the Seventh Battalion and the Tehuantepec Indians. BOSTON, Jan. 20.--Three fairly interesting bicycle events occured at the Institute Fair Building this afternoon in the presence of about 1,000 spectators. The first event was a five-mile straightaway race for the championship of the Bay State Wheel Club.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 20.--Schaefer Meyers, proprietors of the Shelly-Street Brewery, in this city, one of the largest brewing establishments in the West, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of the creditors.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 20.--The weather continues damp and very foggy. The Vice-Regal party passed the day very quietly in their quarters at the Charleston Hotel. Great public interest continues to be manifested at their presence in the city.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 20.--The search in the ruins of the Newhall House was finished to-day. Two charred bodies were found, making 48. Of 177 people said to be in the hotel at the time of the fire 176 are now accounted for, as follows: Indentified, 28; non-identified, 46; saved, 102.

ANNAPOLIS, Nova Scotia, Jan. 20.--Mrs. Sarah Dakin, niece of the late Hon. Joseph Howe, has been missing since last night. A large party has been searching for her all day without success. It is feared that she has been drowned.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 21.--Early this morning the body of Mrs. Sarah Lake was found on the shore of the bay. Her death resulted from intemperance and exposure. She was a native of Lakeville, Mass., and at one time was possessed of uncommon ability and refinement.

LONDON, Jan. 21.--The Hamburg-American steam-ship Cimbria, while on her way from Hamburg to Havre, was run into Friday morning during a dense fog by the British steam-ship Sultan. The Cimbria sank in a few minutes. The disaster occurred in the German ocean off the Island of Borkum, 26 miles northwest of Emden.

HAVRE, Jan. 21.--The General Transatlantic Company's steamer Labrador, Capt. Servan, which sailed from New-York Jan. 3, has arrived here. She brings the crew of the French steamer Picardie, which sank at sea last week.

McFarland, and D.B. Stewart as managers or officers of said company, as proceedings to restrain them from acting have been instituted in court, and Judge Church, of Meadville, has issued a preliminary injunction.

SCRANTON, Jan. 21.--Mayor T.N. Powderly, of this city, who has been Grand Master Workman of the Knights of Labor of America since 1879, has resigned that position, and the Executive Board will take action on the resignation at a meeting in Pittsburg to-morrow.
BUFFALO, Jan. 21.--The telegraphic chess game between Buffalo and Toronto, which was adjourned without result a week ago, was resumed Saturday night, when the tourney was again adjourned ...
There is a difference in the English and American methods of sending transatlantic mails which is decidedly favorable to the postal service of this country.

Recently some Kingston vocalists went into the country and gave a concert in aid of a church. One of the singers made a few gestures with his hands and swayed his body to the time of the song he was singing.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21.--There was no bloodshed following the departure of Mrs. Langtry to-night, but this was due to Gebhard, who, instead of taking the same train as the Jersey Lily, boarded the Vandalia train, and, although he had promised to go ...

An Austin merchant says that Col. Harris Cheever, a member of the Legislature, is the champion impolite man of Texas. "What did he do that was so impolite?" was asked. "I met him on the avenue," replied the merchant, "and he did not lift his hat to me, and it is the same hat I sold him on credit during the session of the Legislature."

COLUMBUS, Jan. 21.--The call of the Chairman of the Republican State Committee for a meeting in this city on Tuesday next, together with the invitation extended to the Republicans of the State to be present for the purpose of consultation and a general interchange ...
TRENTON, Jan. 21.--The Senatorial struggle will be renewed here to-morrow, and there is promise of some interesting developments.
The turf has suffered irreparable loss, within so short a time, by the recent deaths of Lord Stamford and Mr. F. Gretton. Neither Mr. Gretton nor Lord Stamford have successors to "carry on the game."
LONDON, Jan. 21.--Mrs. Litton, the actress, is ill, and it is feared that her illness may result fatally.

ST. JOHN, Quebec, Jan. 21.--The Rev. Mr. Renaud, of St. James's Church, of this city, preached a powerful sermon on the Bible this evening in refutation of the doctrine enunciated by the Rev. Mr. Newton, of New-York, last Sunday.
The mistake at the opera-house last evening which ended in the shocking calamity was made by young Anson Farrington, who had charge of the calcium cylinders.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21.--A member of the National Tobacco Association, just returned from Washington, states that there is little prospect of the passage of any bill during the present session of Congress for the relief of the tobacco trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The Signal Officer at Atlantic City, N.J., reports: "The ship Frederick E. Scammel, before reported ashore on Brigantine Shoals, is now afloat and lying at anchor inside of the shoals in about three fathoms of water."
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21.--During a row in a dance-house at Waco, Texas, last night, Bill Houston, a negro musician of the establishment, was killed, and W.T. Wright, a white visitor, mortally wounded.
Solomon Bortnik, one of the Russian Jewish refugees at Ward's Island, raised a disturbance there yesterday afternoon and severely beat Israel Pressman, one of the watchmen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The programme for the coming week in Congress is unusually simple, and may be described with corresponding brevity.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21.--Another contribution of 15,000 marks for the benefit of the sufferers by the flood in Germany has been sent to the President of the German Reichstag. More will follow.

DUBLIN, Jan. 21.--At the hearing of the charges of conspiracy in the Police Court yesterday, as Farrell, the informer, proceeded with his story, smiles were observed on the faces of some of the prisoners.

An orderly-book captured by Marinus Willett in the sortie made from Fort Stanwix while the battle of Oriskany was in progress and British troops and Indians under Sir John Johnson were defeating Gen. Herkimer and the Militia of the Mohawk Valley has been long in the possession of the Willett family, and only recently was printed in the Magazine of American History.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21.--At a few minutes after 4 o'clock this afternoon the city was shaken by a heavy explosion.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--Gounod's sacred trilogy, "Redemption," was presented to-night to a packed house at the Boston Theatre, with the omission of the orchestral parts, the introduction of which is enjoined by the court.
Julius Davy, a Hungarian, 20 years old, while carelessly handling a loaded pistol in his room, at No. 26 Montgomery-street, at a late hour last night, accidentally discharged it.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 21.--The new steamer Fall River, for the Old Colony Steam-boat Company, will make a trial trip early next week.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached the seventh and last sermon of his series on the uses of the Bible yesterday morning, in the All Souls' (Anthon Memorial) Church, of which he is Rector. His subject was:

The title of this volume we give in full, as it is only just to the author to show in his own words how comprehensive his plan is. He begins at the beginning, so far as he knows where the beginning is, and comes down in this first of his two volumes to the year 1800.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 21.--Red Cloud received more than 100 callers to-day, including the Mayor, college Professors, and prominent citizens. He did not attend church, being somewhat indisposed. He is much gratified at the attentions paid him.
About 31,500 citizens of Indiana have petitioned the Legislature to submit the proposed prohibitory amendment to the popular vote.
The manager of the Brooklyn Base-ball Club has engaged suitable grounds at Third-street and Fifth-avenue, Brooklyn, for his team next season.
TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 21.--The influenza is very prevalent among the horses here. A large number have died.
Not content with having destroyed the ships of the Navy, Mr. ROBESON now proposes, as a fitting close of his public career, to demoralize the officers of the Navy.

PARIS, Jan. 8.--It began to rain on the eve of the funeral of M. Gambetta, and the rain fell heavily through the night, moving with anguish the hearts of thousands who awaited the manifestation of the sorrow of France.
The concert arranged by the Liederkranz and Arion Societies to aid the sufferers by the floods in Germany, will take place in Steinway Hall to-morrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--In view of the pending commercial treaty with Mexico, the official statistics of trade between Mexico and this country, recently compiled by the Bureau of Statistics, are peculiarly interesting.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21.--M. Eisenstadt Co., wholsale jewelers, Nos. 703 and 705 North Fourthstreet, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors. Their liabilities are said to be $110,000 and assets $80,000.

Capt. Sinclair, of the steam-ship Amy Dora, which arrived yesterday from Newcastle, reports that the unusual length of the passage, which occupied 25 days, was owing to the fact that he crossed by the southern passage and met with much bad weather.

Mr. Mapleson's Italian opera company will be in St. Louis this week at the Olympic Theatre where "I Puritani" will be produced to-night with Mme. Albani as Elvira, and Signori Ravelli, Galassi, and Monti in the principal male characters.

Some seven years ago Mr. Bancroft published, under the title "History of the Native Races of the Pacific States," five extensive volumes of what purports to be an exhaustive research into the character and customs of the aboriginal races, which inhabited the western slope of this continent at the time when the first conquerors and explorers landed in those distant regions.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 21.--Upper Reynoldstreet and Washington road, above Hawk's Gullv, in the north-western portion of this city, and the fair grounds and lands in the south-eastern portion are covered with water.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21.--A dispatch from Tehichipa concerning the accident to the southern express train near there yesterday, confirms the death of Mrs. Downey and says ex-Gov. Downey is badly hurt, but will recover.
EASTON, Penn., Jan. 21.--Public sympathy here is entirely with the 50 Hungarians who are now confined in jail by reason of the railroad war at Penargyl.
--The third volume of Prof. Villari's "Machiavelli" has recently appeared in Italy.

ALBANY, Jan. 21.--The Assembly Committee on Contested Seats is expected to make its report in the latter part of this week. Its members have prudently kept their own counsel, and little that is definite can be learned of the course which ...

The funeral of Capt. Gustavus A. Fuller, the Adjutant of the Old Guard, formerly a Captain of Company C, Ninth Regiment, took place yesterday afternoon from the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Madison-avenue and Fortysecond-street.
On train three from New-York on the Erie Railway yesterday morning, there was a little 9-year-old girl named Mary Ann Donohue, entirely unattended, on her way to join relatives at ...

At the Fordham Police Court yesterday, Officer Peter Delaney, of the Thirty-fifth Precinct, arraigned before Justice Morgan a sharp-faced, cunning specimen of humanity, who said he was John G. Gilbert, an English Canadian, recently of Lewiston, Me.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--At a meeting to-night in the Central Church in aid of the Liberia College, West Africa, addresses were made by President Eliot, of Harvard; Profs. H.W. Browne and T. McCants Stewart.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 21.--The Grand Lodge of the Jewish order of B'nai B'rith for Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, Colorado, New-Mexico, Kentucky, and Missouri met in annual session here this morning, and will continue at work for three days. President Braun's message was delivered in the afternoon. The next meeting will be at Evansville, Ind. The report of A. Abrahams, who for 20 years has been the Secretary, elicited much favorable comment.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 18--This is about Decoration Day, and we must be getting ready for the Fourth of July, if the weather is any guide.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 21.--The Monroe County Land League, at its meeting to-day, resolved to take up a subscription to the fund for constructing the pedestal for the Bartholdi statue of Liberty Enlightening the World.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--Representatives of the French and Direct Cable Companies arrived here from North Eastham and Rye Beach yesterday and left for New-York to-night, their purpose being to open in that City an office independent of the Central Cable office, into which their wires now run.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 21.--The evidence in the case of John W. Lane, the Custom-house Weigher, in this city, who was removed on Nov. 5 for alleged irregularities in office, which makes several hundred pages of printed matter, has been referred to Secretary Folger for his action. It is believed that the evidence is sufficiently favorable to secure his reinstatement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--Claus Spreckels, the sugar monopolist of the Hawaiian Islands and San Francisco, is talking about establishing a sugar refinery in Baltimore.
Dedicatory services were conducted last evening by Bishop Simpson at the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh-avenue and St. John'splace, Brooklyn.

Henry Orr, 33 years old, is lying wounded at his home, No. 163 East One Hundred and Twelfthstreet, and, if what he says be true, there was a deliberate attempt to slay him through a hired assassin on Saturday night.
BOSTON, Jan. 21.--The annual report of the State Board of Health, Lunacy and Charity, will be submitted to the Legislature to-morrow.

Nestled in the bosom of the County of Chemung, within the confines of the fertile southern tier, lies a cluster of houses and barns which compose a beautiful little village, to which the natives have given the name of Elmira.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 22.--The railroad miners will meet to-morrow to consider the resolution passed in the general convention last week advancing the price of mining from 3 to 4 cents per bushel.

An overheated still in Sone Fleming's oil refinery, on Newtown Creek, exploded yesterday afternoon and caused a fire which created damage to the amount of $5,000. The head-cap of the boiler blew out, instantly killing James Varley, of No. 77 Herbert-street, Greenpoint, and disfiguring his body in a dreadful manner. Thomas Purcell, foreman of the boiler shop, was missing after the fire, and it is feared that he perished in the flames.

A meeting of the Journeymen Jewelers' Standard Association was held last evening at No. 189 Bowery. John E. Meyer presided. There were present delegates from the jewelers' associations in Newark, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Chicago.

Judge Benedict, in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court, yesterday denied an application made by George D. Bayaud and Gustave F. Perrenoud, the New-street liquor-dealers, who were indicted for defrauding the United States revenue, to withdraw their plea of "guilty" and substitute a plea of "not guilty."
The 11 boxes seized at Jersey City Saturday night were yesterday removed from the Western Union office to the court-room of Justice Davis, where they were placed in charge of Detective Grimes.

PHILLIPSBURG, Jan. 22.--The Court of Chancery to-day, on application of David W. Howell, granted an injunction restraining the Delaware Rolling Mill, at this place, from paying any claims, contracting any debts, selling any iron, or running any of its machinery.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 23.--William Brimble, an Englishman, keeper of a small saloon called the Traveler's Rest, in Asylum-street, quarreled with his wife at 12:45 o'clock this morning, kicked her severely, and then drew a razor from his ... pocket and cut her throat and then his own.

BOSTON, Jan. 22.--The Rev. Francis B. Hornbrooke, of Newton, has been called to succeed the late Dr. Bollows as Pastor of All Souls' Church, New-York City. He has not yet decided what answer to return to the call.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--James F. Brown and John Carey, of Oregon, were called to the witness stand in the star route trial this morning and gave testimony relative to the route from Canon City to Fort McDermott, Oregon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22.--A dispatch to Wells, Fargo Co. from Carson says a store at Gold Mountain was robbed Thursday or Friday by mounted and masked men. The proprietor and two clerks were killed.

Miss Nettie A. Brown, daughter of Superintendent Thomas J. Brown, of the Erie Railroad, was married in the Church of the Incarnation on the 27th of December to Mr. Jacob Food Hitchcock, and among those invited to witness the ceremony were a Mrs. Sheldon, of Philadelphia, and ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 22.--The State Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic will meet in this city on Jan. 30 and will be in session for two days. Preparations are being made by Ely Post, No. 97, to entertain 1,000 delegates and visitors.
For one reason or another the Fifth-Avenue Theatre was but half filled last night, when Miss Mary Anderson appeared there as Galatea in Gilbert's play "Pygmalion and Galatea."
FALL RIVER, Jan. 22.--There is no change in the condition of the strike of the iron-workers at Somerset. The works have not started up to-day.

A singular case of successful surgical treatment is presented in the person of Simon Lodenski, a Roumanian Jew, who came to this country last December with a letter of introduction to Dr. George M. Lefferts, of No. 6 West Thirty-thirdstreet, from Dr. MacKenzie, of London.

BOSTON, Jan. 22.--The Journal will say in the morning: "The Grand Jury has indicted George R. Eager, Edwin M. Fowle, and Abner J. Benyon upon evidence obtained from a written agreement which came into the possession of Mr. Linus M. Price, Receiver, last Tuesday.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Jan. 22.--Two of Whitall, Tatum Co.'s hollow-ware glass factories have suspended operations on account of there being no demand for their product. This throws nearly a hundred men out of work.
Robert Garrett, of Baltimore, is at the Brevoort House. Ex-Senator D.B. St. John, of Newburg, is at the Hotel Brunswick.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--It is very generally conceded that the weather is cold, very cold, colder, in fact, than it has been since Jan. 4, 1879. At that time the thermometer marked 21 below zero at 7 A.M., 20 at 8, 19 at 10, and 13 at 12 o'clock noon.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 22.--In joint legislative convention to-day the roll call brought out no actual changes. Several of Windom's votes were absent or paired and thus disappeared from the footing.
The thirtieth anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association was celebrated last evening in Association Hall, President William W. Hoppin presiding.

It is evident that some sort of "huggermugger" is being practiced in regard to the proposed leases of certain privileges in Yellowstone Park.
The first grand rally of the New-York Sunday-school Choral Union was held last evening in the Broadway Tabernacle.
The "Merry War" was revived at the Thalia Theatre last night, and received so cordially that it will he repeated to-night and on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22.--The Mapleson opera company began a week's season of the opera here this evening in Bellini's "I Puritani," with Mme. Albani in the role of Elvira, assisted by Signori Ravelli, Galassi, and Monti.
Rosa Herbst, a costumer, had masquerade dresses for hire at the ball of the Cercle de l'Harnonie last night and was aided by her daughter Rosa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--"There never was such a boom in pugilism before," said W.E. Harding, the sporting editor of the Police Gazette, this morning. "Every one who knows how to handle his fists is spoiling for a fight.

Thomas Fitzgerald, 18 years of age, was committed by Justice Power, in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, to await the result of injuries to Mary Alice Morse, whom he had stabbed.

The trial of a suit brought by James M. Selover, a broker of this City, against Jerome B. Chaffee, United States Senator from Colorado, to recover $750,000 damages, was begun in the Supreme Court, Circuit, Part III., before Judge Donohue and a jury yesterday.
