SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22.--It is rumored on the street that the steamer Oregon, which left here on Saturday for Portland, has foundered. The report can be traced to no authentic source, and is discredited at the Merchants' Exchange. The steamer should arrive at Portland this evening.

The new iron steam-ship Nacoochee, of the Ocean Line, which plies between this port and Savannah, arrived yesterday from Chester, Penn. She was built for this line by John Roach Son. Her dimensions are: Length, 313 feet; breadth of ...

ALBANY, Jan. 22.--In response to the Assembly resolution calling for information upon the prison contract labor system and its financial results, State Superintendent of Prisons Isaac V. Baker to-night presented his report.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 22.--Messrs. R.B. Roosevolt and Seth Green, New-York State Fish Commissioners, in the yacht Heart's Ease, dropped anchor at this port to-day. They have been two months making the voyage from New-York on account of bad weather. They will spend the remainder of the Winter in studying migratory fish in Florida waters.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 22.--From official sources it is learned that there is no probability of the Prince of Wales visiting the United States and Canada during the coming Spring, as has been stated.

PANAMA, Jan. 22, via Galveston, Texas.-- News has been received here from the Republic of Ecuador to the effect that the revolutionary party there is triumphing. The port of Esmeraldas has been captured, the Dictator's troops having been defeated after 18 hours' firing. A triumvirate composed of Carbo, Montalvo, and ... Alfaro has been appointe with the latter as Supreme Director.
DENVER, Col., Jan. 22.--The Senatorial contest is still undecided. In caucus to-night Pitkin received 20 votes on the first ballot, but did not reach that number again.
Forty of the 900 members of the New-York County Medical Society met last evening at the monthly meeting of the society, in the College of Physicians and Surgeons. President Daniel Webster presided.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 22.--The first regular ice-boat race for the season of the Monmouth Boat Club was sailed this afternoon over the 15-mile course between the Scud, sailed by Capt. Throckmorton, and the Uncle Bob, sailed by Capt. Coley. The Scud won by half a length in 20:40.

The trial of John Kenny, the bill-poster, for the murder of John Lennon, a Myrtle-avenue car driver, was resumed in the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday. Detective Charles Chambers testified that he went to Kenny's house, at No. 88 Prince-street, about 10 o'clock on the morning of the murder.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 22.--In the Ulster Oyer and Terminer this morning District Attorney Clearwater moved sentence in the case of Robert Behrlee, convicted at this term of the court of assaulting George B. Merritt, a prominent dry goods merchant of this city, with a revolver.

Texas was comfortably warm yesterday, if the weather report is to be believed, but that was where the cold wave which struck New-York Sunday afternoon gathered itself together before starting out over the country.

Kate Armstrong, a servant, was arrested on the night of Jan. 15 for being drunk and disorderly, and, after being looked up was found unconscious in her cell, having attempted to hang herself with a scarf. She was indicted for attempted suicide, and, on being arraigned in the General Sessions Court yesterday, pleaded guilty.

Aunt Sally Story was brought out from the County Jail, at Paterson, N.J., yesterday, and into the court-room near by, to stand trial on an indictment for poisoning Mrs. Elizabeth Feest, a neighbor, at Little Falls, last September.
BOSTON, Jan 22.--The report of a difference of opinion in the directory of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad over the question of the extension of the line has been revived.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 22.--The Marquis of Lorne, accompanied by Capt. Domville, of the Dido, visited Fort Sumter this morning, and on his return he lunched with the Captain on board the Dido. The Princess Louise did not leave her apartments during the day.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 22.--Mr. W.A. Engeman, who some weeks ago received a five years' lease of the Louisiana Jockey Club Grounds, has finally concluded, and so announces to-day, to postpone the Winter meeting altogether.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--A general courtmartial has been appointed to meet at West Point, N.Y., at 11 A.M., Jan. 24, for the trial of such prisoners as may be brought before it.

The depositers of the wrecked City Bank of Jersey City held a meeting last night at which the committee appointed to confer with Receiver Williams reported that that gentleman had given them all the information in his power.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--The leading product markets were active to-day and irregularly stronger. There was a general burst of confidence in "values" in the early morning, which lasted until about noon, and then the enthusiasm waned.

ALBANY, Jan. 22.--Mr. De Witt, Democrat, of Ulster, received a knock-down blow to-night in an attempt to railroad a bill relative to the city of kingston through the Assembly.

The Legislature of this State has been in session three weeks. It is about two weeks since the standing committees of the Assembly were announced and all the machinery of legislation was put in working order.

A dispatch received yesterday from Niagara Falls says that Thomas Hilsen, of Philadelphia, a man about 65 years of age, of respectable and wellto-do appearance, jumped yesterday morning from the Luna Island bridge, and was carried over the Falls. He had been staying several days at the Hotel Kaltenbach.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 22.--The Cleveland Rolling Mill Company's steel-works and rail mill will resume operations to-morrow morning, the repairs having been completed. The remainder of the works will continue running as usual.
NEW-YORK, Jan. 22. The Western Union time-ball dropped today exactly at noon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--The resolution providing for evening sessions to consider the Tariff bill was discussed in the Senate to-day until 1 o' clock, when several Senators called for the regular order, the Tariff bill, which was taken up.
ELKTON, Md., Jan. 22.--A boiler at the Ledger Paper Mills, near this place, exploded at 7 o'clock this morning, wrecking half of the large building. Patrick McCormick was killed.
The Assembly Committee on Privileges and Elections resumed its hearing in the contested election case of Coffey against Sheridan at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last evening.

In the Westchester County Surrogate's Court, at White Plains, yesterday, the contestants of the will of the late Mrs. Adelaide Cutter, of West Chester, who died leaving an estate worth $250,000, began their case, the proponents having concluded their testimony.

BOSTON, Jan. 22.--The first indication of a conflict between Gov. Butler and the Legislature appeared in the House of Representatives this afternoon, when the question of printing 10,000 extra copies of the Governor's inaugural address was brought up.
John Doran, a laborer, of No. 416 East Seventeenth-street, on Sunday assaulted his wife, Mary Ann, with a knife in the street near their residence, and inflicted severe wounds in her side and arm.

Col. J.H. Mapleson has decided to give an entertainment with the leading artists of his opera troupe at the Academy of Music, in this City, on the evening of March 27th, the proceeds of which are to be applied to the founding of fellowships and scholarships in the Washington and Lee University.
A three-fourths length picture of Mr. L.J.N. Stark has been presented to the Produce Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22, 1883. The President has approved the act making appropriations for the Agricultural Department for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1884.
Schedules of Daniel V. Arguimbau and William W. Wallis, assignors for the benefit of creditors, to Octavius D. Baldwin were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--At the meeting of the Council Committee on Railroads this afternoon, Frank Adams, Corporation Counsel, furnished an opinion adverse to the interests of the proposed elevated railroad.

Ex-Sheriff James O'Brien brought a suit against Erazm J. Jerzmanowski to recover damages, charging that Jerzmanowski had deceived and defrauded him by inducing him to purchase 50 shares of the New-York Steam Cable Towing Company by representing that the stock was worth $75 per share.

A mandamus to compel State Controller Davenport to honor drafts made by the Commissioners of Emigration against the appropriation of $200,000 made for them by the State Legislature at the session of 1882 was granted by Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the important constitutional case of the United States against R.G. Harris and others, brought here upon a certificate of division of opinion from the United States Circuit Court for the Western District of Tennessee.

The first of the series of six Monday organ matinees at Chickering Hall was given yesterday by Mr. Archer, and was in every respect a successful performance, the attendance being unexpectedly large and the artists without exception in admirable musical condition.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 22.--Major George F. Barnes, Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue, and a posse of four men returned this morning from a successful and daring raid on the moonshiners of Calloway County.

The pews in the Brooklyn Tabernacle were sold by auction last evening. The system of assigning pews in that manner was began last year, when the schedule rental of the pews amounted to $9,457 and the premiums to $2,622.
The drowning and burning of the traveling public was practiced with eminent success last week by a German steam-ship company and an American railway company.
George F. Slosson, who published yesterday challenges to William Sexton and Jacob Schaefer, yesterday deposited $500 forfeit money at the office of the Clipper on the two wagers.

The Western Union Telegraph Company propose to try two systems of laying its wires under ground, in neither of which, however--according to Dr. Norvin Green--it has much faith.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 22.--The Dominion Government declines to entertain the demand of Murphy, counsel for W.J. Hall, the Newark fugitive ...
Miss Helen Bancroft, a young lady whose beauty has been much talked about, appeared at the Turf Club Theatre last night as Julia in Sheridan Knowles's comedy, "The Hunchback."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22.--The explosion of the Point Clement Giant Powder-works yesterday was one of the most disastrous to human life ever known on the Pacific coast, but it is now known that the number of Chinamen killed is not so great as was at first reported. There are not over 30 missing.

The trial of Charles H. Warren for murder in the first degree in having caused the death of Patrick H. Dwyer, proprieter of a pool-room at No. 108 Bowery, on the night of Sept. 21 last, was before Recorder Smyth, in the General Sessions Court, yesterday.

EASTON, Penn., Jan. 22.--The Pennsylvania, Slatington and New-England Railroad Company, through some of its officers and its attorney, at a conference held here to-day, decided to abide the decision of the court in the difficulties now existing ...

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 22.--The Democrats succeeded in getting the members into caucus this evening, but the result is unsatisfactory, even to the triumphant part, and it is doubtful if it will be of more binding effect at the decisive moment than a mere informal conference.

HAMBURG, Jan. 22.--The Diamant, one of the steamers sent in search of the missing passengers and crew of the Cimbria, arrived here this afternoon with 16 passengers and a fireman of the ill-fated vessel.
LIBAU, Jan. 22.--The ship Vorwarts has been sunk off this place. Eight persons were drowned.
If passengers on the Sixth-avenue elevated railway do not catch the "emigrant" or "owl" train they have no other opportunity to ride up or down town between midnight and 5:30 A.M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--The National Republican to-morrow will contain an interview with Gen. Grant on the subject of the reciprocity treaty between the United States and Mexico.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22.--James McManes, the recently dethroned "boss" of the Gas Trust, will make another effort to get back into the position from which he has just been ousted.

A number of Brooklyn men interested financially in the proposed underground road in that city, called on Mayor Low yesterday and showed ahim the profiles and plans of the projected tunnel which were exhibited to the Aldermanic Railroad Committee last Spring.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 22.--Two Senatorial ballots were taken to-day, being the sixth and seventh joint ballots.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--On Thursday the time allowed to Appraiser J.Q. Howard, of New-York, in which to file with the Commerce Committte of the Senate his protest against the confirmation of A.P. Ketchum, nominated by the President to succeed Howard, will expire.
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 22.--Red Cloud, the Sioux, guest of Prof. Marsh, will leave this city for Washington at 9:40 o'clock to-morrow morning.
BELFAST, Jan. 22.--At a meeting of merchants held here it was decided to start a new line of steamers between this port and the United States.

PARIS, Jan. 22.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Cuneo d'Ornano questioned the Government in regard to the removal of Prince Napoleon's manifesto, and charged the judicial authorities with violation of the Press law of 1881.
Henry Pearson, a young Englishman, who makes his living by canvassing, entered a Broadway stage near Wall-street on the afternoon of Saturday, Dec. 16, to ride up town as far as Twelfth-street.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 22.--Reuben R. Springer is seriously ill with catarrhal pneumonia
COLUMBUS, Jan. 22.--This morning, about 10 o'clock, Samuel C. Bell, son of Representative William Bell, Jr., of this city, attempted to kill his wife by firing two shots from a pistol at her.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22.--The Call publishes the following interview with Mr. Howard Tilton, of Yale, British Columbia, the freight agent of the Canada Pacific Railway Company, who was on board the Southern Pacific Railroad train at the time of the disaster.

The committee to consider the proposed plans for giving this City an increased water supply resumed work in the Mayor's office yesterday. Various communications were received, among them one from George B. Butler, which made the committeemen smile.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Herman Biggs, late Captain and Assistant Quartermaster, to be Captain of Staff on the retired list.

Messrs. Lanman Kemp, of William and Cedar streets, and Moore Warren, of No. 57 John-street, have complained to the Board of Health of the "unbearable stench constantly emanating from the pipes of the Steam-heating Company," which, it was asserted as made many persons sick.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--In the Senate this morning Mr. MORRILL moved to proceed to the consideration of the Tariff bill, saying that if the motion were agreed to he would assume that the Senate preferred to take up the bill each day rather than to hold evening sessions.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 23.--Another account of the attempted robbery of a Central Pacific Railroad train is to the effect that at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning six or eight robbers ordered the engineer of the west-bound train to move on and then took possession of the east-bound train.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--The annual meeting of the Drug Exchange was held this afternoon. The annual record of the Board of Directors was read. It states that in June last a committee was appointed to take charge of the interests of the drug trade and chemical industry in connection with the revision of the tariff.

Assistant District Attorney Fiero moved for the sentence of Bayaud Perrenoud, the convicted liquor-dealers, in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Benedict, yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The Herald will say in the morning that the Park Theatre and International Hotel property, Nos. 615 to 619 Washingtonstreet, has been purchased by Messrs. Abbey Scaoeffel, the managers of the theatre. The terms of the sale are private, but the price is understood to be in the neighborhood of $300,000. Important alterations and improvements are expected to be made.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23.--The Sydney (New South Wales) Herald has the following details of the disaster at the Australian mine on Dec. 12: "The accident occurred at 5:30 A.M. in the drift from No. 2 shaft, which unexpectedly broke into the old workings of No. 1 shaft.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The fifteenth annual meeting of the Ticonderoga Trotting Association commenced this afternoon on Lake George, near Ticonderoga, N.Y. The ice was in fine condition and the attendance large.

The death of Gustave Dore at the age of 51 finds the world unprepared. Was he as old as that? one asks, and at the same time a short mental calculation of the length of years during which he has been before the public and the prodigious number of works of which he was the maker changes the wonder the other way.

Four orders were issued by Inspector Esterbrook yesterday to the proprietors of as many hotels directing that additional means of egress in case of fire be provided.
MONTGOMERY, Jan. 23.--Last evening the Marshal appointed by the Commissioners who constitute the municipal authorities of Opelika attempted to arrest a man who was violating the town laws.
Selah C. Carll deposited in the Bank of the Metropolis some United States registered bonds which had the name of the payee erased and his own substituted.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23.--The inquest on the Newhall House fire commenced this forenoon The first testimony read was a deposition written by Mr. Bleecker, manager of the Tom Thumb troupe.
The trial of the action brought against the Northampton National Bank by Mrs. Fannie D. Wylie before Judge Wheeler and a jury in the United States Circuit Court was continued yesterday.

A large number of members and friends of the Nineteenth Century Club gathered last evening in the parlors of the home of Mr. and Mrs. Courtiandt Palmer, No. 117 East Twenty-first street, to listen to a paper read by Mrs. Julia Ward Howe on reminiscences of Emerson and Longfellow.
By a decision of the Court of Appeals, yesterday, a new trial is granted in the case of the New-England Iron Company against the Metropolitan, formerly the Gilbert, Elevated Railway Company.
SCRANTON, Jan. 23.--The trial of John Connors, of this city, who murdered his wife with a carpenter's square last Fall, at their home in Providence, was begun here to-day before a crowded court-room.

MONTREAL, Jan. 23.--Immense crowds of visitors have arrived here from all points of the Dominion and the United States to witness the Carnival. The weather is remarkably suitable for outdoor sports, and everything is favorable for a gay time. The Contractors' Association turned out in great force this morning for their annual drive. About 200 well-equipped sleighs, with two and four horses to each, were in the procession.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 21.--The announcement of the return of Sir T.F. Wade as British Minister excites surprise in many quarters. The highest Chinese officials profess to have understood his last leave-taking as final.

Judge Barrett yesterday vacated the order of arrest in the suit of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien against Erazm J. Jerzmanowski, which was issued on the allocation of O'Brien that Jerzmanowski deceived and defrauded him by misrepresenting the value of stock of the New-York Steam Cable Towing Company.
CAICAGO, Jan. 23.--The packers at the stock yards are just beginning to realize the loss caused by the arctic blast. To them it is a serious blow.
The Palm Garden, in Fourteenth-street, opposite the great Tammany Wigwam, was taken possession of on Monday by the Sheriff.
OTTAWA, Jan. 23.--Some misapprehensions seem to exist as to the real effect of the suspension of the Imperial Extradition act of 1870, and the coming into force of the Blake act of 1878.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--A sensation was caused in the star route trial to-day by the testimony of A.W. Moore, who was at one time intimately connected with the Dorsey star route service in Oregon and elsewhere.

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 23.--A dispatch from Keyser, West Va., to the Intelligencer says: "One of the most terrible railroad accidents that ever occurred in this part of the country happened on the George's Creek and Cumberland Railroad, running from Cumberland to Lonaconing, Md., to-day.
ALBANY, Jan. 23.--The leading topic of discussion this evening is the probable outcome of the open executive session to-morrow on the question of confirming the Railroad Commissioners.
Barbara Finck, 62 years old, fell out of a window at No. 528 West Twenty-seventh-street Monday night and was killed.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 23.--A special to the Sentinel from Waupaca, Wis., says: "Alfred Vandecar, "Whisky" Welsch, and Charley Freeman, are the parties arrested for the murder, on Oct. 7, 1882, of H.C. Mead, a banker of this city.

The President having signed the "act to regulate and improve the civil service of the United States," commonly known as the Civil Service Reform bill, the next step in order is the appointment of the Commissioners, and upon this will largely depend the success of the law in securing the reform which is intended by it.

A fire broke out at No. 192 Greene-street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, at 2:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and spread rapidly. In a few moments three buildings to the westward and two to the eastward were in flames.

CUMBERLAND, Jan. 23.--About 2 o'clock this afternoon a wheel broke under a car of a coal train on the Georges Creek and Cumberland Road, near Pompey Smash, seven miles west of this city, throwing about 60 loaded cars and two locomotives down an embankment.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 23.--William H. Smith, of the Philadelphia Evening Star, and at present a member of the Gas Trust, was nominated by the Governor today to succeed David H. Lane as Recorder of Philadelphia. The nomination of James P. Lindsey for Harbor Master of Philadelphia was confirmed by the Senate.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 23.--The steamer Allentown, from Philadelphia, coal laden. which struck on Middle Ledge this morning, knocking a hole in her bottom, and was subsequently run ashore on Butler's Flat, in the lower harbor, lies in an easy position.
The trial of Aunt Sally Story, at Paterson, N.J., for poisoning her neighbor, Mrs. Feest, was continued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23, 1883. Gen. Grant and Capt. S.L. Phelps, ex-Com missioner of the District of Columbia, were among the President's visitors to-day. Gen. Grant is understood to be in favor of the appointment of Mr. A.M. Clapp, of New-York, as District Commissioner.

Prof. C.A. Young, of Princeton College, N. J., delivered an entertaining lecture last evening before a large audience in the Church of the Strangers. His subject was "The Planetary System," and he illustrated his remarks with stereopticon views of the different planets and their orbits.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 23.--The Wardens and Vestry of Christ Church in this city, the oldest and most respectable Episcopal congregation in Alabama, have called the Rev. Joseph L. Tucker, ...

TORONTO, Jan. 23.--Joseph Hiscock, who has been troubled with insomnia for some weeks, yesterday told his wife he was going into a trance for three days and nights, and shortly afterward he to all appearances died. His body is kept in a warm room and carefully watched by his family until the time of the trance expires. The doctors pronounce the man dead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Jansen, the notorious resurrectionist, who has lately returned to Washington, after four or five years' absence in the North, was to-night arrested for the violation of an ordinance of the Health Department forbidding the transportation of a human corpse through the streets of the city, without a permit from the Health Officer.
BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The House, this afternoon, by a vote of 97 to 95, rejected the resolution providing for printing and issuing 10,000 copies of Gov. Rutler's inaugural address.

CANDELARIA, Nev., Jan. 23--John Chiatovich's grocery store at Silver Peak, Nev., was attacked on the night of the 21st inst. by two men named Rockwell and Tex. The robbers were repulsed by the inmates of the store, who sustained ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23.--The latest news from the scene of the gun-powder explosion near Berkeley is to the effect that the total number of bodies recovered from the ruins is 26. So far as known this number includes all that were killed. The Coroner's jury made an investigation and rendered a verdict that the victims came to their deaths by a powder explosion, the cause of which was unknown.

The calcium lights which shed their mellow radiance upon the ice of the Manhattan Skating Rink at the hour of 8 last evening, illuminated three young men on skates who were securely grappled from behind by three other young men, not on skates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--There has been more or less talk here for many years about the local gas company, which has been able to maintain its monopoly against many attempts in Congress to establish other companies.
MADRID, Jan. 23.--A detachment of Spanish troops has occupied the coast of the island of Tavitavi, off Borneo.
BERLIN, Jan. 23.--The requiem service for Prince Charles was held in the marble hall of the palace at 8 o'clock this evening.

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--The Senate devoted most of its time to-day to the bill prohibiting the Commissioners of Emigration from drawing any more money from the appropriation of $200,000 made last year than has already been drawn--$90,000.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 23.--The Shrewsbury River, which at this point is a mile and a half wide, is frozen over from shore to shore and from the New-York and Long Branch Railroad bridge to the Highlands.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23.--In the Senate today Mr. Taylor, of Trenton, offered a bill which, if passed, will give New-Jersey bank depositors more security than they have heretofore had against hank Cashiers. It requires Cashiers before entering upon

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--A special dispatch to the Times from Harrisburg says: "AttorneyGeneral Cassidy is preparing a special Message, to be sent to the Legislature at an early day, by the Governor, to divert public criticism from Pattison's now admitted blunder in appointing Cassidy, opening a violent and sweeping crusade against railroads and other corporations in the State.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--Judge Lowell, of the United States Circuit Court, gave an opinion today in the case of Theodore Thomas against Joseph G. Lennon to restrain the latter from producing, Gounod's "Redemption" with orchestral accompaniment.

TRENTON, Jan. 23.--The houses balloted separately for United States Senator at noon today. The five who were so conspicuously defiant last evening surrendered without terms. Senator McPherson was nominated in both branches by the Democrats; ex-State Senator ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--A long debate upon the Naval Appropriation bill prevented the House from taking up the Tariff bill today, and it is probable that the tariff debate will not begin until Thursday.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 23.--General dissatisfaction is manifested in the anthracite coal region by the companies with the three days' suspension plan.

CHESTER, Penn., Jan. 23.--Samuel Gast, of Iowa, and his nephew, Davis Gast, of Ohio, traveling cancer doctors, and James E. Haines, a student, of Rising Sun, Md., were arrested to-day, the two first mentioned at Bellefonte, this State, and ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--In the star route trial this morning A.S. Powers was further examined. In answer to questions by Mr. Bliss he said that when he was here at the last trial he had a conversation with Rerdell in relation to remissions for failures. Rerdell told him it would cost 50 per cent. to get the remissions. He cited one case where he had taken one of the clerks out to dinner at some expense.

MATAMOROS, Mexico, Jan. 23.--A strong body of Indians have been murdering and robbing people in the vicinity of Hermosillo. Four Customs guards and 20 ranchmen pursued them yesterday. The Indians fortified themselves behind breastworks on the Romero Mountain. The ranchmen assaulted the works, killing five Indians and wounding many others. Several of the ranchmen were wounded, but none killed. Eleven soldiers in Guadalajara yesterday murdered the guard and deserted.

Inspector Byrnes received a postal card from the Police authorities of Dallas, Texas. on Dec. 28, informing him that the City National Bank, of Dallas, had been defrauded of $6,100, on Dec. 16, by a forged draft, and asking him to arrest the forger.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--General Manager Morrell, of the Boston, Hoosac Tunnel and Western Railroad, states in an interview that it is not true that the negotiations between his company and the West Shore Road for the purchase of the former west of Schenectady have fallen through.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--It was shown in THE TIMES several months ago, in a dispatch relating to land grant railroads, that the pro jected railroad from Mobile to Girard, in Alabama, had received nearly 500,000 acres more land than could have rightfully been claimed ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--The weather as yet shows no signs of moderating. The temperature at 8 A.M. was 20 below zero. The area of cold seems to have its centre over Lake Michigan. Its western edge rests on the Missouri River and its northern boundary is unknown.

In August, 1879, an order was made by Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, allowing William J. Best a compensation of 5 per cent. of the assets of the National Trust Company for his services as Receiver of that corporation. This percentage reached the sum of $88,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--The leading produce markets were very much unsettled and irregular to-day. They were strong early, prices advancing markedly from the reduced figures of the previous afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 23.--The Rothschilds invite subscriptions to a Brazilian loan of 4,000,000 at 4 per cent, at 89.

BERLIN, Jan. 23.--Mr. Edwin Booth appeared here to night as King Lear for the first time during his engagement at the Residenz Theatre. The performance was a splendid success, Mr. Booth being called before the curtain 18 times.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23.--A meeting of representative Republicans from various parts of the State was held in the hall of the House of Representatives to-night for the purpose of a full consultation and general interchange of views.
The court of inquiry into the circumstances which occasioned the loss of the Cimbria will be confronted with a direct conflict of evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--A hearing was had before Judge Butler in the United States Circuit Court to-day on a motion on behalf of H.S. Spofford, Librarian of Congress, for an injunction to restrain the Fireside Publishing Company from selling a book called "American Politics," of which Thomas Cooper, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, is the author.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 23.--The calling of the case of Frank James in the Criminal Court here to-day was the occasion for the gathering of a large crowd of curiosity-seekers around the Court-house, and when the case was taken up at 2 P.M. the court-room was literally jammed.
